PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Harry Jenkins) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. I refer him to the superannuation provisions in the Australian Labor Party-Australian Council of Trade Unions accord mark II. I ask: What criteria or test must be met to qualify as an isolated circumstance? Are the current claims by the Transport Workers Union of Australia and the Federated Storemen and Packers Union of Australia isolated circumstances? Are there any others? What action has the Minister taken, in light of the Government's so-called special relationship with the union movement, to persuade the Transport Workers Union and the Storemen and Packers Union to drop their irresponsible industrial action in pursuit of those claims?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The claims by the Transport Workers Union and the Storemen and Packers Union in respect of superannuation are matters to which the Government has been giving considerable attention. Let me say firstly in respect of the Storemen and Packers' claim that it is not a claim, as I understand it, for payment prior to 1 July next year but a claim about its right to have payment into a storemen and packers' superannuation fund rather than into some industry scheme. This is a matter, therefore, of the type of superannuation fund or the particular superannuation fund rather than a dispute about when payment should commence.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government has made several attempts to bring that dispute to an end. We have been in touch with the ACTU about it several times. The Government appeared in the case before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission last Thursday but, unfortunately, the dispute still continues and it has had a substantial effect on the vehicle building industry, with stand-downs of several thousand employees. Given the fact that the dispute has not been resolved, I have called a meeting of all the parties for tomorrow afternoon to see whether we can finally resolve this issue.

The claims that have been made by the Transport Workers Union are in respect of the major companies, and it has been said that they may form some special or isolated circumstance. The Transport Workers Union is not asking for the whole of the transport industry to have superannuation commence from some time prior to 1 July. That is most certainly not the case. In discussions I had with union representatives, it was agreed that for the industry as a whole there would be no commencement prior to 1 July 1986.

However, the union has insisted that there is some special and isolated circumstance in relation to some companies. We have said to the union that if there are such particular circumstances it should put them to us and we would then consider them. At this stage that has not been done. I understand that discussions are occurring this afternoon between the Transport Workers Union and Mayne Nickless Ltd, one of the largest transport companies. It remains to be seen what comes out of those discussions. However, I should say that I have spoken to the company about that and I believe that the company is concerned to ensure that there is as little flow-on as possible in respect of superannuation prior to 1 July and it may well be that there will be no flow-on of any kind.

We said to the Transport Workers Union and to the companies involved that, if they are to argue that there is some special and isolated circumstance, that must be done in the context of negligible cost, because that is involved in the Arbitration Commission's wage fixing principles. Principle No. 11 states that, if there are any claims outside those which are picked up in the rest of the principles, they should be of negligible cost. If they are not of negligible cost they should be reported to the Full Bench of the Commission for consideration. The Government believes that that is an appropriate way to go. If there is any suggestion of some payment outside negligible cost, in the way that that is understood under the wage fixing principles, it should go to the Full Bench of the Commission for consideration one way or the other.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Prime Minister: What is the Government's view of the recent United States of America-Soviet Union Summit meeting? Was there any progress on arms control and other issues of interest to Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I know that you and the House will excuse me if I preface my answer by saying how pleased I am sure all honourable members on both sides of the House are to welcome back the honourable member for Chifley after his severe illness. The Minister for Foreign Affairs, the Minister for Defence and I were particularly interested to receive this morning a briefing on the Summit meeting from Mr Allen Holmes of the United States State Department, who had come to Canberra from Geneva to brief us as the personal representative of President Reagan. That courtesy extended to us by the President reflects the courtesy and closeness extended to the Government in the pre-Summit period.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Government is encouraged by the outcome of the Summit. It was clear from the briefing that we received this morning that President Reagan and General-Secretary Gorbachev have engaged each other's respect and interest as world leaders. While acknowledging, of course, that serious-in some respects quite fundamental-differences continue on a number of critical issues, they have committed themselves to a process of confidence building and expanded dialogue between their two countries. Given the complexity of the subject matter and the importance of the interests involved, it is not surprising that there was no particular breakthrough on arms control and disarmament. We are anxious, of course, that both sides carry through their commitment to give political impetus to the Geneva arms control talks. Even before the Summit had taken place the Summit itself had the beneficial effect of stimulating both sides to develop their negotiating positions in a constructive manner.

Australia was particularly encouraged by the new commitments to co-operate in the areas of nuclear non-proliferation and limiting chemical weapons. Australia has been particularly active in these areas and it was pleasing this morning that our leadership in the area of chemical weapons was positively acknowledged by Mr Holmes. Looking ahead, another encouraging point to emerge from this morning's briefing is that the United States Administration is determined to improve the relationship with the Soviet Union in steady, incremental steps, avoiding the wild swings that have so far characterised relations between the two countries in the post-war period. That sort of realistic approach to East-West relations is entirely consistent with the policies of this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Prime Minister inform the House whether the guidelines currently being determined to govern the superannuation arrangements outlined in the renegotiated accord will require appropriate employee contributions?

—All I have to say on that matter is that the Treasurer is currently formulating those guidelines. He will be doing that in consultation with the business community and the trade union movement, and he will be making a statement in the near future on that matter.

—Has the Minister for Trade seen reports that bauxite and alumina sales from the Gove project in the Northern Territory involving Swiss Aluminium Limited have been made at artificially low prices which have been arrived at on a less than arms length basis? In this connection I refer the Minister to reports in the National Times of 11-17 October which claims to cover the history of this project, and refer to the pricing policy by which attempts were made to subvert Australia's national interests and its control over this important commodity.
—Order! I suggest that the honourable member get to his question.
—Thank you, Mr Speaker. Can the Minister advise what action he is taking in respect of these exports?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Kingston for his question. I take this opportunity to commend him on his job in representing the Australian Government at a recent meeting of the International Bauxite Association. He was called upon to chair that meeting held in Kingston, Jamaica. It is not the first time that the honourable member for Kingston has served his country with distinction in Kingston, Jamaica. I welcome this opportunity to refer to the matter raised by the honourable member because the bauxite and alumina industries are important industries for Australia, representing some $1.5 billion of export income, or some 5 per cent of our gross income. It has been the policy of this Government to encourage mineral resource exports and to achieve pricing levels which maximise the returns for Australia. Unfortunately in some cases this has not been the case, and in this particular case exports to Swiss Aluminium Limited by its Australian subsidiary, Austraswiss and Gove Aluminium Limited, a subsidiary of CSR Limited, have been made at unreasonably low prices for several years. This matter was brought to a head recently when approval was sought to reduce substantially the price of bauxite being exported from the Gove project. I have recently notified both companies that these arrangements are not acceptable and that I will continue to approve exports only if they are made on conditions which reflect fair and reasonable long term market pricing levels.

ANSWER.PARA: The sales contracts under which these contracts take place predate the introduction of export controls on bauxite and alumina. They are based on prices related to the cost of production and certain contracts have pricing arrangements which do not always achieve what is accepted as a fair international price. Since the mid-1970s successive governments have pursued these matters with the company, Austraswiss, in an attempt, through discussions, to have it change the terms and conditions of those contracts so that the prices can be more fair and reasonable in market terms. Whilst some changes were made in 1977 in respect of bauxite, the company has been unwilling to address the question of its more important contracts in relation to the export of alumina. As well, the company, Austraswiss, has been reluctant-in fact, it has refused-to indicate to the Government the prices at which it on-sells its bauxite and alumina and to whom. The House will know that the annual reports of Austraswiss have indicated that that company has paid no company tax since this project began in the 1970s. The Commissioner of Taxation-this is now a matter of public record-has reassessed the company's income for the years 1976 to 1979 and has increased the notional company income by $100m. He has provided assessments to the company involving increases in income taxation of $4.7m in 1978 and $10.6m in 1979.

The company has steadfastly resisted these attempts by the Commonwealth to ensure that a fair price is received. Also it has vigorously resisted attempts by the Commissioner of Taxation to extract taxation from this company. Indeed, its strenuous attempts, using all legal avenues available to it, have involved an expense to both my Department and the Australian Taxation Office in trying to resist requests for information from this company-requests which involve information provided to the Department of Trade on a confidential basis by other exporting companies. This is a shabby story. It involves important issues as far as Australia is concerned. The Commonwealth has an obligation to secure from these projects the maximum benefits for Australia. Whilst in relation to the export of bauxite alumina I have recently released some proposals for the relaxation of export controls, we are not prepared to relax those controls to the point where Australia's national interest can be compromised. I have, as have my several predecessors, given these companies adequate opportunities to put these affairs into order, to try to ensure that a reasonable return is received from the export of these important commodities. I am still prepared to discuss these matters with the companies, but I can assure them that I will be prepared to discuss these matters only on the basis that we can secure a better return for Australia and maintain the very strong reputation that these industries have in the international market-place.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism. I refer to my question to him on 21 November regarding the Australian Institute of Sport. I ask: Has the Minister found the letter from Sargent and Burton Pty Ltd which was sent to him on 27 May and did a member of the Minister's staff tell Mr Dempster of Sargent and Burton that he-the Minister-had called for a report from the Institute in June 1985? If so, what did the report say? If the Minister has not found a copy of the letter, would he like me to give him one?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not in the habit of asking other people for a copy of my correspondence; it usually stays in my office. I said in the House on Thursday that I could not recall whether I had received a letter from Sargent and Burton. I have obtained a copy of that nefarious letter and its sinister implications from my Sydney office. Perhaps if I read the letter to you, Mr Speaker, you will understand why I had forgotten it:

ANSWER.PARA: Mr G. Hartung has been kind enough to reply to me re the Australian Sports Commission on issues that I raised and my reply to Mr Hartung is enclosed and is self-explanatory. I had the opportunity to be in the audience when you officially opened rowing and water polo into the A.I.S. May I compliment you on these initiatives.
It is a wonder that I did not remember that bit. The letter continued:

May I also take this opportunity to request an appointment be made available preferably before the 24 June 1985, to meet with you either in Canberra or your electoral office to discuss a matter which is important to sport in general and the A.I.S. in particular.
That sort of letter would burn deeply into everybody's consciousness! I do remember getting all those sorts of letters! For the information of honourable members I table the letter.

TALK.START.PARA: —And you did not call for a report.

—No, I did not call for a report. I certainly have not asked my staff whether the woman in question has responded to Mr Dempster's phone call in those terms. I am certain that every member in this House would agree that that letter certainly would not imply that that sort of response would be required by my staff or anyone else. The simple fact of that Sargent and Burton complaint, as I mentioned in the House the other day, is this: The firm made an offer to sell some boats to the Institute and it missed; it lost. Someone else won the contract. Somebody loses a contract every day in respect of every government department. The firm subsequently complained about the processes which were undertaken in order to decide who was going to supply the boat. It made some requests under the freedom of information legislation. Documents were supplied. Subsequently, the firm went through the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and complained that all the documents had not been made available. Its request was refused; the AAT ruled against it. It strikes me as being very much of an overkill for the Opposition to keep pursuing these matters. However, despite the innocuous nature of the charges that have been made a full report will be furnished to the House on Thursday. For the information of honourable members I table the letter from Sargent and Burton. I apologise for the fact that my memory was deficient in not remembering that I received it.
—What about the attachments?
—There were no attachments.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Health. I refer to the fact that the Brisbane Women's Health Centre will close down on 13 December, allegedly because of a lack of funding. I ask: Why is the women's health service in Queensland receiving no funding? What is the specific amount of the Federal Government's allocation of funds to Queensland under community health block grants this year? Which States provide funding for the women's health service, and how much do they provide?

—I am aware of difficulties with the funding of the Brisbane Women's Health Centre as referred to by the honourable member for Lilley. However, I have to point out that primary responsibility for community health services does lie with the States. The Commonwealth, of course, has provided additional funds to States for new and expanded community health care services under the Medicare agreement. This year, 1985-86, Queensland will receive $3.109m. The State Government is free to apply that extra money to its community health services. Indeed, I point out that South Australia has allocated $178,000 of its increased funding to a women's community health centre at Noarlunga. This issue of concern about the funding of the Brisbane Women's Health Centre was raised with me by honourable members from Queensland. I consider it sufficiently serious to speak to the Queensland Minister for Health about. He pointed out, quite clearly, that the philosophy of the Queensland Government was that it would not provide special community health services for particular groups whether they be Aborigines, others in need or women; it was the philosophy of the Queensland Government not to provide such special services. I think, therefore, that it is very much a responsibility of the Queenslanders here and those in the State to ensure that, like other States, Queensland does address the health needs of particular groups in the community, particularly women, Aborigines and others.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Housing and Construction. I refer to the housing finance statistics released today which show a 5 per cent fall in the number of housing loans in September which follows a 1 1/2 per cent fall in August. I ask the Minister: Does he still stand by his claim that the Government's high interest rate policy and tax changes, including the capital gains tax and negative gearing changes, are not significantly affecting the housing sector?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first thing I want to assure the House is the the latest figures, that became available today, regarding the number of loans from all significant lenders show that the rate of lending to September is holding up extraordinarily well. There will be no deregulation of savings banks' interest rates, nor do we have any intention of increasing the rate of 13 1/2 per cent. At least this Government is very certain about what it is doing on these matters, but the Opposition finds it very difficult to decide on anything. It does not seem to be able to get its wage policy or its tax policy clear and certainly we do not know what to expect from it as far as regulation is concerned. If one compares the results of our policy of no deregulation and no increase in the ceiling with the policies that we think the Opposition proposes-deregulation, not now, but later-one will see that, under our policies, current savings bank borrowers will face no increase above the 13 1/2 per cent rate and, as I will show in a moment, significant amounts of finance will still be available, at 13 1/2 per cent, albeit within certain conditions.

ANSWER.PARA: Let us look at the situation. Any reduced lending that occurs during 1985-86 will occur off a very high base indeed. I reiterate the figures that I gave the House last week. In 1981-82 the total of housing lending by major lenders was $6.5 billion; in 1984-85 it was almost $13 billion. The figures that came out today indicate-and I say this for the benefit of the honourable member for Deakin-that in September a total of $620m was lent by savings banks which compares with $622m during August. During September the savings banks made available 2.3 per cent fewer actual loans than they did in August. For the year to September 1985, the number of savings banks loans was up 11.5 per cent. So savings bank lending to September was holding up well.

Let us see what the banks are saying about all this. The point I am making is that any reductions that occur are coming off a very high base. Let me quote Mr Will Bailey, the Group General Manager of the Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd. The other day Mr Bailey said that it was true that the volume of housing loans was falling, but he pointed out that the level was still well above that of 1982, before the Hawke Labor Government was elected. He said that in the third quarter of this year loans were winding down a little so that by the end of this year the amount being lent would be closer to $450m. In the first quarter of 1986 this would be further reduced to maybe around $400m, but-and this is the important point-this would be still twice the figure that was being lent in 1982.

I am not saying that, as a result of the high real level of interest rates and the present figures for savings banks deposits, we will not see any reduction in either savings banks deposit growth or the flow of finance to housing. What I am saying is that during 1984-85 and during the first months of 1985-86, lending has been at a very high level indeed and, as I have shown, at least to September there has not been much reduction at all in the total amount of lending by savings banks. Those figures are available today. The fundamental point to make is that any reduction in the volume of lending which occurs over the next few months will be from an extremely high base-indeed, from a record base in the history of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Foreign Affairs whether he can inform the House of developments relating to the hijacking of the Egyptian airliner to Malta.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure honourable members are aware of many of the tragic circumstances surrounding this incident. I am able to announce the following facts at this point: Egyptian Airlines flight 648 was hijacked at 04.30 hours Australian time on Sunday, 24 November, 22 minutes after departure from Athens to Cairo. It landed at Malta's Valetta Airport at 08.16 hours Australian standard time. A number of different nationalities were on board, including two Australians. The crisis centre in the Department of Foreign Affairs had been manned continuously by at least two officers throughout the night to follow developments.

ANSWER.PARA: The entire Maltese Cabinet, led by the Prime Minister, stayed at the airport to deal with the crisis. The crisis obviously was taken very seriously by the Maltese Government. Our small mission there of three Australians handled the crisis very competently. One of the Australian staff, the High Commissioner, Mr Ross Smith, was almost continuously at the airport and then at the hospital throughout the crisis. Mr Smith was briefed by the Maltese Prime Minister after the storming of the aircraft.

The aircraft was stormed by the Egyptian commandos at 06.20 Australian standard time on Monday, 25 November. Tragically, 63 passengers were reportedly killed. One Australian man on board, Mr Anthony Roystan Lyons, is safe. He currently resides at Cambridge in the United Kingdom. A young Australian woman-at this stage I prefer not to divulge her name as one of the parents has not been advised of the likely outcome-is believed to have been killed during the storming of the plane when the hijackers let off fire bombs and possibly other explosive devices. Research into past terrorist incidents revealed no other Australian fatalities other than the death of two Australian children in the Frankfurt Airport bombing of 19 June this year.

Mr Speaker, I would like to go on and mention some other facts. The United States Administration has issued a statement regarding the tragic loss of life, supporting the difficult decisions of the Egyptian and Maltese governments to end the brutal hijacking and stating that those who support despicable acts must know that justice will be done. The United States Government states that it was not asked for direct assistance and there was no direct United States involvement.

There has been some comment about security at the Athens Airport. Perhaps I should mention this: Following the hijacking of a Trans-World Airlines Pty Ltd airliner from Athens Airport in June, Qantas Airways Ltd conducted a security inspection of Athens Airport and advised our mission in Athens on 18 July that Qantas considered that important improvements had been made to security at Athens Airport which it believed was then probably safe to fly from.

The American State Department announced on 22 July that its travel advisory to American citizens issued on 18 June regarding security at Athens Airport had been cancelled. The American statement said that an official American team had found that Athens International Airport met international airport security requirements.

Mr Speaker, with your further indulgence I will mention something about the hijackers about whom very little is known personally. The three, possibly four, armed men said to be holding Moroccan and Tunisian passports who hijacked Egypt Airlines flight 648 claimed to be members of the Egyptian Revolution. As far as we are aware, they gave no reasons for their action and made no demands-such as the release of prisoners-other than to have the plane refuelled and later a request for food, which the Maltese Government refused.

The only previous occasion we have heard of the Egyptian Revolution was following the shooting of an Israeli diplomat in Cairo on 21 August 1985. A group claiming to be the Egyptian Revolution claimed responsibility for that incident and said it had made an unsuccessful attempt on the life of an Israeli diplomat in 1984. The group issued a statement opposing the Camp David agreement.

Subsequent to that incident Abu Nidal during an interview confirmed the existence of the Organisation of Egypt's Revolutionaries which was hostile to the Camp David accord. Abu Nidal indicated he supplied the group with weapons. Press reports refer to comment that the hijackers, who spoke Arabic, did not speak with Egyptian accents.

The Palestine Liberation Organisation and Libya have both apparently disclaimed any involvement in or responsibility for the incident. We have seen reports that both Tunisia and Libya refused to give permission for the aircraft to land. Reports indicate that Europeans were apparently separated from the Egyptian passengers. However, those who were killed when the final assault took place appear to have been of all nationalities.

I need scarcely say that the Government of Australia, indeed this Parliament, condemns categorically the behaviour of terrorists, in particular the behaviour of these terrorists on this very sad occasion. Their behaviour is that of criminal desperadoes and in no way deserves any understanding or sympathy because there can be no room for sympathy or understanding when innocent civilians are slaughtered in this way.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Treasurer to the report in today's Australian Financial Review which refers to a confidential Treasury document, critical of the BIS-Shrapnel study challenging the Government's estimate of $310m in revenue savings from the prohibition of deductions for entertainment expenses. Will the Treasurer make details of the leaked document available to the House and, perhaps more importantly, when will he make available for public scrutiny details of exactly how the Treasury arrived at its estimate of $310m?

—Of course I will not. The former Treasurer never did. No one has ever expected governments to do so and I will not start the practice now. The Treasury's view is that the whole basis of the calculation is basically ill-founded. The notion that one is taking that sort of money out of circulation in the economy which is, apparently, one of the basic premises of the analysis, is of course a false premise. All of the proceeds of these--
—Well, let us see both documents then.

—Of course the honourable member would like to see them but he is not going to see them. I have told him that I will not give them to him. Apparently the basis of the analysis is that the savings of revenue of the change in regard to entertainment expenses will be lost to the economy. That is not so. The Government is returning all of these funds to the economy. Therefore, the Treasury is very much confirmed in the view that its estimate on this measure is right.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. What benefits will become available to those who served during the Vietnam war on HMAS Sydney, her escorts, the Boonaroo and the Jeparit as a result of legislation which was recently passed by this House?

—The Government has decided to extend repatriation benefits under the Veterans' Entitlements Bill to certain defence personnel who were not previously treated as having been allotted for special duty in a special area. My colleague the Minister for Defence has announced that he will deem, for the purposes of the Veterans' Entitlements Bill, these defence personnel, including those who served on HMAS Sydney, her escorts, the Boonaroo and the Jeparit during the Vietnam war, to have been allotted for such prescribed special duty. This will have the effect of conferring eligibility from 5 December 1985 for the following benefits subject to the usual legislative and policy conditions: The disability pension for service related incapacity or death, a service pension, repatriation treatment entitlements, and defence service home loans, but with no retrospective adjustment of mortgages. The eligibility of these personnel for tax exemption for time spent in the war zone and for a grant of a returned from active service badge are matters which fall within the portfolios of my colleagues the Treasurer and the Minister for Defence respectively. I shall bring that aspect of the honourable gentleman's question to their attention and ask them to let him have a reply.

—I refer the Prime Minister to the fact that the Treasurer has still not produced a clarifying statement on detailed aspects of the capital gains tax that he has promised repeatedly over many weeks. In view of this, will the Prime Minister postpone the commencement date of the capital gains tax from 19 September to such time as the Government is able to tell the public of its obligations and liabilities under the proposed tax?
—No.

—Is the Minister for Health aware of proposals to introduce into the United States Senate a Bill designed to repeal section 801 of the 1938 United States Food, Drug and Cosmetics Act which prohibits the export of drugs which have not been approved for use in the United States? Is the Minister aware that the dumping of unapproved drugs takes a devastating toll on the health and safety of consumers in the Third World and that the proposed Bill will aggravate this already dismal situation? In light of the recent experience with the import of heart valves from the United States to this country, has the Government formed a view towards this proposed Bill and, if so, what is the Government's attitude?

—In responding to the question from the honourable member for Makin, I would first point out that the Government would not presume to advise the legislatures of other countries on measures before them. However, I am aware that a member of the United States Congress has introduced a Bill in relation to the export of pharmaceutical goods from the United States. I am not aware of the attitude of the American Government to that measure. What I can say is that the Australian Government has been active within the World Health Organisation in striving for standards of conduct in relation to the manufacture, sale and export of pharmaceutical goods for very much the same reasons that were noted in the question by the honourable member for Makin. We, as a government, would be very concerned indeed if any measure led to an increased export of non- approved drugs, particularly to developing countries.

—I refer the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment to his recent speech in which he mentioned the possibility of the Australian Government building an incinerator ship to dispose of dangerous toxic wastes produced in Australia and South East Asian countries. Can the Minister inform the House when this ship will be constructed? What are the Government's policies on the destruction of dangerous toxic wastes?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cohen The Hon B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question because this is a very serious matter. Last week in Melbourne I opened a national conference on the disposal of hazardous wastes. It was very widely attended by over 300 people. I have said that in the past the only means of disposing of very poisonous liquid hazardous waste was to take it out to sea and burn it. The SS Volcanus came here a couple of years ago and that was how some of the waste was disposed of. At the moment probably about 85 per cent of the more dangerous waste is located at the ICI Australia Ltd plant in Botany, Sydney. As a community we can no longer continue to ignore the very serious ramifications of stockpiling it.

ANSWER.PARA: There is no alternative which is without risk. If one takes hazardous waste to sea one cannot get rid of the solid waste. If one transports it to some other part of Australia-Broken Hill in the honourable member's electorate has been mentioned and the electorate of the honourable member for Kalgoorlie has been mentioned as a possible alternative-the problem is transportation. Certainly the waste can be got rid of in an area which is not nearly as dangerous to the bulk of the community. If one disposes of it where it is located obviously there will be an outcry from the local community where many hundreds of thousands of people-in fact millions-live. The risk is very minimal; nevertheless the fears are genuine. A whole range of alternatives have to be looked at but doing nothing is not an alternative. Everybody-academia, governments, conservationists and local communities-must participate in finding a solution to an intractable problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment been drawn to recent Press comments concerning the Australia Council and some confusion that appears to have arisen in the arts community? Will the Minister inform the House of the continued statutory independence of the Australia Council, the principle of arm's length funding, and the process of peer group assessment and decision-making?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cohen The Hon B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Throsby for his question. As we all know, he is one of the most cultured men ever to come into this House. In fact, it is said of the honourable member for Throsby that he has done for art what Colonel Sanders did for the chicken.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australia Council Act sets out the relationship between the Council and the Government. It is a principle that this Government will maintain. Last Thursday-I think it was-the Prime Minister and I met a group called the Arts Alliance, which represents a range of people, to confirm to that group, as I did a few weeks before to the Australia Council, the principle of arm's length funding. The Government has emphasised on many occasions that decisions on individual grants are matters for the Council and its art boards. However, it is important for the Government to indicate its expectations in matters of broad direction, especially where large sums are concerned.

The problem really comes down to what one does about the major flagship companies. This is a problem which has bedevilled previous governments, including the Fraser Government. We do not believe that decisions made by the Council which could mean the demise of one of the major companies could be taken without guidance from the Government. I believe that I have explained this to the Australia Council and to the Arts Alliance. I think that they understand our problem. I believe that, between all of us, we can finally find a solution to this problem, which, as I say, has bedevilled governments for many years.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: BEALE; CAMERON; HALVERSON; HAWKER; MCARTHUR; MCGAURAN
PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the Nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will:
Propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian National Flag be changed only with the approval of the Nation as expressed in a Referendum''.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beale,Mr Ewen Cameron,Mr Halverson,Mr Hawker,Mr McArthur and Mr McGauran.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
1. that the overwhelming majority of Australians are completely satisfied with the existing Australian National Flag.

2. That we are totally opposed to any change in the Australian National Flag as provided in Section (3) of the Flags Act, unless such proposed change is first voted on by the people of Australia and passed by a majority of voters in a majority of States.
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Australian flag symbolises the continuity between Australia's past, its present and the future;

That the presence of the Union Jack on the flag represents not a subservience to Britain, but a reminder of our inheritance of the hundreds of years of struggle for individual liberty against the forces of tyranny and oppression;
Nonetheless recognises the rights of Australians should they wish as a people to change the design of their flag.
Your petitioners humbly pray that no change be made to the Australian flag except with the consent of the people in a referendum.
And your petitioner as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled:
The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully sheweth:

That whereas the Commonwealth of Australia ratified the UN Covention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women in 1983, the Government of Victoria in passing the Planning (Brothels) Act 1984 is in breach of Article 6 of the Convention which says that ``States Parties shall take all appropriate measures, including legislation, to suppress all forms of traffic in women and exploitation of prostitution of women''.
That the Victorian Planning (Brothels) Act 1984 provides legal authority to brothel operators to traffic in and exploit the prostitution of women and to live off the earnings of prostitutes.

That whereas the Federal Minister for Health has counselled citizens to shun promiscuity (The Australian 26.1.85) because of the serious and sometimes fatal health hazards, the operations of legalised brothels encourages promiscuity and the spread of diseases, including AIDS.
Your petitioners therefore pray:

That the Government of Australia having ratified the UN Covention on Women remain consistent in its obligations to uphold the Articles of the Convention and request the Victorian Government to immediately repeal the Planning (Brothels) Act 1984.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Ewen Cameron,Mr Halverson and Mr McArthur.

PETITION.TITLE: Fuel Prices
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
1. That we are completely dissatisfied with the frequent and substantial increase in the price of petrol and diesel fuel.
2. That we are aware that these price increases have an adverse affect on the living standards of the average Australian wage earner.
3. That increases in fuel prices adds to farm costs and further reduces the average income per farmer which has already fallen to one-third of national earnings.

Your Petitioners therefore pray that the Government will immediately reduce the price of petrol by three (3) cents per litre in line with the commitment given by the now Prime Minister of Australia during the 1983 election campaign and take all possible action to prevent further increases occurring.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Andrew and Mr Fife.

PETITION.TITLE: Fuel Prices
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
1. That we are completely dissatisfied with the pricing of petrol in this country;
2. That under a Labor Government petrol prices have continued to rise excessively, with recent Government decisions adding over 8c. per litre to the price of petrol in some country areas;
3. The proposed consumption tax could lead to a further rise of 6c. per litre; and
4. The high cost of petrol discriminates against country residents who rely on their cars for essential communication and transport.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Government honour the commitment given by the Prime Minister during the 1983 election campaign to reduce petrol prices by 3c. per litre.
Further we strongly urge the Government to adopt a petrol pricing policy which does not cause unnecessary rises in the cost of petrol.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Identity Cards
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker, and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.
This petition of Australian residents shows that we strongly oppose the introduction of the ``Australia Card'' or any form of compulsory identity cards.

We believe that the introduction of Identity cards will erode civil liberties; will create an increased risk of invasion of privacy; and will not result in any significant increase in Government revenue.
We call on the Parliament to immediately reject any proposals for the introduction of compulsory Identity cards.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Duncan and Mr Staples.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Free Zones
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of citizens of Australia shows:

That the people of New Zealand and the New Zealand Government have given an example to the world in their efforts to achieve a nuclear free South Pacific, and such decision being endorsed by the people at a general election.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government support the principled stand taken by the New Zealand Government and urges it to condemn any efforts by the U.S. Government to impose economic or other sanctions on New Zealand in retaliation for their stand on nuclear vessels.
We further urge the Australian Government to urgently implement its policy to promote the development of zones of peace and nuclear free zones in the Indian and Pacific Oceans.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Kent and Mr Staples.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that they are opposed to the proposals contained in the Government's White Paper for the reform of the Australian Tax System in so far as they relate to the imposition of further capital gains and wealth taxes.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Small Businesses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
Introduction of any additional capital gains taxes, wealth taxes or death duties is opposed on the grounds that:
they adversely affect the small and medium size businesses in Australia, including farms, destroying incentive and discouraging investment in this important area of the economy;
the Australian economy, and employment in particular, is heavily reliant on growth in small businesses;

any capital gains that might result when owners of small enterprises finally sell these assets are not `windfall gains', but the result of many hard years of work and sacrifice, with very little being taken out of the business or farm by way of salaries so that the maximum amount of money can be ploughed back into the business or farm to create growth and jobs;
the owners of small businesses and farms often depend on a capital gain-which are simply deferred salaries-when they eventually sell these assets to sustain them in retirement;
Your Petitioners request that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, will protect the rights of private enterprise and reject any inequitable additional taxes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Enterprise Migrant Hostel

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth do humbly pray that the Commonwealth government:

1. Uphold the principle that the seeds and cuttings of plants are a public resource and a common heritage to all and that accordingly seeds should be freely available to all, freely multipliable, able to be sold, exchanged, exported and imported by anyone who wishes. This is seen as a matter of national food security.

2. Recognise that plant breeding is a highly co-operative venture often involving private enterprise at the very last stages after basic seed collection, storage, and research has been publicly funded.
3. In view of the aforementioned paragraphs, recognise that any system giving `property' or ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises is inappropriate and unjust.
4. Recognise that legislation establishing plant patenting schemes overseas has had serious adverse effects namely:
(i) a slowing-down of scientific information exchange and exchanges in basic plant breeding materials, that is, germ plasm,
(ii) subordination and/or curtailment of public breeding programmes,
(iii) farmer unrest at seed prices,
(iv) monopoly control of seed production and sales has passed into the hands of giant petrochemical and drug corporations also marketing crop chemicals,
(v) increased uniformity of crop varieties leading to a vulnerability to pest and disease attack.
5. Reject any proposal to legislate for any system such as the drafted Plant Variety Rights Act, which gives exclusive ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The serious implications for economic control and power in our community posed by the ACTU-Government deal on superannuation.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The issue of superannuation is, day by day, assuming more importance in the economic and political debate in Australia, and well it may because the current campaign for superannuation benefits which flows out of the renegotiated prices and incomes accord owes more to a Chicago-style extortion racket than it does to a proper and logical extention of superannuation. The activities, particularly of the Storemen and Packers Union, that have led to the stand-down of thousands of fellow workers at the Ford plant amount to nothing other than attempted expropriation by that union. All these events and developments can be sheeted home to the actions of the Government and the nature of the arrangement that it made with the Australian Council of Trade Unions only two and a half months ago when it renegotiated the prices and incomes accord.

SPEECH.PARA: It is very appropriate that the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) is in the House to reply to this matter of public importance because he was the real pacesetter on this matter. He was the man who gave everybody the bright idea that instead of agreeing to a pay rise that was outside the wage indexation guidelines, all the Government had to do was patch up a phoney pay rise, call it a superannuation benefit, fix it to an amount of $11 a week and then it would solve an industrial problem. In 1983 an arrangement was made in respect of the building industry whereby the Government, in order to forestall a break-out from the wage indexation guidelines that were then only a few months old, went behind the back of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and, with the blessing of the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, reached a deal that ran roughly like this: `Give them a superannuation arrangement, mark it down at $11 and dump it all on the employer. We have not breached the guidelines, you have what you wanted, the employer is footing the bill and we can run around the country saying that the wage indexation guidelines are still intact'. That was a phoney, dishonest deal contrived at the time by the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations.

Of course, that action is now coming back to haunt the Government. More importantly, it is coming back to haunt the poor unfortunate employers of Australia. The employers were not given a seat at the renegotiation of the accord. They were not asked two and a half months ago whether they believed in paying 3 per cent more in respect of superannuation. They were not asked whether they approved the handing over of $3 billion a year to union controlled superannuation funds. They played no part in that at all. That is apparently what this Government means when it talks about industrial democracy. It is some kind of democracy that says to one segment of the Australian community: `You can pay for all of it but we will not ask you to participate in the arrangement'. That is exactly what happened because when it sat down two and a half months ago and renegotiated the accord, Bill Kelty was astonished and said that to his great amazement the unions had got the superannuation gains that he thought would take 20 years to achieve. No wonder he was astonished. Would not honourable members be astonished if they got 20 years worth of superannuation benefits and did not have to pay a penny for it? That is exactly what is going to come out of this deal.

Significantly, at Question Time, when I asked the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) whether the guidelines were to include any requirement on employees to make a contribution, the Prime Minister rabbited on about the Treasurer (Mr Keating) getting a statement together. The reality is that when those guidelines come out they will not contain any requirement on employees to make a contribution. This is not a bona fide superannuation deal; it is a disguised pay rise and nothing more. The unions will use all the industrial blackmail and muscle that they can muster, and engage in all the contortions and explanations that they can possibly lay their hands on in order to dress it up as some kind of bona fide superannuation arrangement. But it is not a bona fide superannuation arrangement, and I will give the House four reasons why it is not.

Firstly, the real goal of this exercise is a massive transfer of economic power in this community to the trade union movement. That is what it ultimately is about. It is not enough for the unions to be given Budget secrets ahead of everybody else, to be able to predict what will be in the Government's tax package-I will come back to that in a moment-to have a heat at the right hand of the Prime Minister and to be above the law, as they have demonstrably been able to be, while the Prime Minister and the Government have sat around and done nothing about it; on top of that the trade union movement wants to put its hands on an enormous amount of additional economic power in this community. This is what this superannuation imbroglio is all about. If the community-the business community in particular-and this Parliament stand by and allow it to happen, under the guise of bringing superannuation justice to Australia, we will watch one of the most significant and lasting transfers of economic power in this community that we have witnessed taking place.

It is the role of this Parliament, and particularly of the Opposition, to point out to the Australian public the things that are really at stake over this whole superannuation issue. We are not talking about basic superannuation justice. Nobody argues that companies able to make proper provision for superannuation should not join with their employees in doing so. But that is what is under attack here. Under the arrangement that has been devised by the ACTU and the Government, even those companies that have already made superannuation provision for their employees are being dragged in against their will. The honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) nods his head. Apparently the Australian Labor Party thinks that is okay. Companies, irrespective of whether they have done the right thing by their employees, are to be bullied and bludgeoned into joining a union controlled superannuation fund.

What kind of justice is it to say to a company: `Thank you very much for making generous provision for your employees and for doing the right thing. We appreciate that very much, but it is not good enough. We want 3 per cent on top of that, we want you to put all of your employees into the union controlled superannuation fund and, to boot, if you do not do that we will close you down for a while; we will make you stand down thousands of your workers until you come to your senses'? That is exactly what is happening with this superannuation deal at the moment. It is not an attempt to get legitimate justice for the employees of Australia; it is an attempt to extort, stand over and bully even those employers who over the years have done the right thing. I have already had, as no doubt many honourable members on this side of the House have had, letters from employers complaining that, having done the right thing, having provided superannuation for their employees, they now find, much to their distress, that they are being forced, at the sharp end of industrial blackmail, to provide another 3 per cent. It certainly is not a bona fide attempt to provide justice.

There is no mention yet of any contribution from an employee. Whoever thought of a bona fide superannuation scheme that did not require any kind of contribution from an employee? What employee, faced with the option of staying in a scheme where he had to make a contribution or joining a scheme where he did not have to make a contribution, would opt for the former? Of course, no employee would. What kind of superannuation arrangement is that? Why does the Government not be honest and say that the superannuation arrangement is an enormous bust-out of its own beloved wage indexation guidelines? It makes a total mockery of the wage indexation guidelines and it is nothing more than a further pay rise, a further impost on top of the wage bills that the employers of Australia are already carrying. To boot, this time the benefit will not be paid to the individual employee as a normal pay rise would be paid, although it will cost the employers just as much; it is going to be picked up, holus bolus-a sum calculated by many to be about $3,000m a year-and dumped into the lap of the union dominated superannuation funds, representing a most enormous transfer of economic power in one stroke.

No wonder Bill Kelty could not believe what was happening at the ACTU Congress. No wonder some of our industrial relations writers, those supporters and admirers of the way in which our industrial relations system works, said that there was an air of expectation at the ACTU Congress, a feeling that they had achieved something beyond their wildest dreams. They found that a government, already believed by them to be compliant and always ready to accommodate, had been remarkably accommodating and remarkedly supportive. They had got in one stroke what they honestly believed it would take many years to achieve.

Of course, it all seems okay now. It is all dressed up as superannuation, but in a year's time, when the employment and profitability consequences of this superannuation deal start to sink in the Australian community, when the Australian community starts to realise what an enormous power transfer has taken place, when superannuation funds controlling billions of dollars under trade union control and domination start to flex their muscles, the community will have a much better idea of precisely the extent of the sell-out of its interests in which the Minister and the Treasurer participated when they negotiated this superannuation deal.

This superannuation deal will do more damage to the small business community of Australia than many other actions that this Government has taken. There is no requirement in what the Government has agreed to as to whether a firm can pay the superannuation; no questions are asked as to whether the firm has done the right thing; and the Government has made no attempt, in advance of the bargaining, bullying and badgering that are now taking place, to lay down any guidelines. The Prime Minister says: `The Treasurer will make a statement before too long'. I say to the Prime Minister and the Treasurer that their statement is too late. Right now businesses are being closed down, people are being put out of work, the unions are flexing their muscles and all over the place it is very clear that this superannuation deal will become a very major battleground between the trade union movement and the business community.

The reason why that has happened and the blame for that can be sheeted home directly to the relationship that exists between this Government and the ACTU. They have pretended, they have fibbed and they have misled the Australian public about the nature of this superannuation deal. It is yet another demonstration of the degree of influence, control and power that the ACTU exercises over this Government that, in one stroke, it could get a deal which, in effect, busted the wage indexation guidelines, gave workers the equivalent of a 3 per cent salary rise without having to prove a productivity claim; and gave the unions the potential to exercise enormous economic power over sums of up to $3 billion a year; and inflicted upon the small business community of Australia in particular an impost from which many members of that community will not recover.

No wonder people bubbled over with excitement and there was an air of expectation at the ACTU Congress in Sydney 2 1/2 months ago. The unfortunate thing is that everybody in Australia except the trade union movement will have to pay the cost of that bubbling expectation, will have to foot the bill. What else can we expect from a government whose Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) yesterday said that the sugar industry of Australia, which is absolutely flat on its back, has to pay the full 3.8 per cent wage increase? What else can we expect from a government that has such an idiotic economic attitude as that? But we should not really be surprised. If we think this year, economically or indeed in any other way, has carried any surprises it was all foretold, certainly on the economic front, by none other than Mr Kelty himself when he addressed the Socialist Forum on 4 February 1985. This is what he said, and it is remarkable prescience:
The ACTU has predicted a bumper year for wage and salary earners, including two national wage rises, additional money for low income earners, no tax increases and superannuation for every worker.
That was on 4 February 1985. The report went on:

He also foreshadowed a push by the ACTU for a government crackdown on perks-such as company cars, expense accounts and education fees . . . and an expansion of the taxation `pot' into currently non- taxable areas.

The Government might as well have had no Summit and it might as well have not had a parliament this year because right there, on 4 February, at the beginning of this year, Bill Kelty predicted it all. He told the Government and he told us exactly what was going to happen and that demonstrates the extent of domination over this Government.
