TALKER.NAME: Mr WILLIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations)

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard a quarter of an hour of claptrap from the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), who found it very hard to fill in the time and had to repeat most of his theme over and over again. The Government has no qualms in saying that it strongly supports the extension of superannuation to that part of the work force which does not have superannuation at present and it believes that to do so would be to correct a substantial social inequity. We have no qualms about supporting that development. It is our view that that extension of social equity to the rest of the work force-that half that does not have superannuation at present-should occur in a way that is economically responsible. That economic responsibility aspect is built into the approach which we have taken in the extension of superannuation.

SPEECH.PARA: All honourable members would be aware of the basis upon which that extension of superannuation is to take place but let me remind the House, for the benefit of those honourable members who might have forgotten, that it will take place over the course of at least a couple of years. The wage fixation guidelines provided for a productivity case this financial year. That case has been postponed and there will be no outcome from that case, under the agreement between the Government and Australian Council of Trade Unions, until the end of this financial year. Therefore, we will have no impact from a productivity case in respect of superannuation this financial year.

Over the course of three financial years-all years of strong economic growth-we have had no real increase in wages and nothing happening apart from indexation increases. That is a factor of some significance and real importance to this matter. If honourable members take the view that any increase in labour costs is wrong they are living in an unreal world-a world which obviously the Opposition, when in government, could not maintain. It is a fact that, as prosperity is developed over time, there will be an extension of that prosperity to the work force and it is right and proper that that happen. The point is, though, that it must happen in a way which does not add to inflation and does not undermine that economic prosperity.

We have had two years of very strong economic growth-growth of around 5 per cent. In conjunction with that there has been growth in employment of about 5 per cent and growth in productivity of about 5 per cent over the course of the last two years. In the current financial year we are again witnessing strong growth of the economy, strong growth of employment and strong growth of productivity. We cannot just simply have that strong growth in productivity continuing to pile up in profits. Profit share has increased considerably over the course of the last couple of years. That was right and proper because profit share was low and was certainly a great inhibition to the improvement of investments. With that increase in profit share we have seen investment beginning to turn around. We are now looking at real growth in investments and we expect that that will continue.

It is an absurd situation to take the view, as the Leader of the Opposition has in this debate and as speakers on the other side of the House perpetually do, that any increase in labour costs is somehow wrong and incorrect and should never occur. It is an absurdity. It means that they are saying that wage earners should never share in economic prosperity and should never get a share of productivity. That is a nonsense. It must occur and will occur. If it does not occur in any orderly way it will occur in a disorderly way through massive industrial disputation. What we have done is to ensure that we avoid that substantial industrial disputation by adopting an approach which brings superannuation about through a decision of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission.

What we have seen in the history of this country has been the gradual spread of superannuation in a way which has been utterly uncontrolled. There has been no accounting of that in wages policy and in general economic policy; it has simply been occurring outside the general parameters of government policy. There certainly have been taxation arrangements in respect of it but there has been no way of controlling what happened from year to year. So we have had the development of superannuation as though it had no economic implications.

What the Government is doing, with the concurrence of the ACTU, is bringing superannuation out of that uncontrolled area into wages policy so that it has its extension built into wages policy. The Government has done so with the approval, we hope, of the Arbitration Commission-that will certainly be the application which we and the ACTU will make under the agreement-so that the Arbitration Commission will be in control, for the first time ever in the history of this country, of a very substantial element of labour on-costs. We keep hearing from honourable members on the other side of the House this terrible thing about labour on-costs. They did nothing whatever, when in government, to control labour on-costs. When we bring about a process which controls them and ensure that that increase in superannuation occurs only in a way which is in line with economic capacity, honourable members opposite say that this is a terrible thing, that this is handing over control to the unions, that this is a disaster and that it is not real superannuation and so on. It is all absolute nonsense. It will be real superannuation and it will be done in a way which is thoroughly economically responsible.

Another benefit to the economy will come from this in the form of increased savings. There will be a considerable increase to savings as a result of that superannuation extension and that savings increase will enhance our capacity to increase investment and so provide a stimulus to the economy in that area where it needs it most. We believe that this is an important quantum leap in the level of savings that will occur through the development of superannuation and, through that process, a quantum leap in investment, which is certainly essential if we are to redevelop the Australian economy in the way which the Australian Government is seeking very much to achieve. The substantial advantages are the extension of superannuation, bringing it under control and also adding to the level of savings and so promoting investment.

As I have said, that is all happening in a way which is thoroughly responsible. We totally reject the ludicrous sorts of allegations that have been coming from honourable members on the other side of the House about how this is handing over control to the unions. The fact is that we will be establishing criteria in respect of superannuation which were never established by the previous Government. Honourable members will recall that when the previous Government was in office superannuation was one of the great tax rorts. It was one of the great areas where one could use the tax laws to rip off taxation and make substantial gains that way. It was only when there was a great outcry over tax avoidance that the previous Government moved to do anything about it.

We say to those honourable members opposite who have said to us that we are allowing superannuation to develop in a way which is not real that they are the ones who allowed taxation rorts in respect of superannuation. They did nothing to control the extension of superannuation and they did nothing to account for it. We will do all that and we will provide criteria which will ensure the development of superannuation which is real superannuation, which is not just deferred pay and which provides real benefits to employees in their retirement. The real benefit is that it will greatly increase the retirement living standards of wage and salary earners in this country.

We want to avoid people going from a reasonable wage at work to a much lower income in retirement, as half the work force now does. With the superannuation arrangements we are developing, people will be able to have a real increase in their retirement benefits. But they will get that only if proper criteria are established. Criteria have to be established in respect of the preservation of the benefit and in respect of vesting in the employee, and various other controls will be built into those criteria to ensure that superannuation cannot be rorted any more, that it will not be just deferred pay but an improvement in the retirement incomes of wage and salary earners. In that way we will get to the situation in which, with an aging work force, people will be much better able to look after themselves in their retirement than is now the case. Also we will have the long term benefit that as they are so able to do that there will be less demand on the taxpayer to fund them in their retirement. All of those are substantial benefits.

We reject totally the argument that this is some phoney pay deal, that this is not real superannuation. It is a totally false allegation which the Leader of the Opposition can in no way justify. We can only make an allegation which is totally unjustified, and when he sees the criteria which will be brought out shortly he will see that every attempt has been made, in a way which was never made by him in his many years as Treasurer, to ensure that superannuation is real and that it does bring substantial retirement benefits. He said that a great fault in what we were proposing is that there is to be no contribution from employees. Of course he does not know what is in the criteria yet so that is a somewhat early allegation. When the Leader of the Opposition was Treasurer he allowed tax deductions to be taken in respect of superannuation schemes involving no employee contributions. It has not been a requirement in this country that there be an employee contribution, and it was because of that fact that some of the tax rorts occurred under the previous Government. It is a nonsense for him to argue now that we would be at fault if we do not require an employee contribution when in his five years as Treasurer he never required that to be the case. It is absurd of him to make that allegation. It is highly desirable that there be employee contributions and we will do what we can to encourage that.

It has been said by the Leader of the Opposition, who is burbling away here like some sort of half-witted idiot, that there is some fault in the Government because there will be some union control of superannuation funds. He seems to think that it is an outrage for superannuation no longer to be controlled by an employer. Of course it depends on how these things develop. He said that if that were to be the case it would be an outrage; it should be regarded as a travesty of justice if unions have some say in the control of superannuation funds. We totally reject that absurd notion. We believe that unionists and employees have a right to some say in what happens to their superannuation contributions or funds which are contributed in their names. They have a right to that because their end benefits are at stake. We believe that employees and employers should have a right jointly to say what happens concerning the investment of funds. It is a nonsense to say that employees should not have any such say. If that is what is being said by the Leader of the Opposition-I take it that it is-we regard it as being an absolute nonsense. If members of the Opposition want to say that employees have no right to any say in the investment of their funds, that is their privilege. I would have thought that it was a fairly outrageous position to be taking.

I totally reject the allegation that we have pretended and fibbed on the superannuation deal, which is the way it was put by the Leader of the Opposition. There has been no pretence and no fibbing. We have made it clear from the outset that we support superannuation. In the agreement we reached with the Australian Council of Trade Unions which renegotiated the accord and made the adjustment to wages policy, it was stated clearly that we supported superannuation but only on certain conditions, including the fact that these arrangements will not operate until 1 July 1986 except in special and isolated circumstances. That is the way it will be. There will be no extension of superannuation on anything but the most minute scale between now and 1 July. When it does occur it will be spread over a couple of years. I emphasise that. It will not all happen on 1 July. The implementation of these arrangements will occur over a two-year period; some workers will be getting this benefit only by the middle of 1988. So the implementation of that benefit will be very prolonged. To describe that as economically irresponsible is incredible, particularly when that description comes from people who never controlled in any way the development of superannuation in this country. They never took it into wages policy, but regarded it as something that ran along totally outside economic and wages policy.

We are proud of the fact that we are extending superannuation and we believe that it will bring great social benefits. The fact that it will be caught up in wages policy will also bring great economic benefits to Australia. It is part of a deal which will be to the benefit of the whole of the country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The prices and incomes accord mark 2 and the superannuation deal that goes with it is a shabby back room deal done by the Government and the Australian Council of Trade Unions which casts aside the whole principle of consensus which was once so advocated by the Government. It casts aside the Government's concern that it once said it had for the business community and the capacity of the business community to create wealth in the economy. It has replaced those things with a kind of latter day Vichy government that we have on the other side of the House-a Vichy government which in effect is under the thumb of the occupation forces; in this case the ACTU. We have just heard a most interesting speech from the Marshal Petain of that Vichy government when it comes to the issue of relations with the trade union movement. Quite simply, as most members of the community are increasingly coming to realise, this whole superannuation deal is one of the most underrated threats to the future stability of Australia's economy, and indeed to the capitalist system so hated by the people in that corner of the House, and it is something that the community increasingly will become concerned about and will increasingly debate-I believe at the long term expense of the Government itself. This is a dramatic leap towards the objective of socialism by a government which is already being dictated to by the ACTU which is clearly predominant in this country at the moment.

SPEECH.PARA: Two basic questions need to be addressed in regard to the whole of this superannuation package: First, is this productivity deal justified in the first place; and, secondly-this is the very fundamental question covered by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard)-is this superannuation deal in any case the right way to go? On the productivity deal, the Confederation of Australian Industry in a very considered report has argued that there is no case for a productivity deal at all at this time because since March 1983, when productivity per hour worked equalled $12, productivity has actually declined to $11.95. That is a decline of 0.4 per cent in labour productivity in this country. In other words business in those two years has had imposed on it additional costs. What this superannuation deal does-if you like, this productivity deal-is impose yet another cost on the business community.

But even if one does argue, as the Government and the ACTU clearly do, that there have been productivity gains, is not the fundamental question how these gains should be taken; how they should be distributed through the community? Should they be taken through a de facto wage increase, which of course is what this superannuation deal is, or should they be passed on to consumers through lower prices and indeed to business so that it can compete more effectively in the international market-place? No one here needs to be reminded of how desperately important it is that business be able to compete more effectively in the international market-place. Equally I think it is reasonable to argue that any increases in productivity should also ultimately be passed on to the community in the form of higher investment in our corporate sector, greater efficiency in our corporate sector and, again, greater productivity in that sector which will allow it to continue to compete and, indeed, continue to create jobs. Instead, what the Government has done is to agree to the ACTU's demands to pass on this productivity increase, insofar as it exists at all, just in the form of a wage increase.

The second fundamental point is whether this productivity gain should be taken in the form of the quite extraordinary so-called superannuation deal. The Opposition has made it clear time and again that we support the extension of the concept of occupational superannuation. We want that to be extended as far across the working community as is possible. Indeed, our record shows how much we have achieved in that area already. During the period of the Fraser Government superannuation coverage rose from 29 per cent to just under 50 per cent. There was an enormous leap forward during the period of the Fraser Government. We understand that that coverage has to be extended still further because the burden of the state pension on the Budget is one that is growing progressively year by year. Indeed, with an aging population in Australia it is all the more urgent, for budgetary reasons alone, that we try to replace the age pension with occupational superannuation schemes.

What the ACTU-Government deal has done is to provide a scheme which ultimately will put those superannuation funds into the hands of the unions. This will create maximum confusion in the community as the new scheme is introduced. Already in Australia there are some 180,000 different superannuation schemes. Nobody knows yet what effect this deal will have on those 180,000 schemes. How will the superannuation deal affect the existing contributors to those 180,000 schemes? Will they be taken out of those schemes and put into trade union dominated and controlled superannuation schemes? We do not know. Also we do not know how the new contributors themselves will relate to those schemes or, indeed, what direction those schemes will be forced to go in by the ACTU.

We have however some indication of what will happen. We have an indication from the ACTU and the trade union movement in general in the form of the already existing so-called industry schemes which, as the House knows, are in effect schemes run by the trade union movement itself. Already we have the Australian Building Construction Employees and Builders Labourers Federation superannuation scheme. We have the Transport Workers Union of Australia superannuation scheme, which we can read about every day now in the newspapers. The Transport Workers Union is arguing that that scheme should be introduced prematurely, apparently contrary to the words of the agreement reached some two and a half months ago. We also have the Federated Storemen and Packers Union of Australia scheme. This is a scheme of which people in South Australia in particular are very aware.

These superannuation schemes have certain features in common. I believe all of these schemes ultimately will undermine the very economic system we have in this country. The trustees of these schemes are not people in the community; they are not businesses or organisations such as that. The trustees of the schemes are the union officials themselves. All of the trustees, not just some of the trustees, are from the trade union movement. The schemes are entirely controlled by the trade union movement itself. The second feature of these superannuation schemes is that all contributions made to it come from the employers. There is no employee contribution whatsoever. Thirdly, I think one should point out quickly that great pressure is building in the ACTU-in the trade union movement generally-to ensure that all employees join these superannuation funds and that membership of a trade union dominated superannuation fund be contingent on a person in the first place being a member of a trade union. In other words, it is a back-door method of ensuring compulsory union membership.

These superannuation schemes are being introduced. They are being bullied through by the various unions involved. The bullying and the cajoling of those unions is not being resisted by the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis), it is not being resisted by the Government and it is not being resisted by the Labor State Premiers. Let us look very briefly at the Storemen and Packers Union dispute and the effect that union's demands are having on the paint industry and flowing through to the rest of the industry. The Leader of the Opposition mentioned that a number of workers had been laid off at a Ford motor vehicle factory. Let us look at what is happening this very day in my own State of South Australia. As a result of these extortionate claims by the Storemen and Packers Union-claims which are not being resisted by the Government as they should be-1,300 workers at the General Motors-Holden's Ltd Elizabeth plant have been laid off this very day. Today all 1,300 of those workers are going home without work because this Government has not acted to stamp on the actions of the Storemen and Packers Union. As well, 1,200 workers are being laid off in Dandenong.

The Mitsubishi Motors Australia Ltd motor vehicle plant in Adelaide is facing closure by the end of the week, again because of inaction by the Government. Six hundred workers from the Kelvinator Australia Ltd factory in Adelaide also are facing retrenchment. This is because the Government has done nothing and because Premier Bannon in South Australia has done nothing. Premier Bannon was asked 11 days ago by Kelvinator to do something about the dispute. In 11 days he has not even replied to that company's demands. I think there could not be a better example than that of the South Australian Bannon Labor Government, supported by honourable members opposite, supporting the gangster tactics of the union in railroading through superannuation schemes which within one year will give union control of $4 billion worth of superannuation funds-funds that will be invested throughout the economy to the disbenefit of Australians.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIA BILL 1986[COGNATE BILL:AUSTRALIA (REQUEST AND CONSENT) BILL 1985]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 13 November, on motion by Mr Lionel Bowen:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it is the wish of the House to debate the Australia Bill 1986 concurrently with the Australia (Request and Consent) Bill 1985. If there is no objection, the Chair will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australia Bill and the Australia (Request and Consent) Bill which are now before the House are important, if uncontroversial in the sense that there is no objection from the Opposition to the Bills. Indeed, we support them. The purpose of the Bills is to terminate, or get rid of, constitutional links between Australia and the United Kingdom and between the Australian States and the United Kingdom which are anachronistic, which are no longer needed and which do not reflect the needs of this country or of the States. The constitutional linkage between Australia and the United Kingdom has been a close and unique linkage and reflects the history of the founding of the Australian colonies and the way in which we developed until the time of Federation.

SPEECH.PARA: Each of the main areas of settlement of our country was founded and developed under quite different conditions-something that is frequently forgotten by outsiders and Australians. Each of those areas of settlement was prisoner of the tyranny of distance which has shaped not only Australia's relations with the outside world but also relations between its main population centres, and which has so influenced the different and characteristic developments within different parts of our country.

It is often forgotten that one reason for the traditional rivalry between Sydney and Melbourne, to take an example, and the traditional rivalry which is still felt at some levels between the States is to be found in the simple fact that before the advent of modern communications, particularly in travel, telecommunications, radio and television, the different parts of the country were in a very true sense, isolated from each other. People could and did live and die without having any real understanding of how Australians in other parts of this vast country lived.

Australia's linkage with the United Kingdom has been close not only constitutionally, in a very unique way, but also in a deeply personal way. It reflects our settlement, our development and the common language, customs and traditions which were imported into this country from settlement. Perhaps, above all, this close linkage is a reflection of our place, first in the empire, later in the Commonwealth of Nations but most especially in the fact that until the end of the Second World War a very great majority of settlers in this country, or their ancestors-indeed more than 90 per cent of them-had come from the United Kingdom and Ireland. But tides change in the affairs of nations. Over the last 40 years we have drawn migrants from all over the world and have markedly changed the ethnic mix, character and destiny of our nation, although we are still desperately underpopulated for such a rich country in a world that is short of resources and living space. We have witnessed over the last 40 years the transformation of Britain from a world power to a second order power and, with Britain's entry into the European Economic Community, we have witnessed an historic change in Britain's perception of its place in the world. Incidentally, there has also been a loss of free entry by Australians into Britain and by Britons into Australia.

The Bills before the House are, in an historical sense, notable. For all that some may look back with nostalgia and a sense of loss to our past, it is something that cannot be recreated. These Bills give effect to an agreement reached between the States and the Commonwealth under section 51 of the Constitution which provides for such agreements. The purpose of the Bills is to remove outmoded constitutional links and restraints that presently exist between the Commonwealth of Australia and the States and the United Kingdom, and to replace them with arrangements that reflect our sovereignty, nationhood and independence. The Bills will be reflected and given effect to by mirror legislation that will be passed by the United Kingdom Parliament.

I shall speak briefly about the changes that the Bills will make-changes that have been put to the House by the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen). In part, what these Bills have done is to put certain things beyond doubt. I shall outline some of the changes. First, there is the termination of the power of the United Kingdom Parliament to legislate for Australia. One would think that this was something that did not exist in any event. The ordinary Australian would be surprised if he or she were told that theoretically such a power existed. Next, it is to be made clear that the States will have full power to make laws for the peace, order and good government of each State and that in doing so their laws may have extraterritorial operation. It is also to be made clear that the legislative powers of each State parliament include all the legislative powers that the United Kingdom Parliament might have exercised before the commencement of the Australia Bill which will come into operation as an Act in 1986. The other Bill is the Australia (Request and Consent) Bill. Incidentally, this does not mean that States will be able to establish diplomatic relations with other countries-a very wise inhibition on State power. The Bill also provides that no law of a State made after the commencement of the Australia Act, as it will be called, shall be void or inoperative on the ground that it is repugnant to the laws of England or to any law of the United Kingdom Parliament. In future the Queen's representative in each State of Australia will be the Governor and advice to Her Majesty in relation to the exercise of her powers and functions in respect of a State will be tendered by State Premiers instead of advice going through the Foreign and Commonwealth Office of the United Kingdom-a somewhat cumbersome, ancient and outmoded procedure.

Another provision of the Bill is that States may not, in the future, make laws with respect to the constitution, powers or procedures of a State, unless these are made in such manner and form as may be required by a law of a State parliament. The Australia Act will require a State government not to withhold assent to a Bill passed according to the requirements of the Parliament of a State and the power of the Queen to disallow State laws and any requirement of State laws to be suspended pending the signification of the Queen's pleasure are to be put to an end. Other changes were outlined in the Attorney-General's second reading speech and in the explanatory memorandum. Save for one area, there is nothing more that I wish to say about the provisions of the Bills. Much in the Australia Bill is of a rather theoretical nature in the sense that it deals with questions which have, for the most part, been of little real practical importance to this country.

However, one part is of great importance-and that deals with the termination of all rights of appeal to the Privy Council. This has been a longstanding right and it has had many adherents, not simply amongst lawyers who might desire to take a trip at a client's expense. The arguments advanced have been largely three-that one needs consistency in development of the common law, that one needs an impartial outside tribunal and that one needs something in the nature of a Commonwealth court. I must say that I have never been able to accept any of these arguments. Let us look at the argument of consistency. What about a case in which we believe the Privy Council is wrong? That seems a very high price to pay for consistency. What of impartiality? I have heard many lawyers advance the view that if one goes to London one might get a more impartial view of things. I have never checked but I sometimes suspect that the provisions safeguarding appeals to the Privy Council might have been introduced originally at the request of sectional interests. Putting my suspicions to one side, I have never been able to understand why Australians should think that they would get a more impartial hearing in London than they would in their own High Court. I have never been able to understand the suspicion of the High Court that some highly intelligent Australians have felt in the past. I think that some people still believe that it is better to go to London than to the High Court.

Lastly, there is the argument that we should have a Commonwealth court. That is understandable, but it is an opportunity that has passed. The Privy Council was never a Commonwealth court, although if one looks at law reports one sees that occasionally a judge from one country or another-sometimes Australia-appears as a member of the board of the Privy Council hearing an appeal. If there had been an opportunity to establish a Commonwealth court, I wonder how good it would have been. Whilst parts of the Commonwealth have produced great judges, equally parts have produced judges of far lesser calibre. I would also put the argument against the retention of the appeal to the Privy Council on broader grounds. As an Australian, I have always found it incomprehensible that we should go to London to learn what our law is. I can recall going there in 1966 on a constitutional case. It was an application for special leave and we had already lost five nil in front of the High Court presided over by Mr Justice McTiernan, with Justices Kitto, Menzies, Windeyer and Owen sitting on that Court.

We went to London in mid-1966. As a practising barrister I was delighted to accept the fee and fascinated with the opportunity of being in London. I want the House to understand quite clearly that I felt no qualms about going to London. The only sorrow that I entertain about the Privy Council in terms of my days in practice is that there were not more occasions to go there. But when we arrived in London we were struck with the same feeling of what we were doing here, particularly when I recall the counsel who appeared in that case. The name of the case was Beal v. Marrickville Margarine. The leading counsel was Mr Aickin of Queen's Counsel, later Sir Keith Aickin of the High Court and, sadly, deceased. The second Queen's Counsel was Mr Mahoney, now Mr Justice Mahoney of the Court of Appeal of New South Wales. The third counsel in the case was a promising junior by the name of Ninian Stephen, later Sir Ninian Stephen of the High Court and now the Governor-General of this country, and the last counsel was myself.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have all done well.

—I was very glad to be on board that team. Just by way of an anecdote, I must tell the House that after Mr Aickin had presented a lucid analysis of the law for the purposes of the Privy Council, the Presiding Law Lord turned to the Solicitor-General for New South Wales, Mr Harold Snelling, who was there to intervene and said `We don't need to trouble you, Mr Snelling', and that was the end of that. The other side was not even called upon and one cannot lose a special leave application more directly than that.

SPEECH.PARA: If honourable members remember the kind of lustre that surrounded the Dixonian High Court at the height of its eminence-of all the courts that was probably the most eminent court this country has had-they really must ask people who say that we should keep this remnant of a colonial past why it is when that Court was generally regarded throughout the English speaking land as the pre-eminent court in the English speaking land that we have to go elsewhere for the purposes of learning our law. I therefore welcome this Bill, although I do appreciate the feelings of some of my colleagues at the Bar who will look on this repeal of the final way of getting to the Privy Council as a gross trampling on their rights, freedoms and privileges and the opportunity to go forum shopping and to choose between the High Court and the Privy Council in those few circumstances where an appeal is now open. I welcome the step made by the Attorney-General in bringing forward this Bill and I also welcome the Bill itself.

Let me conclude with a few general observations. This Bill is not, of course, a step in the direction of Australia becoming a republic. This country does not need to be one and it does not want to be one; nor, if I may say so, as the Attorney-General is at the table, is it any justification-I do not think he would suggest that it is-for a wholesale amendment to the Constitution. People can have different views about whether we need a new Constitution and can sincerely entertain quite different views on that subject. We on this side of the House are still awaiting the justification of the Government's proposition that we need a new Constitution for 1988, which is our Bicentenary. It is a simple-minded proposition for the Government to argue that it would be nice to have a new Constitution for 1988. I would be glad if the Government or the Attorney-General would sometime in the very near future take the trouble to spell out in detail the defects in the existing Constitution. Nobody would claim that it is perfect; nobody would claim that improvements could not be made to it. But making improvements is one thing-a wholesale change is a quite different matter.

I notice on the speakers list the names of one or two members from the other side of the House whom one of my Tasmanian colleagues sometimes refers to as members from Moscow corner. I do not know what they are going to say on the subject, but if they do have any views about this country becoming a republic which they would care to express, I am sure the Australian people would like to hear those views even though the Australian people would massively disagree with those views.

Once again, I congratulate the Government on bringing these two Bills forward. I wish them a speedy passage in the Parliament and, of course, in the United Kingdom Parliament where we have to join the queue of Bills for the purposes of finally disentangling ourselves from anachronistic restraints and arrangements which simply do not reflect the status, the sovereignty and the future of this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australia Bill and the Australia (Request and Consent) Bill arise from a desire by the Federal Government and all State governments to remove outmoded residual constitutional links that still exist between Australia and the United Kingdom Parliament and the Government and the judicial system. In some ways it is amazing that this action was not taken many years ago, but when one compares the attitudes even of Australian Labor Party Prime Ministers since Federation it is easy to understand that the change in public perception of the relationship between Australia and the United Kingdom has been gradual. Speaking of the Mother Country in 1914, Andrew Fisher said:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia will stand beside our own to help and defend her to our last man and our last shilling.
This was prior to a war of very dubious justification. Let us compare this statement with a well-known statement of another Labor Prime Minister in 1941. John Curtin said:
Without any inhibitions of any kind, I make it quite clear that Australia looks to America, free of any pangs as to our traditional links or kinship with the United Kingdom.

This was said at the start of a war of more justifiable origin. It was a long time before Australia realised that, as a nation, it did not depend intimately and comprehensively on another country, a country which could not really be much further away. A former Minister in this place, Gordon Bryant, is said to have made the point that the reason French is a major language in Australia is that France is across the channel from England.

World War II should have taught us something we ought never forget. When Singapore fell there was a stage when Australians realised Australia was defenceless against invasion. We should have learned then that our great and powerful friends are there with us for their own interests as well as ours. Conversely, we should have learned that independence does not always mean freedom even if it reaches the extent of isolation. That isolationist attitude is always out there in the electorates of Australia, but it is generally held by people who give little credence to the events of history. We do not want to break our friendly ties and indeed have not broken our friendly ties. Relationships with the United Kingdom are not attacked by this legislation. They will continue with the Commonwealth of Nations.

Some would say that Britain gave birth to our nation. I would say the Britain laid the egg that was to yield the nation, but laid it in someone else's nest. There was some nourishment from outside. The United Kingdom peopled this country and thus cultured it in its own way. The original inhabitants, though, are certainly questioning that culture today. There are people who claim that the slate with England should now be clean. John Pringle wrote:

Yet, when all is said, everything that Britain could do for Australia as a nation was done long ago. Britain discovered Australia, founded her as a place to dump her criminals, governed her, peopled her, nourished her and finally set her free. Australia long ago repaid any debt there was hundred times over with the blood of her young men killed in three wars. There is nothing to regret; the slate is rubbed clean.

The legislation brings a number of changes. It removes outmoded constitutional links. The Queen will now be advised directly by State Premiers on her exercise of power relating to the States. No longer will she be formally advised by United Kingdom Ministers on State matters; she will be advised by the Premiers. The United Kingdom Parliament may no longer make laws for Australia, and the Privy Council in England will no longer be a place of appeal from Australian courts. The High Court of Australia will be the final court of appeal for Australian courts.

I have quoted a little today from our history books. I might conclude by mentioning the growing trend to republicanism in Australia, particularly among young people. The honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) mentioned that he was anticipating some republican-type sentiments from what he termed `Moscow corner' on this side of the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —He was not suggesting you were in it. You just sit close to it.

—No, I thank him for that. I suggest that other members are not necessarily in it, either. I was surprised to hear Ron Barassi-who I noticed was being accommodated in this House a few days ago by a section of the Liberal Party-at a meeting in Cooma state that it was time that we got away from mother's apron strings. He was talking about a break with the United Kingdom, not just to the extent contained in this Bill, but in our relationships with the monarchy and our total relationship with the United Kingdom. There are those from all sections of Australian politics who, I guess, will try to slow down that process. There are also those from all sections of Australian politics who would speed it up. It seems to me that the breaks will continue to happen, especially when one considers that this legislation that we are debating today involves all States asking for this Bill, the Australia Bill 1986, to be enacted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure what were the breaks that the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow) said needed to happen, because as I understand it the Australia Bill and the Australia (Request and Consent) Bill constitute the measures left for this Parliament to play its part in patriating to Australia its constitutional arrangements or, in the words of the explanatory memorandum, to sever the remaining constitutional links between Australia and the United Kingdom. If this legislation does that, I do not know what is left to be done, unless of course the honourable member is suggesting that we should abandon our role as a consitutional monarchy and that the Queen should be removed as Queen of Australia. If that is what he means by breaking the links, let him say it openly, but as I understand it these Bills constitute the measures left for this Parliament to play its part in repatriating to Australia its constitutional arrangements. Nothing more is left to be done.

SPEECH.PARA: Even so, nobody, I am sure, has felt that we are less than an independent nation. For my part, in participating in this Parliament, I have never felt that. We have our own Parliament and our own policies. We have determined our own taxes. We have declared war. Yet despite all of this having occurred, it is still said in terms of our legal links that we have ties with the United Kingdom. Like most Australians I have in no way felt intimidated by those links or threatened by the possibility of the United Kingdom's intervention. This, I suspect, is because of the way in which Australia's constitutional arrangements have developed over time. Yet we still have these residual links which, for those involved, have caused some difficulty and, for the purists, some exasperation.

What are the matters requiring this complex co-operative effort on the part of Australia, the States of Australia and the United Kingdom Government? First, it is the sovereignty of the United Kingdom Parliament over Australia and the States in strict legal terms; second, the continuing subordination of some State laws to the laws of the United Kingdom; third, the power of the Crown still to disallow Commonwealth and State legislation; fourth, the remaining appeals to the Privy Council from State supreme courts on State matters; and fifth, the obligation of States when nominating Governors and proposing honours to advise the Crown through the British Ministers rather than directly.

These are not new initiatives of a republican Labor government desirous of overthrowing our traditional and valued links with the British Crown; rather, they are a co-operative effort of Labor, Liberal and National Party governments, past and present, State and Federal. As the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) has advised, the States of Australia have already put in place their legislation respecting this Commonwealth action. The Attorney in his second reading speech acknowledged the role of the Government, albeit guardedly, by the use of the phrase `in accordance with the established policy of successive Commonwealth governments' and more generously by the reference to consultations `dating from the 1982 Premiers Conference under our predecessors'. I think he clearly recognises the involvement of the former Fraser Government in developing these proposals.

It was Attorney-General Durack who in 1982 was able to achieve from a Premiers Conference a decision to adopt a package of proposals to sever the constitutional links. Such was the concern at misinterpretation that it was stressed that this did not involve cutting links with the Crown or, in the Attorney's words, `impair the position of the Queen as Queen of Australia'. Since 1982-83 discussions have progressed on this matter rather slowly to the point of this legislation, which is somewhat different in some areas of peripheral legal importance, but nevertheless symbolic to the States. In the time during which agreement was not possible a great deal of difficulty arose, particularly in relation to appeals to the Privy Council, and this a matter which I will return for comment shortly.

That delay was occasioned by the need for resolution of these questions: How State Governors would in the future be appointed and how imperial honours, in those States which retained them, would be recommended. The solution proposed in this package is that on those two matters the Queen will be advised, not as in the past by United Kingdom Ministers, but by her State governments directly. Administratively, until now Premiers would offer what an official once described to me as little `a' advice to the Foreign and Commonwealth Office in the United Kingdom and the Minister of that Office would then offer big `A' or capital `A' advice to the Queen. The first solution proposed was that the Queen would in future be advised on these matters, not by the Foreign and Commonwealth Office, a British department of state, but the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia. In other words, advice on who should or should not be a State Governor or who should be the recipient of an imperial honour would come from the State Premier to the Governor-General, who would then advise the Queen-no different from the old arrangement, but through a more appropriate postbox.

It seems to me that the Commonwealth of Australia, if it means anything at all, should be able to speak as one, particularly in tendering advice to the Queen as Queen of Australia. Nevertheless, the Queen, in the spirit of compromise that this legislation represents, will now have to deal directly with as many State Premiers as Australia has now or may have at some future time. It seems to me that this issue was a stumbling block in the discussions which occasioned a delay of several years in advancing these proposals.

This delay has been significant in the area of Privy Council appeals. Since the passing of the 1968 Privy Council (Limitation of Appeals) Act and the 1975 Privy Council (Appeals from the High Court) Act, it has been accepted that the High Court of Australia was the final court of appeal. This decision to abolish appeals in Federal matters set the scene and put an end to any ideas that some, like me, may have harboured to see the development of genuine Commonwealth court of appeal in lieu of the Privy Council. By that I mean a court of the Commonwealth of nations and not the Commonwealth of Australia. The Privy Council, while it retained very distinguished jurists, not only from the United Kingdom but from the Commonwealth, appeared to many to be anachronistic and, as a result, its role was limited. A Commonwealth court could have drawn from a wide membership of Commonwealth countries generally, as the inheritors of the common law of the United Kingdom. While courts still pay regard to the judgments of superior courts of other common law countries it is most likely that the laws of each country will become increasingly unique and the common law will be no longer common.

The High Court became the final court of appeal for Australia but not for decisions from State supreme courts. In 1975 a Bill entitled Privy Council (Appeals Abolition) Bill was introduced to this Parliament to abolish unilaterally all remaining appeals from State courts. The Bill failed. In 1978 the High Court in Viro and the Queen unanimously decided that it no longer regarded itself as being bound by decisions of the Privy Council. This created some problems of interpretation for State supreme courts, which could find themselves bound by precedents from the Commonwealth High Court in conflict with Privy Council decisions. The anomalies that this could create were seen, as early as 1975, as likely to be significant.

In 1984 the Australian Law Journal in its June current topics section dealt with two cases-the Attorney-General v. Finch and Caltex Oil (Australia) Pty Ltd v. XL Petroleum (NSW) Pty Ltd. It noted that appeals to the Privy Council came to an end in Canada in 1949. In commenting on these cases it stated that the High Court's concern at delays in finalising the abolition of appeals because of conflicts created was best summed up in the words of the majority of the Court in the Caltex and XL case as `a piecemeal approach to abolition'. The High Court acknowledged that it was possible in the same litigation for an appeal to lie on the one hand with the High Court and on the other with the Privy Council. In considering the consequences of this proposition the Court then considered what would be the assumed result were contemporaneous appeals considered by each court.

Now that the High Court is not bound by Privy Council decisions the old hierarchical relationship between the two courts no longer applies. What the High Court has had to assume for the management of such cases is that the Privy Council should stand aside while the High Court dealt with the same matter. I suspect this was done more in pleading than in the sense of there being any reality of any particular power of the High Court. It is clear that delay has led to uncertainty and appeal forum shopping with the possibility of conflicting judgments of different courts.

One other contemporary decision of this Parliament served to exacerbate these problems. That was the decision to restrict appeals to the High Court by the removal of some appeals as of right. I am not critical of that decision, rather I am drawing attention to its consequence. The conflict of authorities are well understood but the Chief Justice of our High Court, the Rt Hon. Sir Harry Gibbs, wrote about it in the following terms when he addressed the twenty-third Australian Legal Convention in Melbourne on 5 August:

The situation was described as intolerable by my predecessor, Sir Garfield Barwick, in his address on ``The State of the Australian Judicature'' in 1977. It has become worse since that time, because the fact that no appeal may now be brought as of right to the High Court provides a reason or at least an excuse for taking appeals to London. Indeed, Priestly J. A. recently said that New South Wales case-law is growing relatively more quickly in London than in Canberra. Litigants from Western Australia, previously no great clients of the Judicial Committee, now appear to find it cheaper to appeal to London direct from a decision of a single judge than to appeal to the Full Court of the Supreme Court of Western Australia and then to seek special leave to appeal to the High Court. In a significant number of cases the unsuccessful party in an action in a Supreme Court now has it both ways, and institutes an appeal to the Judicial Committee and at the same time applies for special leave to appeal to the High Court.

It has recently been announced that agreement has been reached between the Commonwealth, the States and the authorities in the United Kingdom to abolish the remaining right of appeal to the Privy Council. Nevertheless, I have felt it necessary to point to the difficulty and inconvenience of the present situation, because progress in this matter has been so slow that one feels that not all of those concerned understand the urgency of the need to lose this chapter in our judicial history.

I, too, join the Chief Justice in lamenting the delay in processing these Bills to fruition and encourage the Attorney-General to have the matter concluded as soon as possible. I am glad in a sense, like the Attorney, that the matter will be carried into operation via the power exercised under section 51 (xxxviii) of the Constitution whereby legislation is enacted at the request of all States. This avoids the possibility of the United Kingdom Parliament having to legislate to hand these matters back to the States.

It also avoids a problem that we may have suffered; the problem the Canadians suffered when their repatriation arrangements were being considered. Some United Kingdom members saw it as appropriate to raise questions relating to the American Indians and the treaties that the British had previously entered into. They used this as an opportunity to intrude, in a way which most of us would find quite unexpected, into the internal affairs of Canada. One hopes that the United Kingdom members would not want to do this to Australia's affairs in relation to, say, our Aborigines. Some people may seek to raise this matter overseas with a view to embarrassment rather than to extending helpfully questions relating to our Aboriginal people. How ludicrous it would be as evidence of our sovereignty if the United Kingdom Government were to use its residual power to legislate a scheme of arrangement to patriate the Constitution which was not in a form acceptable to the States.

One other matter addressed in this legislation is the provision to retain those sections of the Colonial Laws Validity Act 1865 which provided the legislative basis for certain manner and form provisions in State constitution Acts. These provisions, which are restricted to the powers or procedures of State parliaments, can be the basis of binding successive parliaments to an electoral arrangement which cannot be readily revoked or changed. Provisions requiring a referendum before changing upper House arrangements for New South Wales were upheld under those provisions in the significant case of Clayton v. Heffron, a case with which I am sure the Attorney is familiar.

In my judgment it is appropriate that legislation of this sort should not seek to change the status quo. It is appropriate that this legislation is supported by the Opposition. While it in no way enhances the freedom most Australians have long enjoyed and taken for granted, nevertheless it is still the culmination of a series of events which complete all the legal steps necessary to ensure that even technically nobody in any other country can make laws for Australia. It properly reflects Australia's status as an independent and sovereign nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fitzgibbon Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to have the opportunity to speak on the Australia Bill 1986, an historic Bill. I say it is historic because in November 1985, almost 200 years from the time of the first settlement, we are about to sever the last remaining outmoded, antiquated and anachronistic residual constitutional links with the United Kingdom. We are about to divest ourselves of our convict shackles and give Australia the status it so richly deserves, that of an independant and sovereign nation able to stand on its own feet and be legislatively and judicially independent. Yet whilst we break these last remaining constitutional links with the United Kingdom, we still accept and recognise Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II as Queen of Australia and we still remain a member of the Commonwealth of Nations. What is probably more remarkable is that this historic occasion of our coming of age has been achieved not only with the co-operation of successive Commonwealth governments but also, at long last, with the co-operation of the States.

SPEECH.PARA: For some years now, although successive Commonwealth governments have desired to be legislatively and judicially independent of the United Kingdom, for some reason or other the States have failed, until recently, to reach agreement on this important and sensitive issue. In essence, the Bills before us are the culmination of Labor, Liberal and National governments' efforts. The Attorneys-General, both present and former, who have brought about this historic occasion are to be commended. The Bills also represent the co-operation and agreement of Her Majesty the Queen and the Commonwealth and United Kingdom governments.

I now turn to some of the important legislative and judicial aspects of the Australia Bill 1986. Following agreement reached at the Premiers Conferences in Canberra on 24 and 25 June 1982 and 21 June 1984, the States have requested the Commonwealth Parliament, under paragraph 51 (xxxviii) of the Constitution, to take measures to bring constitutional arrangements affecting the Commonwealth and the States into conformity with the status of the Commonwealth of Australia as a sovereign, independent and federal nation. The Bill contains several major changes, one of which seeks to end the powers of the British Parliament and Government in relation to the States, including power to legislate to affect the States and the Queen's power to withhold assent from or disallow State laws on the advice of British Ministers. The Bill also seeks an end to British legislation still restricting the legislative powers of the States.

The repeal of the Colonial Laws Validity Act 1865, which can, at best, be described as a colonial relic, means an end to the humiliating subordination of the State parliaments to imperial legislation. The inability of the States to free themselves of some of the provisions of the imperial Merchant Shipping Act 1894, is a good example of some of the problems faced by the States. Consequently the repeal of sections 735 and 736 of the Merchant Shipping Act 1894 means that the States are now free from the restrictions imposed by these sections of the Act under which certain State laws on merchant shipping are subject to confirmation of the Queen acting on the advice of the United Kingdom Ministers, or reserved for the signification of the Queen's pleasure. No doubt this procedure was invaluable to the United Kingdom in the 1890s to ensure that the lifelines of the empire, the shipping lanes, remained unimpeded by colonial legislative control, but its relevance today is non-existent.

Of major significance in this Bill is the move to end the right of appeal to the Privy Council, thus making the High Court of Australia the final court of appeal for all Australian courts. This is an important and long overdue step. It is absurd and anachronistic in this day and age to have a Privy Council in the United Kingdom deciding whether decisions made in our supreme courts are correct. This belief is also apparently shared by the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council, which, in 1981, handed down a decision in a damages case from the South Australian Supreme Court and warned that in future it would dismiss such appeals. It made it abundantly clear that because of the increasing social and economic differences between Australia and Britain, the High Court of Australia was the only proper tribunal to hear damages appeals.

The Bill contains special arrangements which will apply in relation to State Governors and recommendations for imperial honours, so that United Kingdom Ministers no longer advise the Queen. The Bill establishes a new constitutional principle of allowing State Premiers to advise the Queen directly on the appointment and dismissal of State Governors. Thus the present outdated requirement of State Governors to be appointed on advice from British Ministers will cease. If the States are to preserve that degree of independence that was clearly intended at the time of Federation, it is fundamental that they retain absolute control of the right to secure the appointment of Governors of their own choice.

Under this legislation State Governors are to be vested with the Queen's existing powers and functions in respect of the States, except those in relation to their own appointment and dismissal, and in relation to the awarding of imperial honours. Clearly, imperial awards remain the prerogative of the Queen and are not affected by this legislation. State Premiers wishing to recommend imperial honours may do so directly to the Queen. However, when the Queen is personally present in a State, she will be able to exercise a power or function in relation to a State but will do so only if there has been mutual and prior agreement between the Queen and the relevant Premier that it would be appropriate for her to do so. The State Premiers have confirmed their acceptance that such mutual and prior agreement is an essential ingredient of the proposed arrangement.

As I said earlier, this legislation has been achieved with bipartisan support, and by the enactment of similar legislation in the United Kingdom the last remaining impediments of our colonial status will disappear. It is highly appropriate at a time when we are approaching our bicentenary that Australia now has the status of an independent and sovereign nation. Accordingly, I commend these Bills to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nehl Mr G.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australia Bill and the Australia (Request and Consent) Bill purport to provide the legislative basis for the ending of residual and outmoded constitutional and other legal links with the United Kingdom. I know that ardent republicans might portray these views as very unfashionable, but these people would argue that any defence of our British heritage, including the great institutions of our constitutional and political system, are perhaps meaningless in the so-called multicultural eighties. I am proud of the British patrimony of this nation. I am proud to see that we fly the Union Jack in the hoist of the Australian flag. I would be bitterly opposed to any attempt by any Australian government to champion what passes for fashionable prejudice amongst certain circles in our country and change our nation's ensign.
