TALK.START.PARA: —You'll have a lot of friends.

—Yes, I know that. Our Constitution, notwithstanding the destructive knocking which it has received from some sour partisans of the Labor Party during the last 10 years, is the product of a great constitutional and political settlement which saw six disparate and very independent colonies federate to produce a Commonwealth. The creation of this Commonwealth resulted in one federated nation straddling an entire continent. It produced a Commonwealth committed to freedom, liberty and democratic government, and no amount of vindictive invective from the Labor Party can alter the fact that the Australian people retain a commitment to the system of constitutional government which we have today.

SPEECH.PARA: Our masters, the people of Australia, have consistently asserted their faith in our Constitution and the system of government enshrined therein. This has occurred in referendum after referendum. Where the Australian people wished to alter the Constitution, they did so, and conversely, where they wished no change, they denied proposed alterations. This is just as it should be. While I support the thrust of this legislation, as outlined by the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) in his second reading speech, I believe that these Bills are fundamentally defective. We are once again being treated to the dubious spectacle of the Hawke Government seeking to pass legislation which is binding on a subsequent parliament. The Attorney-General is asking the Parliament to pass legislation which, following enactment by the Parliament at Westminster, will purport to bind succeeding parliaments at Westminster. This flies in the face of the accepted doctrine of parliamentary sovereignty which exists in both English and Australian constitutional law.

I remind the House that, under the doctrine of parliamentary sovereignty as outlined by constitutional authors such as Dicey, Wade and others and as accepted by courts both in the United Kingdom and in Australia, no parliament can purport to bind a subsequent parliament so that the latter must follow the legislative fiat of the previous parliament. The contrary proposition is a nonsense. Only a fortnight ago we saw the Attorney-General and the Government passing futile legislation which purported to subject future Commonwealth parliaments to the legislative provisions contained in the Australian Bill of Rights Bill. Today the House is once again presented with this proposition in clause 1 of the Australia Bill which is repeated in the Schedule of the Australia (Request and Consent) Bill. The Government is asking this Parliament to pass a clause which says:

No Act of the Parliament of the United Kingdom passed after the commencement of this Act shall extend, or be deemed to extend, to the Commonwealth, to a State or to a Territory as part of the law of the Commonwealth, of the State or of the Territory.

While this Parliament, and ultimately Westminster, can bring this clause into legislation it is in reality a mere puff, the effect of which is to bring the exercise of legislative power by both parliaments into disrepute. Such a clause will be effective only so long as this Parliament and Westminster abide by its spirit.

There is no power on earth which can stop a future parliament either in Canberra or in Westminster from repealing the Acts incorporating the Bills before the House. While some academic authors challenge the doctrine of parliamentary sovereignty, the fact remains that it is clearly upheld by the courts. For as long as the system of jurisprudence which underlies our system of constitutional law remains in place, the doctrine of parliamentary sovereignty will remain a functioning part of our constitutional law. I would suggest to the House that, if the Attorney-General is serious in his attempt to find a method of abolishing the capacity of Westminster to make laws affecting Australia, the most sensible way would be to patriate the Australian Constitution and extend to the provisions of the Commonwealth of Australia Constitution Act the provisions for altering the Constitution which are found in section 128. A similar scheme would need to be devised for the States and Territories so that in the end the origins of legislative power are the Australian people and the citizens of each and every State and Territory.

Unfortunately, the structure of the relationship between Westminster and Australia can still be changed by any future Federal government. An extremist government, whether of the far Left or Right, could tamper with the Constitution by making advances to an ideologically similar government in the United Kingdom, and persuading it to act legislatively. Our Constitution and our system of government are not safe from this possibility, far-fetched though it may be. It behoves this Parliament to ensure that the Australian Constitution and the system of constitutional monarchy that it enshrines emanate from the Australian people, who are in reality the source of all power in this nation. In this way, neither our Constitution nor our democracy will ever be threatened because they will be firmly guarded by the ultimate source of power in this nation, namely, the Australian people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —When preparing my speech for this debate on the Australia Bill 1986 and the Australia (Request and Consent) Bill, I felt that this was an historic piece of legislation. To say that is to repeat myself because, twice before in the last two weeks, I have made similar statements about two other pieces of legislation. However, I stand by my view. This is truly a piece of legislation that indicates a coming of age with respect to constitutional development in Australia. It is important to emphasise that this legislation is, to the best of my knowledge, supported by all parties represented in the Australian Parliament. Also, and equally importantly, it is supported by all the States of Australia. It is my personal opinion that the present constitutional arrangements governing the conduct of government in Australia will, despite the passage of this legislation, remain woefully inadequate. I compliment theAttorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) on his initiative in trying a new way to achieve constitutional reform. Clearly the Constitutional Conventions have failed us all, have failed Australia as a nation, and we must think of new alternatives and a way to bring about the bipartisan support that is so necessary to achieve constitutional change.

SPEECH.PARA: Speaking in the debate on the Australian Bill of Rights the other day, I referred to one of the innumerable examples of the inadequacy in the present Constitution. I referred to section 25 of the Federal Constitution which entrenches the principle of racism into our own national Constitution. That is but one of hundreds of examples where the Federal Constitution, and equally State constitutions, remain inadequate and will do so following the passage of this legislation. Australian history tells us a number of things about constitutional change. The first is that we will not achieve substantial constitutional change in this country until there is a bipartisan support on the initiatives to be undertaken. Secondly, we will not achieve constitutional change unless there is a powerful and popular movement of people who are committed to that change. In the first respect I compliment the Opposition on its support for this initiative and indeed pay tribute in particular to Senator Durack, of whom on other occasions I have been most critical, for his constructive initiatives which are substantially responsible for this legislation. I hope that that bipartisan spirit will be further reflected in years to come because I am sure that people of good will on both sides of the House can reach agreement on the need for other constitutional reforms, many aspects of which are the subject of public debate but on which as yet we do not have that bipartisan agreement. However, those challenges and reforms are for the future.

The passage of this legislation that is now before us is a source of pride for the Government. Perhaps the best way to highlight the significance of the reforms is to outline briefly the unbelievably outmoded nature of the relationship that exists at this very moment between the United Kingdom and Australia and the Australian States. At this very moment I wonder how many Australians realise that State governments do not have the legal authority to advise the Queen in relation to State matters but must, instead, communicate such advice through a foreign government, namely, the Government of the United Kingdom. Thus, also at this time State governments have no absolute right to secure the appointment of governors of their choice. In 1865 the United Kingdom Parliament passed the Colonial Laws Validity Act. One of the effects of that legislation is to subordinate State parliaments to legislation of the United Kingdom Parliament which applies to the States. This power of the United Kingdom Parliament, this overriding legislation, brings about absolutely ludicrous situations.

In 1894, the United Kingdom Parliament passed the imperial Merchant Shipping Act which was designed to ensure that the then lifelines of the empire, the merchant shipping lanes, remained unimpeded by colonial legislative control. One of the cases highlighted in a research paper prepared by the Australian National University is the China Ocean Shipping case heard by the High Court in 1978. In this particular case, if the port installation damaged by a ship in South Australia had not been crown property we would have had the ludicrous situation that the liability of the owner of the vessel would have been limited to a figure calculated according to the ship's tonnage, multiplied by eight pounds sterling, which was the fixed rate in 1894. I do not think any of us want that sort of constraint or outmoded provision on the statute books and in the legal framework of the Australian nation.

Another effect of the passage of the Colonial Laws Validity Act 1865 is to require that certain Bills be reserved for royal assent as well as to require that laws with respect to the Constitution, powers or procedure of the legislature must be passed in the manner and form laid down by existing law. In 1931 the United Kingdom Parliament passed the Statute of Westminster which had the effect that the Colonial Laws Validity Act no longer applied to the Commonwealth. However, 54 years later that outmoded legislation still applies to the Australian States despite the fact that in 1931 the United Kingdom Parliament passed a law to apply that legislation no longer to the Commonwealth. The Crown still has unfettered power to disallow Commonwealth and State Acts and certain Bills are required to be reserved for royal assent. It is still at present legally possible to appeal to the Privy Council sitting in the United Kingdom in respect of cases heard by the State supreme courts on State matters. However, even in advance of legislative action by the Parliament, the Privy Council indicated in 1981 that it would dismiss such appeals where they related to damages. It is a matter of national pride that as a result of this legislation the High Court of Australia will henceforth be the final court of appeal in all cases.

Turning to the other provisions of the Bill, which override the anachronisms that I have referred to, clause 1 provides that no Act of the Parliament of the United Kingdom passed after the commencement of the Australian Act shall extend to the Commonwealth or a State. Thus, in one clause, the legislative independence of Australia from the United Kingdom is spelt out. Clause 3 of the Bill is modelled on the key clause of the Statute of Westminster to which I have already referred and will mean that State legislatures gain for the first time the sovereign power to legislate inconsistently with Acts of the United Kindgom Parliament which extend to the States. Clause 6 of the Bill is important because it picks up the principle enshrined in section 5 of the Colonial Laws Validity Act 1865 and will mean that, after the commencement of the Australia Act, any law passed by a State parliament shall be of no force or effect until it is made in the manner and form, if any, required by a State legislature. I believe that in years to come this will be a particularly important principle in Australian democracy.

It is to the credit of the New South Wales Government that one of the reforms it has made has been to entrench into the New South Wales Constitution the principle of one vote one value. This is another area where I hope people of good will on both sides of the Parliament will translate their expressed faith in the Australian people into constitutional amendments in all the Australian States. I hope that there will be inspiration at a national level to ensure that in the years to come we will not have the electoral rorts in this country that currently exist. We need to make sure that the right of people to decide the future of their government through the principle of one vote one value is really respected.

Clause 7 of the Bill provides that, subject to limited exceptions outlined in the clause, the powers and functions of the Queen in respect of a State shall henceforth be exercisable only by the Governor of the State. Clause 8 of the Bill provides that, after the commencement of the Australia Act, no State Act that has been assented to by the Governor of a State shall be subject to disallowance by the Queen or have its operation suspended pending the signification of the Queen's pleasure, while clause 9 nullifies any law purporting to require reservation of a State Bill for the signification of Her Majesty's pleasure. Clause 10 of the Bill achieves the complete executive independence of Australia from the Government of the United Kingdom.

Finally, I refer to clause 15, which has the effect that the important reforms initiated by the Australia Act could be set aside only by an Act of the Commonwealth Parliament which was passed with the concurrence of all the State parliaments. My concluding hope and plea to the Parliament is that people of good will on both sides of the chamber can work together through the changes and the ideas implemented by the Attorney-General to inspire constitutional change. Hopefully, we can make the reforms that are so desperately needed to our constitutional framework.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to take up one point that was put to the House by the honourable member for Hughes (Mr Tickner). I am always most amused to hear members of the Australian Labor Party carry on about the principle of one vote one value as though such a thing was possible to achieve in a country like Australia. I think the advocates of one vote one value would be more honest if they pointed out that it is simply impossible to achieve this objective in a federation like Australia. One has only to look at the value of a vote in, for example, Tasmania and the value of a vote in the more populous States such as New South Wales to realise that that objective simply cannot be achieved and it is quite wrong to mislead the people of Australia with that continuing shibboleth.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me get back to the legislation at hand. The Australia Bill 1986 and the Australian (Request and Consent) Bill 1985 gather up some of the residual problems which are left over from the legal situation which identifies the Queen as the Queen of Australia. This was a widely acclaimed development-a change from the old style and title, where Australia received a secondary reference. The concept of the Queen as Queen of Australia, constitutional Head of State, holding herself legally separate from her role as Queen of the United Kingdom and other realms and territories, is, I believe, a valuable innovation which has reinforced the position and acceptance of Her Majesty as Queen of Australia.

The Australia Bill has picked up some residual anomalies which need to be put out of the legal system. It is known that the merchant shipping legislation has been particularly anomalous, where sections of the relevant United Kingdom Act have been part of Australian State legislation. This legislation has had the capacity to complicate some of the essential work of co-ordinating maritime law between the Commonwealth and the States. Australia is very fortunate in the way we have been able to identify the residual problems and, through the machinery of the Premiers Conference, gather the necessary consensus to bring these matters forward into this Parliament. Canada, of course, had an analogous problem, but it went through a constitutional adjustment known to that country as a process of repatriating the constitution. It was a very difficult process indeed. I believe that our system has proved to be much superior.

Our constitutional development, of course, was quite different and proceeded from an agreement between the self-governing States to come together in one nation, the Commonwealth of Australia, which would act for Australians in foreign affairs, defence and Customs and be the focal point of Australia's nationhood. That this Constitution proceeded so quickly to give full effect to the growing sense of Australian nationhood is, I believe, a wonderful testament to those wise men who drafted it. If we stand off and look at this legislation today and place it in the context of the vast accumulation of authority that speaks in the name of Australia, I believe we can truly say: `Was that all there is to be done?' It is not very much. I believe that those people who attack the drafters of our Constitution really have no concept of the very real wisdom that was brought to bear in bringing it into place. That we have moved so smoothly through the various stages of tidying up the Statute of Westminster, the Style and Titles Act and the present legislation says a lot for the path on which Australian constitutional monarchy has been set.

In some ways there are some losses. The system of appeals to the Privy Council, until this Act limited in opportunity, enabled Australian legal minds to test the quality of contemporary British legal thinking which is of continuing world significance. Having said that, I am not against cutting off the right of appeal to the Privy Council. I just make the point that this process allowed some quite eminent legal brains to test their minds against their British contemporaries. I believe that my colleague the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) is one of those who had that opportunity. There are some in Australia who have made the point in recent times that the High Court of Australia has not been a brilliant court in recent years. In some ways it faces quite major difficulties. I am not about to enumerate them here, but they act as shadows over the thinking of many Australians as the Court moves into its position as the unquestioned interpreter of all the law of this land.

This legislation has another important general message. That message is that the institution of the monarchy has never been an inhibiting factor in Australian constitutional development. In fact, I believe that it has been a factor which has accelerated changes. The contribution of the institution was one which provided the umbrella of certainty, which meant that all our necessary changes since Federation have taken place quietly and efficiently. We have heard many complaints from the Whitlam school about the Constitution. Mr Whitlam was long a proponent of overwhelming the rest of Australia with a rule from Canberra. He saw the salvation of Australia as more and more power to Canberra, and his recent activities suggest that he has lost no faith in the capacity of the growth of Canberra bureaucracy to solve all Australia's ills. But we have to face the fact that our national administration is remote from most Australians and that so many Australians are removed from it. The reality is that the States can have a much more intensive understanding of the needs of their people than the bureaucrats in Canberra. So we cannot regard with equanimity the thirst that exists in those who want to rubbish the States and State powers. The States have vital powers, and they need them.

This Government did a great disservice to the States when it argued the Franklin dams case in the way it did. The Attorney-General of the day, who I think could be described as a legal bureaucrat if ever there was one, set about the task of demolishing every argument for maintaining the rights of the State in the face of international conventions which are determined by the United Nations, largely by countries which have no intention of applying them. The drafting of many of these so-called treaties is often appalling, and we do not have the time to put in the national effort to get them licked into shape. Most of them go to matters of law which are correctly the concerns of State governments and parliaments. The whole procedure is a mess and is laying up a great store of trouble for the future of Federal-State relations. The decision in the Franklin dams case induced by the action of this Labor Government was a sad one for the balance of the relationships with the States. Thus the High Court, which under this legislation finds itself sole master of every legal issue in this nation, has much to ponder about the future quality of its work. We have imposed great powers on the Court and we trust that the legal profession in this country will match the quality of that trust.

I now turn to the issue of the powers of State Governors. The system of their appointment has been outmoded for years, as we have heard in discussion today. The Governor was appointed on recommendation to the Queen through the Secretary of State for Foreign and Commonwealth Relations. It was wholly unsatisfactory that a British politician should have been interposed between the recommendation of a State Premier and the Queen. The effect of this legislation is to increase the direct relationship between the Queen and the Premiers of the States. It is made clear that when the Queen is personally present in a State she will be able to exercise a power or function in relation to a State where there has been mutual and prior agreement between the Queen and the Premier that it would be appropriate for her to do so. Therefore, it is quite mischievous to suggest that this legislation weakens the Queen's identity in the States. If anything, it does the opposite. It also, it seems to me, strengthens the concept of statehood.

There are those who would see any retention of the royal presence in our system as something which looks to the past rather than the future. In recent weeks, as we will all recall, we have been having a further heart-searching about the sacking of Prime Minister Whitlam by the Governor-General of the day. We are led by some in the Government to believe that the processes under which the Governor-General acted were provided by the founding fathers with very little thought. But, of course, this is not so. The Constitution came to invest the Governor-General with powers to ensure parliamentary government for the wisest and most essential of reasons. The logic is that, if parliamentary government is destroyed, democracy is gravely threatened. We saw what happened when that came about in nazi Germany.

The key to the authority of parliament is the authority to control the public purse. Under the Constitution the proviso is controlled by a joint action by the House of Representatives and the Senate to approve Supply, that is, the supply of money for government. There are those who say that, as the Prime Minister is responsible to the lower House for his majority, the Senate should not have the powers that it has been given under the Constitution. To my mind, this is a very strange argument. The Senate is elected by proportional representation, the most representative of all forms of voting. It is impractical for the House of Representatives, but it happens to be the system for the Senate. There can be no doubt in my mind that the Senate has an important claim to retain its powers over Supply. The problem for the Governor-General was the notice the Prime Minister of the day gave to the effect that he would go outside parliament for funds to run the Government. This became a crucial issue which no Governor-General could ignore. That this issue was to the fore in public debate at the time is often overlooked by the critics of the sacking.

The dismissal is pertinent to this discussion, in dealing with the critics of this legislation who suggest that our constitutional arrangements are not in keeping with our fully democratic ideal. I believe that the essence of the practical ideal is that the elected representatives of the people should at all times be supreme. They exercise that supremacy through the control of the purse. The head of state is there to protect that authority. The House will recall that the Australian newspaper published a supplement on the dismissal and that this included the front page facsimile of some of the key headlines of the day. Let me just quote them. On Saturday, 1 November we had the headline `Whitlam says he'll carry on without the Budget' and, on Thursday, 6 November `Hayden calls bankers to money talks'. We will all recall that Mr Hayden was then Treasurer, a shadow of his later self. On Friday, 7 November we had `Banks asked to meet wage loans' and, on Tuesday, 11 November `Banks ready to refuse to pay public servants' and `Court action considered to stop loans'.

It is against this public knowledge of the intention of the Government of the day to go outside parliament that the Governor-General of the day acted. Those who say that under a republican constitution the Prime Minister would have remained supreme in his authority, that the Prime Minister's authority would have remained unchallenged, ignore the fact that republican constitutions have provisions to rein in the Executive, to protect the people and the parliaments from the misuse of Executive powers. Most democratic constitutions place in the head of state, and not the head of government, special powers to protect the constitution. Indeed, republic presidents have more powers than our Governors.

No system can work without the co-operative good sense of those responsible for working it. It is amazing how well the separate responsibilities of Premier and Governor have been handled by their respective occupants. I shall not dwell on the problems which arose in Victoria, but I am quite sure that the office of Governor as an institution is one which means a great deal to the people. I recall the governorship of Sir Roden Cutler in New South Wales. There could not have been a more highly respected figure in any public life. It is vital to have a public institution which is free of politics and which can carry the many essential activities of leadership outside the framework of politics. That is what really happens when the Queen's representative takes his or her rightful place in the government of the States. This legislation removes a very outmoded system of appointment, and that is a sound development. The legislation makes no claim to change the quality of the relationship between the State Premier and the Queen. If anything, it brings the relationship into a more obvious standing. It is to be welcomed for that achievement and for the subtle legal clarifications which ensue.

TALK.START.PARA: —There have been a number of contributions on the Australia Bill and the Australia (Request and Consent) Bill and I believe that it is important that we emphasise some of the characteristics of the legislation. The honourable member for Hughes (Mr Tickner) addressed himself to the question of one vote one value. He stressed the importance of the fact that in New South Wales there has been a substantial declaration by the State Government of the principle of one vote one value. The honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar) took issue with that and pointed out that it was very difficult, in the context of a federation such as Australia, to have one vote one value when one compares perhaps the population of Tasmania with that of New South Wales. I think that is well understood in the Australian community and I think it is well understood in this House. I also think it is equally well understood that the arrangements that have been foreshadowed for Queensland by the Queensland Government and the arrangements that prevail in Western Australia in the upper House clearly are well away from the goal of one vote one value.

SPEECH.PARA: I suggest to the honourable member for Warringah that what has to be addressed is the question of intention. Since we removed the 20 per cent allowance for rural electorates-which really was an opportunity for some degree of gerrymander-there has been the intention of one vote one value in this Parliament. This is certainly so in South Australia. To strike a bipartisan note, the redistributions in South Australia under a Liberal Premier and then taken up by Labor governments have been sound and fair and have been recognised as such. But that is a long step from the foreshadowed arrangements in Queensland and also the arrangements that prevail in Western Australia, which clearly are well removed from the principle of one vote one value. In fact in Western Australia we have the extraordinary situation at the moment where the Burke Government is being held up by a most unrepresentative upper House, where some people can be elected on a very small voting basis, whilst others, usually on the Labor side of politics, need something like 10 times as many voters. That is clearly far removed from the principle of one vote one value. Obviously the situation in Queensland is so extraordinary that, in international terms, one really has to look very hard to find something quite as unrepresentative as those arrangements. I make those remarks because I believe that they have some relevance in the context of this debate.

There is a need to make some other points about this legislation. The Deputy Prime Minister and Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen), in his second reading speech, made what amounts to the substantive points about this legislation. I think it is necessary to reflect on these again because we will find that, in the context of this debate, there is a tendency for some honourable members opposite-I do not say this about all honourable members opposite-to misrepresent. The important point that has to be established is that this is not some sudden surge and urge for Australia to get rid of all its historical connections or to do away with the monarchy but it is a recognition that Australia, as a collection of States and as a national government, can on a consensual basis come to an arrangement to change some of our existing arrangements with the United Kingdom.

It is important to emphasise that one of these pieces of legislation bears the title Australia (Request and Consent) Bill 1985 because this Bill results from the co-operation of the States, the Commonwealth and the United Kingdom Government. This legislation has been drafted clearly on a co-operative basis and it is important to emphasise that. It is also important to emphasise that we are now getting clarified in this legislation something that vexed the founding fathers. I know that honourable members opposite pay great attention to the question of history, sometimes, I believe, for their own sakes. A substantial debate raged between a group represented by Deakin, who was arguing that all State communications, in a sense, should go through the Governor-General before they were directed to the United Kingdom, and a group represented by Kingston, whose view was that it should be possible for the States themselves to have direct communications with the United Kingdom. In effect, the Kingston view won out in the draft Constitution of 1891. The Deakin position was not carried; the Kingston view was carried, which gave the capacity for States to have direct communications with the United Kingdom. The only problem with that has been that we have tended to find that the representations of the States have gone through the United Kingdom Ministers and not directly from the States as such.

This legislation removes that requirement. It will now be possible for the States to deal directly with the United Kingdom Government rather than to have to go through the Ministers. I think that is a maturing of the process. Clearly, this was an important matter for debate in the 1890s. It was a matter which both Kingston and Deakin had considerable debate about but which was resolved in Kingston's favour. I say to honourable members opposite that it is important to remember that they talked about the powers of the States to deal directly with the United Kingdom as distinct from going through the Commonwealth. We are now saying that that power can be clarified because, clearly, there was some debate about it in the 1890s. On these matters, the legislation will put an end to the present position under which the Queen is advised by United Kingdom Ministers, following recommendations by the State Premiers to the Foreign and Commonwealth Office of the United Kingdom Government. Instead, the Queen will be advised directly in each case by the Premier of the State concerned. That is a far more mature basis than the previous arrangement.

I think it is also necessary to say, with respect to the comments made by the honourable member for Warringah on the question of the developments in 1975, that there was at stake both a legal position and a convention position. One of the things to which conservative parties in Australia have often paid scant attention is the question of convention. Conventions have been something that they have carried around with them and have made great play of, but when it has been necessary to overturn them they have done so. History in Australia has shown a great willingness by people on the conservative side of politics to overturn conventions when it suits their short term political objectives. The Australian community recognises that substantially. I say to those opposite who talk in this place about the powers in terms of the Constitution and link those to the practice of politics that the practice in politics carries with it another requirement-that is, the issue of conventions in politics. The Australian community is now very sensitive about whether or not people in politics should obey some of those conventions. I must say that the conservative parties in Australia are getting a very bad reputation for overturning conventions. I hesitate to draw a parallel between their behaviour and what has happened in cricket in recent times but, clearly, the Australian community has begun to see that the conservatives are really willing to make a mockery of conventions when it suits them and the conservatives need to be reminded of this.

Another issue that needs to be addressed is the question of appeals to the Privy Council. This legislation removes that right. However, if there are any current appeals or if notices of appeal have been lodged, clearly they still stand. But it is also important for us, as Australians, to say that we should not have to have that avenue of appeal to the Privy Council. We are a nation in our own right; we have matured. The 1890s saw the great nationalist period in Australia when Australia sought to stand up for itself. Sadly in 1914-1918 it exhibited that it was able to. I say sadly because the circumstances were unfortunate. Australia has been able to demonstrate that it has matured as a country and it is very important that we recognise this. I am sure that the nationalists and people such as Henry Lawson would have been disturbed that it had taken us so long. Nevertheless, we have reached this point and it is important that we have reached this point.

What we are seeing here is really a set of arrangements which makes good sense in terms of Australia as a country. This legislation represents a set of arrangements which we on this side of the House recognise as being quite capable of being misrepresented by those who have a more short term objective in politics-which is simply to score points for the day. But the objective in politics is also one of having a longer term notion of what is good for a country. We on this side of the House believe that this legislation represents a statement about that. We also believe that appeals by people such as Bruce Ruxton of the Returned Services League in Victoria to what I would term the baser motives in the Australian community-the inherent Anglo-Saxon objectives that he turned into a racist argument-have to be identified. We are saying that we as a country can stand up for ourselves. We are a nation that now represents a wide variety of communities. We have the good fortune of having inherited a system that works but we are now bringing that system more up to date. We are saying, as a mature country, that we are about the business of conducting our affairs as a nation. That makes good sense but I also believe it is important that we recognise that in debate here. Accordingly, it is my pleasure to commend this legislation to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australia Bill makes four major changes to our relationship with the United Kingdom Parliament, Government and legal system. I must say in considering the Australia Bill and the Australia (Request and Consent) Bill that I accept the Government's declaration and that contained in the agreement of the State governments that nothing in this legislation will impair the position of the Queen as Queen of Australia. The first major change is that the Queen, instead of being formally advised on State matters by United Kingdom Ministers, will now be advised directly by State Premiers in her exercise of the power concerned. Secondly, the Bill will terminate any powers that might still remain in the United Kingdom Parliament to make laws having effect as part of Australian law. Thirdly, the Bill will remove the remaining avenues of appeal from Australian courts to the Privy Council, which obviously makes the High Court of Australia the final court of appeal for all Australian courts. Fourthly, for those few States which still retain imperial honours, arrangements have been made for those honours to be awarded by the Queen upon the advice of the Premier of the State concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: In considering the Australia Bill, which does cause us to reflect on our relationship with the United Kingdom, I find myself wondering about the extent of the knowledge of many Australians, particularly young Australians, of the institution now under discussion. All members of parliament would be aware of the frustration and general dissatisfaction that is permeating the community at present. Yet so many of the problems that Australia faces revolve around attitudes. Governments cannot legislate to correct all wrongs, or to correct all injustices. That is a lesson that this Government and its State Labor government counterparts have not yet learned. The real solutions to Australia's economic and social problems lie more in a change of attitudes than they do in legislation and regulation. Therefore, I believe that our institutions and all the traditions that brought them about need strengthening. Parliamentary democracy, executive government responsible to a house of elected representatives, an independent judiciary and a non-political Public Service are the basic institutions which guarantee Australians a freedom not experienced in most other parts of the world.

As we are looking at changing many of the institutions which link us with the United Kingdom, this is an opportune time to examine how this Government regards those institutions, bearing in mind that those institutions have been developed over decades-indeed, 200 years. Much of that time, if not all of it, has been dominated by the Judaeo-Christian ethic. I believe, as so many other members of this Parliament on both sides believe, that this Government's prime responsibility is to ensure the security and the standing of these institutions. It ought not weaken them by responding to the demands of strident minorities which will always chip away not just at the edges but at the central core of the institutions we value so much. Institutions are fragile things and need constant nourishment if they are to survive and flourish. Sadly, I find that young Australians do not have the knowledge of and often the respect for our institutions necessary to guarantee their prosperity.

One of the great difficulties for the present younger generation is its lack of moral certainty. If we look at the generations throughout the history of Australia we see that each seemed more or less, in general terms, to be pointed in the one direction. Of course the generation growing up before the First World War had to deal with that awful problem; then there was a reconstruction following that war and the next generation was tragically confronted with the Second World War. The next generation, together with the magnificent influx of immigrants, sought to deal with the problems confronting them and set about meeting the challenge of reconstruction. But the present young generation does not have that unanimity of view. There is not refuge for any individual in a commonly held set of values and goals. The one cry of the young generation, above all others, is for leadership.

It is true to say that this lack of forced values that the present generation is encountering often works to the individual's betterment because he or she is able to set goals and set about achieving them in a way that often their parents could not. But there are also tremendous risks and consequential challenges for legislators in dealing with the present state of moral uncertainty in our society. The leadership that this Government, or any government, can best provide is to work through the institutions already in place-institutions that often have been brought about by mistakes but more importantly by blood, sweat and tears. It is important for the Government to reiterate on every opportunity available that we do not seek to repeal or forget our past as we move into some brave new socialist world. There is every reason to be proud of Australia in the development of our institutions. Therefore it saddens me that Australian history, to cite just one example, is not a compulsory subject in the latter years of secondary schooling. Making Australian history optional to the extent that it is, in my view, weakens the young's appreciation of the structure of society and the institutions which guarantee so many of the rights and freedoms which this Government believes, as demonstrated by its Bill of Rights, need to be legislated for and need to be stated.

The point was made by many Opposition speakers during the debate on the Bill of Rights last week that we do have the institutions in place-common law, the Constitution and the Parliament-to guarantee the freedoms and rights of the majority. Yet this Government's action in passing that Bill of Rights through the lower House, and together with the Australian Democrats almost certainly through the Senate, weakens and bypasses those institutions. I do not for a moment suggest that the Australia Bill will in any way weaken the institutions I have mentioned, but, if we look at the sophisticated research carried out by Government into the attitudes of the young, the surveys show that the most commonly held goal is that of security. Security for the young is represented, as this survey bears out, by a family and employment. The security that the young seek to achieve at a time of tremendous technological and social change is guaranteed by the present Westminster system of parliament, an independent judiciary and a non-political Public Service.

For that reason I believe the Government ought to be stronger in so many of its dealings with those who would seek to undermine those guarantors of freedom. We have in Victoria at present an example of a government that is tolerating an open denigration of the rule of law; namely, by the Builders Labourers Federation, the Hospitals Employees Federation and the railways union. This Parliament, together with the State Parliament, to protect the rule of law which the BLF, to choose one of the three as an example, openly challenges, must pass legislation to deregister that union. The Federal Government and the State Government are working through the institution of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and it is giving the BLF through that slow, inefficient process the opportunity to continue on its lawless way. Why does this Parliament seek to play a game with rules which have long been thrown out the window by the BLF? This Government, supported by the State Government of Victoria, must bite the bullet and pass legislation through this Parliament which will put an end to the destruction by the BLF not just of institutions but of attitudes throughout the community. No government can tolerate the campaign of war and hatred by the BLF against the established order.

In conclusion, I say again that the Australia Bill does much to reinforce our pride in Australia. However, at a time of uncertainty and growing dissatisfaction with the workings of the Parliament throughout the community, I believe the duty of this Government-as it will be the duty of the following government-is to shore up and to strengthen the institutions available.

DEBATE.TITLE: OBJECTIVES, ACHIEVEMENTS AND PRIORITIES IN ENVIRONMENT, CONSERVATION AND HERITAGE AND STATE OF THE ENVIRONMENT IN AUSTRALIA 1985

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cohen The Hon B.

TALKER.NAME: Mr COHEN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-It is with great pleasure that I present to the House two important reports-`The Objectives, Achievements and Priorities in Environment, Conservation and Heritage' and `The State of the Environment in Australia 1985'. It is our intention that in the future an annual state of the environment report will be made to the Parliament. This initial report is therefore a landmark in environmentl monitoring and planning.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me say at the outset that I believe the Hawke Government has the proudest record in protecting and preserving Australia's environment of any government in Australian history. It has been the practice of some of our critics to denigrate that effort because anything less than perfection is unacceptable. Comparisons have been made between the record of this Government and the Whitlam Government, but the Fraser Government is rarely mentioned. It is a common practice to look back with nostalgia to the past and imagine that all was perfect then. The Whitlam Government had a great record on the environment but history will show that so too has this Government.

Let me remind the House of just what has been achieved in the short space of 2 1/2 years. The first legislative action of the Hawke Government, and it was with great pleasure that I introduced the Bill, was to introduce the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act 1983 which ultimately led to preventing construction of the Gordon below Franklin dam in the south-west Tasmanian wilderness area. This historic legislation, introduced to fulfil Australia's international obligation as a signatory to the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation Convention for the Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage, was hailed internationally as a landmark in preserving places and sites of unique natural beauty. Following the narrow High Court of Australia decision in our favour the Government negotiated a compensation package with the Tasmanian Government totalling almost $300m. The Commonwealth and Tasmanian governments have put in place joint management arrangements for the protection and management of the Tasmanian world heritage area. The arrangement consists of a ministerial council, standing committee of officials and a consultative committee. The Commonwealth has provided $2m this financial year and will provide a further $2m in 1986-87.

In 1975 the Whitlam Government passed the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act and the Fraser Government, to its credit, managed to obtain the co-operation of the Queensland Government to make the park a reality. However, by the time we came to office only 14 per cent of the Great Barrier Reef region had been incorporated within the park. After approximately 18 months this Government had increased that figure to 98.5 per cent. Effectively the whole of the region is now within the park making it the greatest marine park in the world-great not only because of its size but because it contains the most complex coral reef ecosystem anywhere in the world. At the same time the Government introduced regulations to prohibit oil drilling in those parts of the region not included in the park. This ensures that oil drilling cannot occur anywhere within the Great Barrier Reef region. We are also working to introduce legislation to control off-shore developments in any zoned section of the marine park and have commenced major funding into research on the crown of thorns starfish.

It has been one of the complaints of people who have been to the Barrier Reef, particularly those from overseas, that because of weather conditions they have often not been able to get out to the reef itself. The provision of off-shore developments on the reef will make it easier for people to visit it and spend time there. For those who cannot make it because of weather conditions or because of the cost, the Commonwealth and the State Government are developing the Great Barrier Reef wonderland complex on the mainland at Townsville as a bicentennial project. I pay tribute to the work of the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay), who has been so assiduous in promoting this project. There can be few greater conservation achievements than the establishment of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park.

Australia has five areas on the world heritage list. They are: Lord Howe Island, the Willandra Lakes Region, Western Tasmania Wilderness National Parks, Great Barrier Reef Marine Park and Kakadu National Park. The latter was established by the Fraser Government but in February 1984 the Hawke Government declared stage II which more than doubled the size of the park. The Government intends to enlarge the park even further. During the past 2 1/2 years there has been a considerable upgrading of the facilities in Kakadu to the point where it is now one of the finest parks in the world. More is still to be done but during the last three Budgets a total of $15m has been spent, with much more upgrading planned for the future. For many years after the great battle to save Fraser Island a much quieter but no less intense battle was fought to stop sand mining on Moreton Island. In February 1984 the Government was able to announce that there would be no mining on Moreton Island.

It is not my intention to read out all the environment achievements of the Government. They are all in the report. However, I would like to mention briefly a few more to illustrate the depth and breadth of what has been done during a relatively short period in government. One of the truly great pieces of environment legislation introduced by the Whitlam Government was the Australian Heritage Commission Act which established the body to oversee the Register of the National Estate and to provide funding and guidance for its protection and preservation. Ten years on, we are reviewing this legislation through a process of community participation. The aim of the review is to examine the scope of the Commonwealth's role in the conservation of the National Estate. A few days ago, as part of this review, a major seminar was held in Canberra to enable the wide variety of interests concerned about the National Estate to discuss some of the problems that have arisen with the processes of nomination and listing in recent years. I opened that seminar but had to leave to fly to Adelaide to attend the historic ministerial meeting on the Murray-Darling basin. The initiatives which flow from that meeting of four Labor governments have provided a framework for the conservation and development of this major region.

During our time in office we have doubled funding to the Australian Heritage Commission enabling it to increase its information and research activities. More remains to be done. I am aware that there is still a need for increased staff and facilities to catch up with much of the backlog of work that accumulated during the Fraser Government's period in office. Although the real level of expenditure through the National Estate grants program has been maintained by this Government it is still below the level achieved in the 1975-76 Budget, if one excludes the very considerable funding provided through the community employment program. The report mentions a figure of $12m provided for heritage projects throughout Australia in 1983-84 under the CEP. However, more recent figures provided to me would put that figure at over $15m.

Another innovation introduced by this Government to protect areas of national heritage significance was the provision of income tax concessions to those who make donations of property of national heritage significance to the National Trust. Another Whitlam Government initiative was the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 that introduced into Australia the concept of environmental impact statements and public inquiries into matters of significant national importance. The latter led to the inquiries into Fraser Island and uranium mining. The Government has been reviewing this legislation to improve the effectiveness of the Act and to increase public participation in the assessment of projects being examined under its administrative procedures. I expect to be able to make a statement soon about the introduction of legislation to give effect to the Government's review.

In the area of planning and management we have tabled and later endorsed the national conservation strategy. The plan for a strategy was initiated by the Fraser Government and brought to fruition under the excellent guidance of Sir Rupert Myers. To quote the report of the interim consultative committee, the endorsement implies agreement with the objectives and strategic principles of the national conservation strategy and a willingness, in principle, to implement the priority national actions, in co-operation with development and conservation interests, taking into account Australia's federal, constitutional, legislative and administrative framework, and the general economic climate.

A test of the community's desire to protect and conserve our environment will be determined by our willingness to implement the national conservations strategy and to not just pay lip service to its goals and objectives.

There can be few more important areas for action than in the area of environmental pollution and contamination. Although much of the responsibility for this problem lies with the States and Territory governments the Commonwealth is playing a leading role in cleaning up the mess. We have ratified the Convention on the Prevention of Marine Pollution by Dumping of Wastes and Other Matter-commonly known as the London Dumping Convention-and have proclaimed the Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Act 1981 which regulates the dumping and incineration of wastes at sea. We have also announced the intention to introduce a national notification and assessment scheme for chemicals and completed the first stage of compilation of an Australian inventory of existing chemicals. Also an Environment Contaminants Division has been established within my Department.

Last Tuesday, I was in Melbourne to open a three-day national conference-organised by my Department, together with the Melbourne and Metropolitan Board of Works-entitled National Strategies for Managing Hazardous Waste. I pay particular tribute today to the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Milton), who is in the chamber, and who was unfortunately unable to attend that conference, at which he was to chair a meeting. He is, of course, the Chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation. He has done a wonderful job. I am sorry that he was not able to honour us with his presence at that meeting. He was kept in by the Whip. It has been my view-and I answered this point today in replying to a question by the honourable member for Riverina-Darling (Mr Hicks)-that for too long the community has pretended, ostrich-like, that if nothing were done about the increasing accumulation of hazardous waste it would somehow go away. Hazardous waste is one of those intractable problems on which the whole community must work together to resolve. Burning waste at sea, or in the cities where the waste is mostly located, transportation overseas or to outback areas in Australia, or simply doing nothing and allowing it to stockpile, all have their good and bad points. There is no perfect solution. From a range of alternatives one must be chosen. There is no point in people criticising each alternative separately and saying how bad that may be. We must all play a part in finding the best of a not very attractive range of alternatives.

One of the most important initiatives introduced by the Whitlam Government was the funding of voluntary conservation groups. The view taken by the then Minister for the Environment, Dr Moss Cass, was that groups who were monitoring the environment on a voluntary basis and acting as a watchdog for the whole community were incapable of competing with the vast resources available to the Government and the private sector. If they were to be able to do a valuable job effectively, the community through its government should provide them with some resources. It was argued that a democracy only works efficiently if competing interests have some level of equality in their access to resources. I think my very good friend Ralph Nader played a very important role in getting this message over to the community. It was with great pride that I was able to help to bring him here on three separate occasions. It was obvious that there was no way that full equality could ever be achieved between, say, a large multinational enterprise or a government and a voluntary conservation group, but some of the imbalance could be redressed.

When the Whitlam Government went out of office it had appropriated $450,000 for the groups for 1975-76. The Fraser Government reduced that to $390,000 and by the time it left office 7 1/2 years later it had been further reduced to $350,000 annually. The result was to reduce dramatically the value in real terms. When in opposition the Labor Party made a commitment to increase the level of funding to that which prevailed in the 1975-76 Budget. This year the voluntary conservation groups will get $945,000, an increase in only three years of about 270 per cent, which confirms our commitment. The grants were announced last weekend.

There has been a quite significant change in the make-up of the voluntary conservation groups during the past decade. Many new groups have emerged both at a national and regional level and the activities and work load of groups vary enormously. Other factors that need to be taken into account are the contribution of State governments and the distance factor. By the latter I refer to the type of problems faced by conservation groups in, say, Western Australia and the Northern Territory. To get to a conference held in the eastern States or to travel to the Kimberlys obviously is a severe strain on the resources of those bodies. I have taken this into account by giving those groups significant increases over the past three years.

TALK.START.PARA: —And they respect this.

—I thank the honourable member for Stirling. He has been so co-operative in this matter. Regrettably the conservative State governments now, and in the past, have provided virtually no funds at all for voluntary conservation groups. This is hardly surprising in view of their general antagonism to these bodies and their ideals. But this is not a partisan matter. All States should do more. Let me make it perfectly clear that we expect all State governments to meet their proper share of support for the voluntary conservation movement. However, a 270 per cent increase by the Commonwealth in three years is in my view not a bad effort.

SPEECH.PARA: There have been many other achievements by the Hawke Government in the short space of 2 1/2 years, including establishing a National Kangaroo Monitoring Unit in the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service and a Kangaroo Advisory Committee. The Committee represents a broad range of community groups including scientists, conservationists, farmers, governments and industry, and advises me on management, export, research and public information. We have also provided through the Commonwealth employment program about $30m in support of the national tree program, and we have rescinded the provision of taxation incentives for land clearing. Ours is a record of which any government can be proud and, as I said before, one that compares more than favourably with the record of any of its predecessors. However, it is not our intention to rest on our laurels, because much more needs to be done.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.

—I do not deny it. The job will never be completed. The one, in fact virtually the only, criticism of this Government's environment and conservation record is the perceived failure to stop the building of the road through the Greater Daintree Forest from Cape Tribulation to Bloomfield. In a number of speeches, the most recent being my address to the National Environment Law Symposium in Hobart on 8 November 1985, I detailed fully the reasons why we did not invoke the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act. The main reason was very simple. On legal advice from the Attorney-General it would not have worked. A long drawn out court case with the Queensland Government would have saved not one tree in the rainforest and would have made it impossible for the two governments to work together towards protecting, not just the area where the road has been built, but the hundreds of thousands of hectares of tropical rainforest still yet untouched. I am aware that sections of the media and some environmentalists love the `stop the road' or `stop the dam' type of confrontation, but knowledgeable scientists have continued to point out that the rainforest through which that road runs, important as it is, is by no means the most important scientifically or environmentally. What is important is that a proper plan of management for the whole of the remaining wet tropical rainforests must be worked out with the Queensland Government and a plan implemented that will ensure Queensland's future timber needs, guarantee employment for those who presently work in the timber industry, and encourage people in the region to see the rainforests as a tourist attraction on a par with the Great Barrier Reef and requiring similar protection and conservation.

SPEECH.PARA: May I say that I am encouraged by a discernible shift in opinion in recent weeks by articles written by John Larkin and Greg Borschman in the Age and by the excellent editorial in the Canberra Times on 12 November 1985. Those two papers have been my most severe critics so it has been heartwarming to find that both have now recognised that maybe, just maybe, there is something in the non-confrontationist approach.

From day one of the Hawke Government I have held the view that the protection of Australia's forests will be the major environmental issue of the 1980s, but that it can be achieved only by co-operation between the States and the Commonwealth. With this in mind I convened a seminar in Cairns in February last year which led to a working group consisting of all the interested parties-government, adacemics, the timber industry, the unions and conservationists. The working group provided me with an excellent report which is shortly to be considered by Cabinet.

Developing a national rainforest policy and implementing it in consultation with the States will therefore be a major priority for the Government as it continues to tackle the task of conserving our natural resources. The report `Objectives, Achievements and Priorities' sets out in some detail what we have done, where we are going and how we hope to get there. It places some stress on the need to incorporate environmental considerations in government decision making, the importance of environmental education for the community and the need to ensure active and informed public participation in the protection and use of our environment.

The second report, `The State of the Environment in Australia 1985', has been prepared to provide a picture of the Australian environment as it presently exists, to assess some of the changes that have taken place since European settlement, and to identify trends, resource conflicts and address major emerging issues. It outlines briefly the distribution and current use of environmental resources, considers pressures from human activities and problems which arise from them, and lists major events affecting the condition of our natural resources. It lists, in the annex of the report, some of the major environmental events which have taken place in Australia in the last 20 years. I seek leave to have the annex incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report establishes a bench-mark from which future environmental changes can be reported and indicates the environmental conditions that might be expected without further improvement in planning and management. It provides an information base to assist in the development of policies to deal with current and emerging environmental problems.

SPEECH.PARA: Before summarising the main findings of the report I would like to note that the volume being tabled today will be supplemented by an illustrated version with many colour photographs depicting the uniqueness and fragility of the Australian environment and the effects and severity of pollution and resource mismanagement. The illustrated version and a source book containing detailed statistical data and discussion of management issues are expected to be available in February 1986. The report indicates the growth of public interest in the environment since the 1960s and the responses of governments. Given our constitutional basis, it draws attention to the importance of Commonwealth-State co-operation and the mechanisms which have been developed for this purpose.

The report responds to the 1981 report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation and to the calls from the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development and the United Nations environment program for all countries to report annually on the state of their environment. It considers the main sectors of the environment-land, inland waters, air, forests and woodlands, flora and fauna, protected areas and the National Estate, and the coastal zone. Each sector contains information on one or two selected major issues.

The information provided in the report is sobering. Land degradation is widespread and increasing. Many river systems, wetlands and underground water resources are severely degraded. Air pollution in most capital and major industrial cities periodically exceeds the goals recommended by the World Health Organisation and the National Health and Medical Research Council. Only about one-third of Australia's tree cover at the time of European settlement remains. Significant sections of coastal lands have been extensively modified by inadequately controlled development. Clearly the improvement in this situation is not something which can be done by governments alone. All sections of the community must be involved.

The report concludes that despite major achievements during the last 15 years, much remains to be done to maintain and enhance environmental quality in Australia, while allowing development to continue to provide for the needs of society. Greater initiative, commitment and co-operation between the community and all levels of government to environmental matters are needed. It is also necessary for greater emphasis to be given to the development of anticipatory policies designed to prevent future problems, rather than application of merely curative policies.

The Government endorses that view. By tabling today not only the report on the state of our environment but also the Government's statement of its objectives, achievement and priorities in environment and conservation, I place on record this Government's proud commitment and its intentions for the future environmental protection of Australia.
