TALK.START.PARA: —by leave- Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen) was extolling the virtues of the Government's program in the area of environmental management over the last three years. Listening to him rather reminded me of the medieval town-crier who went from street to street ringing his bell in the desperate hope that people would listen. But the difference between the Minister and the town-crier no doubt rests on the fact that if the town-crier did not tell the full truth he was likely to cop a pile of rubbish dropped on him by some irate hausfrau above.
—Possibly worse.

—Or possibly worse, as the Minister so rightly points out. But, of course, we live in more pleasant times. The Minister, because he has the privilege of the House and because he is the Minister, has the ability to gild the lily as he thinks fit. I think it is worth pointing out that the Opposition supports, without reservation, the concept of an annual environmental report which is to be tabled in the House, provided that that report contains the expressed views of the respective State governments which, as the Minister rightly pointed out on a number of occasions, have at least a joint responsibility with the Commonwealth to ensure that the environment and the conservation of Australia's natural resources will be maintained at an adequate standard to be passed on to succeeding generations.

SPEECH.PARA: However, this Government has a tendency, of which we are well aware, when it suits its so-called principles, to exert the primacy of Federal legislation, as it did in the Tasmanian dam situation, while at the same time it is able to demonstrate, as with the Queensland rainforest situation, a peculiar difference of opinion. In all fairness, the Opposition parties have been totally consistent on this point. We have always believed that land management is a State responsibility primarily and that the Commonwealth is there to support the national objectives by the provision of adequate support, financial assistance and so forth, but that the primary decision-making rests with the State. Therefore, it was not without expectation on my part that the Minister started with great praise of the fact that his Government, soon after its election, introduced the World Heritage (Properties Conservation) Act 1983, which ultimately led to preventing the construction of the Gordon below Franklin Dam in South West Tasmania.

Before this country has the opportunity to forget those very difficult days of early 1983, I remind the House that we had a very divided nation on this issue. It was divided because people on both sides believed that they were right. In that atmosphere the Australian Labor Party, then in Federal opposition, sought the opportunity to make hay in a very difficult environmental situation politically. It did that with some success. There is no doubt in my mind that perhaps 2 or 3 per cent of the Australian electorate was influenced in a primary sense by the events which were taking place in Tasmania.

But in politics, as in life generally, one cannot escape having to face realities and principles. The Opposition parties, whilst we lost that election, believe that much could have been achieved in that environment had it been possible to act earlier and to get some form of agreement between the Commonwealth and the State. But, as I have said, because of the fundamental divisions of opinion, particularly in Tasmania but throughout the Commonwealth, we really reached the situation of the issue becoming a major plank of the policies of the then Opposition which was successful in that regard. But much of the support that the then Opposition won on that particular case has quite clearly dissipated over the years. I was interested to note an address by the Minister-in Melbourne, I think it was-a week or so ago, in which he made a statement to the effect that the politics of the environmental movement should not be overstated, and that its members do not really have the political clout that some of them would like to have. Be that as it may, as I said, they have also been living on the history of 1983 and perhaps to an extent which is not totally justified. But the Minister was right in observing in relation to this annual report that there is no question that the level of interest in environmental issues around Australia in the population at large is greater today than it has probably ever been, certainly in my lifetime. This is a good thing, provided, again, that it is not taken to extremes and that people are not tending to put emotion ahead of reality, forgetting the principle that I mentioned earlier-that in life one has to not only to live with the principles but also try to live with the results of one's decisions. After all, the economy has to proceed, but it has to be developed in the context of the Australian conservation strategy to ensure that we have the ability to conserve our environment while, at the same time, being able to pass it on to others and to make a living for present and succeeding Australian generations.

The second report which was tabled by the Minister is somewhat more significant politically, perhaps, than the first. It is rather interestingly titled `Objectives, Achievements and Priorities in Environment, Conservation and Heritage.' It is almost the sort of document that one would expect to see a government come out with about a month before an election. Here we are, late in November, and thank heavens we are not likely to be having one in December again-not this year, anyway; perhaps next year. But it is essentially a political document. I just wonder how many trees were cut down under the responsibility of the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment-I see that he suggests it was one; I think that it would be a lot more than that-to pay for this particular document, which, as I said, will no doubt find its way into schools and institutions around Australia. But it is nothing more than a paean of the alleged virtues of the Hawke Government in the environmental conservation area.

The Minister, in his statement, tended to ignore a lot of the realities and-as is his right in these situations-to gild the lily somewhat. He tended to emphasise, for example, that it was the Whitlam Government which apparently set the foundations of modern environmental concern in Australia. I would have to say that I would contest that. There is absolutely no doubt in my mind that there were very great achievements in the Fraser years. There are too many people in this country who find it cheap political mileage to score off someone who is no longer able to defend himself, or his record in public and certainly not in this place. As far as the environmental record is concerned, I will certainly defend that of the Fraser Government, because it was a record second to none.

I think that I should take this opportunity to emphasise it for what it was. It was the Fraser Government which brought in the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act to protect both our own wildlife as well as international wildlife. It also brought in the Environmental Protection (Sea Dumping) Act. Neither of those Acts was proclaimed at that stage. That was left to the succeeding Hawke Government. Nevertheless, they were initiated and passed by this Parliament during that period. In world heritage context, all five world heritage listings were in fact those of the Fraser Government, including that of South West Tasmania-something which people tend to ignore. The Great Barrier Reef Marine Park, it is true, was initiated by the Whitlam Government in 1975, but the difficult negotiations were carried through during the period of the Fraser Government through his own personal involvement as well as that of his Ministers. Leading out of that, most of the zoning plan work was commenced-although, as the Minister quite rightly points out, it was carried through to ultimate fruition during his period of administration. But when one reads the Minister's statement, there is a tendency to assume that, somehow or other, in 1975 the Whitlam Government passed a whole raft of legislation of an environmental nature and then there was more or less a period of non-activity for nearly eight years before the Hawke Government came into place. I simply must put on record that that is not correct.

In addition to the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park, to which I have just referred, the Fraser Government also supported the world conservation strategy. It is worth pointing out that it was from the world conservation strategy that the Australian conservation strategy was initiated. Again, all the basic fundamental work was done during that period, although the Australian conservation strategy conference, which was initiated by the current Government some two years ago, led to the document in its present form. Again, it is worth pointing out that it was the coalition parties two years ago that publicly announced our support for the Australian conservation strategy, a long time before the Labor Government did so. Our policy at the last Federal election was based primarily on that report. Those were the objectives to which all our policy initiatives were directed. I take great pride in that fact because that strategy marked the first time in Australia's modern history that we have been able to get a disparate group of people from all sectors of the community-mining, primary industry, agriculture and so forth-to agree with the environmental movement on the basic principles as to how Australia should be developed in the future and its resources protected for future generations. All who were involved in that conference, especially the chairman, Professor Myers, have, as the Minister rightly pointed out, every reason to be thoroughly satisfied with what they have done. I trust that the present Government and future governments will make sure that their environment and conservation strategies are in line with those objectives.

In addition, the Fraser Government prevented sandmining on Fraser Island, and I understand the Liberal Party in Queensland also supports the proposition that there should not be sandmining on Moreton Island. The Fraser Government also introduced the Whale Protection Act 1980 which was a trail-blazing piece of legislation for Australia. My final point in terms of the Fraser record, which by no means is meant to be a demonstration of the totality of that effort, is that the Fraser Government also established the national tree program. I would like to say something about that because I think that the Government's current policy in terms of its refusal to provide tax incentives for the funding of forestry is a contradiction of what that Government claims to be all about. It is also worth pointing out that the Minister in his statement has tended to emphasise the glories of environmental policies conducted by State Labor governments. The Minister is a citizen of New South Wales, as I am; but, unlike him, I live in Sydney. It is a matter of great concern to me and to millions of other Australians, especially those living in Sydney, to see the pollution of New South Wales beaches. The Wran Government has been in place for some 10 years and its environmental policies obviously have been directed at priorities elsewhere, but it is quite clear that that Government has been totally lacking in any capacity to control what is a growing social problem around Sydney. There is virtually not a beach one can safely take one's children to at a weekend without the prospect of swimming with all sorts of unwelcome guests on the water as well. These elements are worth noting.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's where you get your tan from.

—I do not think my tan is quite as good as the Minister's. As the Minister emphasised last week, he is particularly concerned about a national strategy for pollution control and so on. It is worth noting that the Western Australian Government is currently looking at a feasibility study for the construction of an incinerator-type facility in the Kalgoorlie region. I think that the central desert area of Australia would be ideal. I would prefer to see something in the area of Broken Hill, especially because that is closer to the central industrial areas of Australia than Western Australia. Nevertheless, these are issues to be considered because we cannot depend indefinitely on using the Vulcanus, which is the European ship that comes out here most infrequently, to burn off Australian chemical effluents and so forth. The real problem is that small chemical companies tend not to be able to afford such facilities and thus we have to look elsewhere.
—And it cannot burn off solids;

—It cannot burn off solids; that is a good point. I see no reference in the Minister's statement or in `The State of the Environment in Australia 1985' report to the devastation of bushfires but I trust it is there somewhere. As the Minister is aware, the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation conducted a far-reaching and, as I understand it, the first report ever tabled in this Parliament by a committee of the Parliament into what I believe to be a serious environmental and conservation problem. Again, there is no word of this matter in the Minister's statement. I am concerned because again it demonstrates the tendency for Australians to imagine that, somehow or other, bushfires happen in January, February and March and can be ignored for the remaining nine months of the year. We can do this at our peril. We have seen in recent years, especially from the massive human and property losses in the Ash Wednesday fires a few years ago, that this country is very prone to bush fires. The Government must take a closer interest in these matters, especially in the regions around the Australian Capital Territory.

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of conservation programs generally, the Minister emphasised a need for closer community involvement. Of course, the Opposition totally supports that point. But, again, if we want to involve a community, and sections of the community which are vitally concerned with environmental protection while at the same time being able to make a living from the environment-such as farmers, for example-clearly, effective tree planting schemes, water conservation, soil conservation and so forth are matters of very great importance. In this area the Government's record again leaves much to be desired.

We have heard in recent days statements about four governments reaching an historic agreement in terms of the Murray-Darling river system, which represents possibly Australia's major environmental problem and is certainly most relevant to the people of South Australia, who have the often odious pleasure-if it is that-of drinking the water from the river system. It has two major problems. There is turbidity on the one hand, which generates essentially in the upper reaches of the Darling River, and salinity, on the other hand, which tends to come from the Murray. It is not insignificant that this meeting, which has been heralded by the Minister as being so significant, held only last week, I think on 16 November, was obviously timed to meet the election requirements of the South Australian Government.

Again, a significant point is this: All the governments represented at that conference were Labor governments. The point of which I think the Minister needs to take particular note is that tributaries of the Darling River happen to start in central Queensland and southern Queensland. Apparently, nobody invited the Queensland Government to come to that conference.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was invited.

—I am delighted to hear that because, quite clearly, in the longer term there will be a need to involve five governments, not four, in the future management of that area. There is a tendency, as demonstrated by this Government, to try to blame the Queensland Government for all sorts of things, whether it be lack of co-operation in the construction of adequate facilities on the Barrier Reef or the problems of the rainforests in north Queensland and so forth. People often fail to understand the reality that Queensland also has its own problems and its own priorities and that these issues have to be discussed at great length on both sides to get an adequate answer. I am sure that the Queensland Government, if it were approached in the right way, would be prepared to consider the realities of the River Murray situation.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is also worth noting that the Government announced last week that in its generosity it is going to put forward another $1m in 1986-87. That announcement was made by Senator Evans. It should be put on record that that announcement was effectively already made, because the Australian Water Research Advisory Council had made that recommendation. Here we are effectively having a Minister, again for purely short term political reasons in terms of the South Australian election, re-announcing the most generous gesture of providing $1m for the upgrading and co-ordination program for water and water related research for the Murray- Darling basin. I hasten to add that the Government will not get very far with $1m when we consider that size of the problem.

The final report on the national conservation strategy for Australia emphasised the problems of the river. It was stated, for example, that individual projects which should be considered include tree establishment programs along key sections of the river banks for soil erosion control, revegetation of selected ground water recharge sites, rehabilitation of salt affected areas, reduction of sewage flows into the rivers, restoration of vegetation along river banks, tree establishment irrigation areas, tree conservation establishment for wildlife habitat and enhancement of river red gum forests on river banks. Those recommendations are very similar indeed to those which were developed by the Opposition's joint committee, which I set up two years ago with the full co-operation of both the National and Liberal parties in South Australia, Victoria, New South Wales and, of course, this Parliament. We believed then, as we still do now, that the River Murray-Darling basin is the most important agricultural region in Australia. Although it occupies only one-seventh of the continent, it contains approximately one-quarter of the nation's cattle herd, one-half of the crop land and three-quarters of the irrigated areas. Its natural resources, directly and indirectly, support some two million people and contribute primary and secondary production estimated to be excess of $10,000m per year.

It is in that context that the committee recommended the formation of the River Murray Council of Ministers, and I am pleased to see that the Government has accepted that recommendation, albeit coming from a joint Opposition committee. Clearly, until we can get political agreement on these issues we will not be able to reach a situation where the experts will feel that they have either the financial or the political support that they obviously need. The River Murray Council of Ministers, comprises representatives from all signatories to the River Murray Agreement. As I have said, I hope that I will see the day when Queensland will also be such a signatory.

We also recommended that the River Murray Commission draft a management plan with the co-operation of State and local authorities; that the implementation of an agreed management plan be co-ordinated by the River Murray Commission over 25 years in five-year stages; that the River Murray Commission be consulted on all programs which affect the region; and that there be a co-ordinated soil conservation program over 25 years to be developed to meet identified reclamation, waterlogging and salinity problems found in the dry and irrigated areas of the basin. We recommended direct government financial assistance to individual farmers to encourage improved management efficiency while considering the need to construct additional water storages, the diverting of saline water from the valley and the upgrading of the Menindee Lakes storage system.

We recommended the protection of the ecological welfare of the River Murray by ensuring adequate water is provided to maintain the unique red gum forests, native fisheries, ibis and other bird rookeries. We recommended the integration of a major tree planting and regeneration program into any desalination and soil conservation programs and the encouragement of local governments and farmers to plant appropriate species. We recommended the construction of off-river municipal sewage disposal and treatment plants to minimise the damaging effects of nutrient flow into the river. Finally, we recommended that the River Murray Commission should conduct an extensive public awarness campaign at the national level with the assistance of State authorities, community groups, schools and organisations such as the River Murray League.

All these issues are important because over a million people depend on that river. It is of enormous ecological importance to southern Australia in particular, and the Government, despite all the talk and all the Press releases over the last three years, has not demonstrated either the ability to get its act together in this area or the willingness to put adequate funding into that program.

I wish to relate to another issue raised by the Minister in his statement, that is, the question of Kakadu. Again, the Kakadu National Park was initiated by the Fraser Government but, in November 1983, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) announced a $36m accelerated expenditure over the next six years. That program was brought in at a time when it was necessary to have a political smokescreen because of the intense divisions which were clearly evident publicly within the Australian Labor Party on the question of uranium mining. But I think it is significant that, since 1983, there has been virtual silence on what is happening in Kakadu. The Minister told us today: `Do not worry. Everything is all right. Money is being spent'. I was in the park last June and I have to say that the road situation leaves much to be desired. I was appalled at the level of maintenance and the level of protection being given in certain areas of the park. People who apparently have had commercial access to certain waterways and so forth have, I am led to believe, on the basis of advice given to me by the person taking me around, put nothing back into the park. There is no financial requirement for them to make a commitment to the park, yet the Australian taxpayer is expected to carry virtually the entire load.

The clear evidence is therefore this: We need to build up a major tourist access to Kakadu, which is of tremendous importance in terms of world environmental interest as well as economic interest to the Northern Territory. The simple fact of the matter is that at this stage there is only one motel in the entire national park where people can stay. Clearly, therefore, a lot more needs to be done in that area. I get a little tired of hearing the Minister and other people in the Government continually waxing eloquent about the beauties of Kakadu when the simple reality is that the $36m promised in November 1983 has not been forthcoming. I doubt that it will be because it was initiated at the time as nothing more than a smokescreen for this Government.

I refer also to another issue which is still very much in the pot-the Daintree forest. In August 1984 there was a considerable amount of concern within the environment movement in relation to north Queensland and the construction of roads through the forest and so forth. I put forward to the Government in a Press release on 5 August 1984 a number of proposals based on the principle that the Federal Government, in discussions with the Queensland Government, should develop firstly a long term regional plan for the Daintree area, secondly, improve management of the Daintree National Park, and thirdly, rationalise park boundaries. These proposals would not only protect the remaining rainforest but also would assist in the development of a tourist industry based on the Daintree National Park, which is on the doorstep of the Great Barrier Reef and within easy access of the Cairns international airport and the coastal island resorts further south. Since then the sugar cane industry has gone into serious economic decline and clearly the issue is even more important today than it was then. North Queensland obviously needs all the support it can get from the Commonwealth Government to enable the development of a sophisticated tourist industry based on the conservation of as much as possible of its very rare forest areas.

The Minister has tended over the years-certainly since August of last year-to try to side- step this issue. As I said at the beginning of my address, he was quite happy to use Commonwealth powers in relation to Tasmania because there was an election in the offing but he is not prepared even to countenance such a situation now. Nor should he. However, it is inconsistent with the Government's policy-not ours-that he is not prepared to countenance such a situation because he is scared of the Queensland Government. Clearly he was not scared of the Tasmanian Government. When one is in opposition there are occasions when one tends to have much more power of the spoken word than perhaps one is prepared to demonstrate in one's mental approach to these issues.

There is a lot yet to be done in terms of the environment. The Minister has emphasised that point and I certainly second his views. While we want to see a continuation of programs which are effective, I am concerned about the public disagreements which we have had in this House and elsewhere in regard to the Tasmanian woodchip industry. As an example we have the comments made by the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) on the one hand and my colleague the Minister for Arts, Heritage and the Environment on the other and the fact that there have been differences of opinion and divisions within the Caucus committee structure. On this issue at least the Government and the Opposition are as one: The development of those forests must be carried out in a manner consistent with long term environmental protection while ensuring the retention of the significant number of jobs in the timber industry. I think that to one extent or another about one third of the entire economy of Tasmania is related to that industry. These are obviously very important issues. I would hope that if in future years there is a need to renegotiate border changes in terms of the South West National Park and the World Heritage area in particular, these matters can be discussed in a satisfactory manner in the context of the machinery which has been established with the agreement of both the Tasmanian and the Commonwealth governments.

Finally, I want to refer to the national tree program. Much has been said about this program, and I have to say in all honesty that I think that a great gap has been left between words and actions. The fact of the matter is that Australia remains to this day a country which is very sparsely covered with growth. We have tended over succeeding generations to cut down without any real control over the future problems we create in terms of soil erosion, water pollution and conservation matters generally. The activities of the Government in relation to the national tree program are not adequate. The decision which this Government took, for example, to make farmers claim tax deductibility on conservation matters over five years instead of over one year, which was the case before, is quite clearly an act which will destroy even greater areas of Australia because many farmers, especially as a result of drought, are at the margin in financial terms. They are now being put in a position in which they will have neither the financial resources nor the physical resources to carry out an appropriate tree program as they should. It was for that reason that the coalition parties at the last election emphasised the need to have a rural tree regeneration program on a national basis and emphasised that it should be integrated with the national soil and water conservation programs. We offered to assist private land holders to maintain native tree cover, especially in areas which had been excessively cleared or which suffered from soil erosion. We believe that there is a need to develop with the States a rural extension program to inform rural communities on the advantages of increasing tree and regeneration cover.

The Minister also emphasised that $30m was being applied to this area. He knows, as I know, that that is not true. What he is talking about is that, in terms of an unemployment program, that much money is being provided as wages and various supports. How many trees will be grown and where they will be grown are questions which I am particularly interested in. I think we have some time to wait before we will see an adequate result to that program. The Opposition believes that there is a definite need for an environment corps to be established, so that young people who suffer the very real problems of long term unemployment can be given the opportunity of training and being involved in a major outdoor activity which will be of great significance to this generation and future generations of Australians. It is by linking the available human resources with the need to develop a wider appreciation of humanity's role in the total development and protection of nature that we will be able to achieve a lasting environment for future generations of Australians.

DEBATE.TITLE: PETROLEUM REVENUE BILL 1985[COGNATE BILL:EXCISE TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 16 October, on motion by Mr Barry Jones:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: — Order! I understand it is the wish of the House to debate order of the day No. 3, the Petroleum Revenue Bill, concurrently with order of the day No. 4, the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2). There being no objection, the Chair will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Petroleum Revenue Bill 1985 and cognate Bill will enable the Government to forgo the crude oil levy excise where a State has agreed to apply a resource rental royalty to crude oil production and where that State has made appropriate revenue sharing arrangements with the Commonwealth. These Bills are aimed to protect the revenue raising ability of the Commonwealth where States exercise discretionary powers which affect royalty collections. The Petroleum Revenue Bill and the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) also will enable the Commonwealth to meet its end of the new tax and revenue sharing bargain. To these ends the Opposition will not oppose the Bills. However, the Opposition is concerned about the spread of the new taxation measures and that the tax take will increase over time-the inevitable consequence of this Labor Government's desire to tax more and more.

SPEECH.PARA: The coalition has opposed the resource rent tax as an additional or secondary tax impost. However, while the resources rent royalty is similar to the RRT and while it is a new tax, it is not an additional tax, as it will replace the current excise tariff. A profits based tax is preferable at any time to a production based, ad valorem tax. In the case of Barrow Island the tax should provide the investment incentive for marginal production for a project which may otherwise become uneconomic.

It must be remembered that this legislation is only half the story. Because the Commonwealth does not have the constitutional power to impose such taxes on shore, this legislation will provide the framework for State legislation to be enacted. Under the Petroleum Revenue Bill and the appropriate State legislation the State stands to benefit immensely by taking a larger slice of the tax in revenue, but the lower overall tax rate may also encourage further secondary development of reserves which benefit all parties. The Commonwealth will take a reduction in revenue in the short term as a result of the lower average tax rate and the compensation payment of $20.3m it will pay to the Western Australian Government in lieu of the royalty revenue which it would have received if it had put its own royalties in place.

In the case of Barrow Island, the Western Australian Government will do very well out of the new arrangements. It will pick up a bigger slice of the revenue from crude oil production this year. It will receive a payment of $20.3m in compensation and for prolonging the life of its older fields. It is no wonder the deal looks attractive to Premier Burke, who faces an election next March. One can only view with cynicism perhaps the introduction of the Bills now and those elections next year. Western Australia might do very nicely, but how will this legislation affect the producers in other States in Australia, in view of the fact that the RRR will only assist continued production from existing wells under current oil recovery techniques for secondary and tertiary production? Also, as production costs increase, because of the inflation rate in this country and the state of our depressed currency, government revenue will decline. Will the Government then seek to develop another tax to bolster its declining fortunes from oil production?

The situation in this country at present is that demand outstrips supply by some 24 per cent. The situation will worsen as our known fields are depleted. I believe that the Government should be looking at incentives to exploration and development of new fields as our major old fields, such as the Bass Strait, become depleted. The Australian Petroleum Exploration Association supports this legislation on the basis that it will assist production but, like the Opposition, it is worried that the Commonwealth Government is establishing new tax imposts on oil exploration and development, particularly off shore. Recently, this House dealt with the cash bonus bidding system and the proposed Commonwealth resource rental tax. All of this has occurred at a time when the Government should be reducing the tax burden to encourage initiative, development and production.

In the long term, will this legislation help our dwindling oil production? Going on figures issued by the Resources and Energy ministry, our energy exports are expected to rise by 150 per cent in the next decade, but the major contributor to that increase will be uranium production, which is expected to treble in the next 10 years to approximately 10,000 tonnes in 1994. Coal is predicted to overtake crude oil as Australia's principal energy source, accounting for 43 per cent of total energy demand by the same year of 1994. The question must be asked: What is this Government doing for the uranium and coal industries? The Hawke Government's policies on uranium are crippling what could be a billion dollar earning for this country. The potential for uranium is immense. Ranger mine production alone is sufficient to provide power for all of Australia's needs. Recently, we saw another cave-in by the Government to the unions with the Government decision not to withdraw coal export controls. This Government is so keen to deregulate the sugar industry, but is reluctant to make any deregulation decisions that might enable the reduction of the cost structure of the coal industry and enable coal producers to compete effectively in world markets.

It appears that the Government does not fully appreciate the contribution that the mining industries make to Australia's balance of payments. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table showing the value of exports over mining in 1984-that is, the total of our exports and the percentage of mining in that total. While I understand it may be difficult to reproduce the table, I would like graph 1 to be incorporated.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just seen the piece of paper which the honourable member has before him. It seems unlikely that the graph will be able to be incorporated. If leave is granted for the incorporation of the remainder of the table in accordance with Mr Speaker's ruling, it may be incorporated.

INTERJECT.PARA: Mining as a Percentage of Total...
(Figures from the Australian Mining Industry Council)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. The table which I have incorporated sets out the value of Australia's exports of mineral and primary mineral products, which include oil. The total value of exports in 1984 was almost $11.3 billion, representing 43.1 per cent of Australia's total merchandise exports of $26.1 billion. Some 20 years ago, the value of mineral exports, as indicated by the graph to which I have referred, calculated on an equivalent basis, amounted to 10 per cent of total exports. Thus mining growth, which went from 10 per cent of total exports in 1964 to 43 per cent in 1984, has made a vast contribution to Australia's living standards. I think that should be appreciated by all those people who are not really interested in the mining industry.

SPEECH.PARA: Looking ahead to the next 10 years, it is apparent that mineral exports will need to continue to accelerate if economic growth is to be sustained in the face of mounting foreign indebtedness. At a time when Australia's foreign debts have reached record levels and interest rates are soaring, government policy should be directed at increasing exports, rather than preventing them. The uranium policy of this Government is benefiting Canada at the expense of Australia. I have already said that uranium production is expected to treble by 1994 but, in addition, Australia could be a major world supplier of uranium, earning in excess of $1 billion a year. However, this Government is shackling the industry by restricting the number of companies that are allowed to develop their uranium deposits. We now have the absurd situation in the Northern Territory where Nabarlek and Ranger can develop but Koongarra and Pancontinental Mining Ltd at Jabiluka cannot. While these restrictions are imposed on Northern Territory companies, South Australian uranium deposits at Roxby Downs are declared good and are approved. That just shows the Government's inconsistency in its policy on uranium. It is as inconcistent as its policy on petroleum products. Millions of dollars have been spent by Koongarra and Pancontinental to bring both these mines to the point at which development could proceed immediately, but at the moment development has been halted by these restrictions. Besides the potential contribution that these projects could make to the Australian economy, it is unfair to those companies which spent millions of dollars with every expectation that they could mine their deposits. I understand that the Commonwealth pays some $4m per year in restitution for the prevention of that mining.

What purpose has been served by banning the supply of uranium for end use in France, for instance? It will cost Australian taxpayers more than $100m by the end of 1986 and probably further millions thereafter. About 50 per cent of the electricity plants in France are already nuclear powered, but nuclear testing still continues in the Pacific. Plenty of other countries are willing to supply our markets and this futile ban has achieved nothing, done immense damage and further tarnished Australia's reputation as a reliable supplier. Our reputation as a supplier will shortly be put to the test by the proposed just in time arrangement in Japan. Can the Government give the guarantee of reliability that will be required for this new Japanese arrangement? While Australia fiddles, Canadian uranium developments are going ahead and gaining world markets, markets which should have been sown up by Australia within the last couple of years. I turn to the coal industry with its huge potential to aid our ailing industry and provide an energy resource product to the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about turning to the Bill?

—I am talking about the energy resources of the world and I am pointing out the inconsistency of the Government's attitude on petroleum which matches its inconsistency on uranium and coal. All these provide the basis of our energy resources and what is available overseas. We have vast deposits of good quality coal but prices must be competitive on the world market. It is the duty of this Government to pare additional costs to a minimum. We must stimulate, not stifle our export industries. Once again, the Government has bowed to union pressure on not withdrawing coal export controls. When will the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Council of Trade Unions realise that inflexible and high cost regulation will result only in long term structural unemployment and lower revenue, both to the coal industry and the country? I know of one coal mining company, for instance, whose customers in Europe waited nine months for contract approval while the Federal authority reviewed the situation.

—On a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker: I am reluctant to interrupt the honourable member, but this is not a Bill about coal. This is a debate on two revenue Bills which relate quite specifically to the petroleum industry. While the honourable member may no doubt make casual passing reference to them in my submission he cannot concentrate his speech essentially on matters which may be analagous in some ways but which are not relevant to the subject matter of the Bill.

—Order! I have been looking at the Bills which are being debated and I have been trying to make the connection that the honourable member for Dawson obviously seeks to make. I will allow the honourable member for Dawson to continue in the hope that he will make his point and make the connection with the Bills before the House.

—I will not argue the point I made a few moments ago in that we are talking about energy resources of Australia of which petroleum is one. I was pointing out the inconsistency in the taxing methods of this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: An incident having occurred-

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a bit like this Government. The only difference is that this Government is like a chook with its head cut off, not with its head on. I have spoken about the effect on coal and the comparative situation that applies throughout the world as far as advantage has been taken in connection with trade. I also talked about whether the Government could, in the just in time arrangement, be able to give Australians the guarantee of reliability to produce for that market.

SPEECH.PARA: In the last 20 years we have seen Australia drop from eighth ranking as a world trader to twenty-third. I will give as an example our trade relations with Japan. In 1978 when the Minister for Science and I were in Japan, we were told that Australia's trade with Japan on energy resource commodities was on a ratio of 3 : 1. I understand that in the coming year, 1986, there could be an equalisation. So export of our energy is of vital concern to Australia. On a per capita basis Australia is one of the most resource-rich nations in the world; yet our standard of living has slipped from second to sixteenth in the world. Why? Because of bad management of those resources. Even at sixteenth this standard is being propped up by borrowing against the future. That is not a very nice legacy for our children. In actual fact, we are mortgaging Australia's security and our children's future to prop up a government of deceit. The positive encouragement of our export industries is the only way Australia can look to reduce its massive deficit on the current account, which is expected to exceed $10 billion this year for the second consecutive year.

I reiterate that the coalition is committed to encouraging our mining industries. The legislation before us today highlights, with its financial sweeteners, the length to which this Government will go in pursuit of its revenue-raising objectives for short term advantages. My concern with this legislation is that, as oil production falls, the Government will be tempted to increase the tax rate to maintain revenue levels. This would, of course, be self-defeating, acting as a further disincentive to oil exploration and development which are so badly needed. The coalition will not oppose these Bills; it will examine the application of the tax in the overall review of tax arrangements when re-elected to government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) ranged very widely in his comments and did not spend much time on the Petroleum Revenue Bill and Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2). In fact, he was concerned to talk to us about a wide range of mineral industries and the impact on the foreign account deficit. We totally agree with strongly supporting Australia's mining industry. We are aware of the crucial role which the mining industry plays in our exports. Although we are aware of that fact, this does not mean that we should place all our eggs in the one basket as was the policy of the Fraser Government which for many years-honourable members will recall the election of 1980-claimed in an irresponsible fashion that there would be a huge resources boom in this country and in fact produced figures which showed about $30 billion of new investments which never materialised. SPEECH.PARA: I believe that the way in which we can overcome this problem is to develop Australian technology in a number of areas. The Minister for Science (Mr Barry Jones) is working at this. But there is one area in which the coalition is culpable. It not only zeroed in on the mining sector, but also did very little to assist in mineral processing and in industries associated with mining.

TALK.START.PARA: —You banned uranium processing.

—We have our principles. We are not unprincipled, as are honourable members opposite, in relation to the uranium issue. Let us turn to what happened in relation to those mining resources. It is true that many of our problems stem from the total mismanagement of the so-called resources boom of that period. It is because of that mismanagement that we have many of the problems that we face at present. We are now told by honourable members opposite that they are great supporters of the mining industry in this country and that we should not concern ourselves because we are opposed to mining. In what way is the Labor Government opposed to mining?
—Aboriginal land rights; capital gains tax.

—Let us look at the facts. The honourable member interjects about Aboriginal land rights. That is the level of understanding of honourable members opposite of the issues concerning mining in this country. I recall that for many years members of the Opposition opposed the introduction of the resources rent tax. The fact is that in this area, as is the case in many other areas, when it comes to careful, planned development it is the Australian Labor Party and the Labor Government that put the policies into place, as opposed to the nonsense we have heard from the Opposition, which, as I said, missed a golden opportunity because of its total mismanagement of mining development in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Deputy Speaker, if you look at the proposals that we are debating, you will see that they are very important proposals precisely because they are no longer based on volume of production, but on the level of profitability. They will encourage new investment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you deal with the Bass Strait?

—I will deal with Bass Strait in a moment. Mr Deputy Speaker, the honourable member for Deakin seems to get excited about these matters without giving much thought to or studying the real issues involved. I tell the honourable member that I have studied these issues for five years. He has come into this House with some theoretical notions which he thinks he can apply to the Australian economy. We have already heard them. They are absolute nonsense.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us turn to the real issues concerning mining. The fact is that this particular tax, which is a form of resources rent tax, is very important because it will stimulate production without excessively taxing the industry. We have just heard noises from honourable members on the other side to the effect that we have taxed the industry excessively. How have we done that? The introduction of this new tax to replace the excise will have a very major effect. It will stimulate investment and it will stimulate production, precisely because if a company does not make sufficient levels of profit it will not have to pay tax. It is no longer based on the production notion. That is a very substantial change and, as the Minister for Science stated in his second reading speech:
The Bill represents a major step forward in reform of resources taxation in Australia.

All we have heard is some grumbling noises from the other side of the House without any recognition of the importance of this approach. If honourable members opposite are really seriously interested in the promotion of mining and resource development in this country they will support not only these measures but also the kind of planned development approach which we have put into place. The shadow Minister attacked the cash bidding principle. This is a very interesting approach. The so-called champions of private enterprise are attacking the cash bidding principle. Why is that? The cash bidding principle enables--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a Government rip-off in areas where it has no expertise.

—The honourable member says that the Government will get some money; therefore honourable members opposite object to it. The company that makes the best bid will get the licence. Therefore, is not cash bidding based on the private enterprise principle? Or are Opposition members saying that there should be no competition in this area? I will tell honourable members why the Opposition does not want competition in this area: It is because the Opposition wants to give accessibility to these resources to its specific friends rather than leave it open to the market. The Opposition should never have opposed the cash bidding principle.

SPEECH.PARA: I return to the issue with which I began; that is, the form of taxation that is introduced in this legislation. SPEECH.PARA: At the moment we are roughly 70 per cent self-sufficient in Australia. We need to be 100 per cent self-sufficient so that we are not dependent on world markets, world changes, world fluctuations, et cetera. When we went to import parity pricing-the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale) who is sitting in front of me knows this quite well- I said that the reason we matched the world price was so that we could become self-sufficient and look for alternatives such as liquefied petroleum gas and diesel motor vehicles. The Minister for Science, who is sitting at the table, is a very intelligent Minister. I have my criticisms of the oil industry, as honourable members know. We had our first major industry inquiry in 1975, when I think Mr Justice Collins said that this industry cried out for reform, needed reform, that every consumer in Australia needed a fair go and that if every consumer in Australian was going to be dependent on a petrol driven vehicle, he needed to have a fair opportunity to get a fair price.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was Collins, not Coleman.

SPEECH.PARA: We talk about reforms in relation to other things. We form committees on this matter and on that matter. But I want Australian consumers and every motorist to have a fair go. Some of those motorists are people who can ill afford to pay the high price for petrol. It is the means of making the family structure a little more--

TALK.START.PARA: —Interest rates are killing home buyers.

We should look for a reduction in the price of petrol. It is useless for the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) at election time to say that there will be a reduction in the price of petrol. People remember that. SPEECH.PARA: For many motorists and families, their only enjoyment is their motor vehicle. TALK.START.PARA: —I support the views of the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck). There should be a good look at the petrol industry. There is something wrong with it. I have said on many occasions that it has the Australian public over a barrel-the oil barrel. It is taking millions of dollars from the motorist and it is not putting back anything into the community in proportion to what it takes out. Whereas previously many people were employed at petrol stations, they now employ hardly anyone. If one goes to a petrol station now in Melbourne and one wants to inflate the tyres on one's vehicle, one has to pay 20c to get some air. That is the sort of policy of the large oil cartel set up in Australia and how it is affecting the motorist. I believe that they are not doing the right thing by us. They are carving up the Australian market to suit themselves. They are cutting down the number of refineries to suit their own marketing policy. I think we will find in a few years' time that the Shell Company of Australia, for example, will look after Victoria, BP Australia Ltd will look after Queensland, and so on. That will be the set-up. Then the companies will dictate the prices to us. I quote from an article in the Sun of Tuesday, 24 September. The Executive Director of the Victorian Automobile Chamber of Commerce, Mr Bob Davison, made a number of statements. He described the discounting and petrol pricing as `a cynical rip-off', and continued:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the reason for the original pattern of petrol pricing is oversupply.

I think the figures they give us in relation to a shortage are not correct. I believe that many of the figures, graphs and charts are being beaten up to justify the price charged by the petrol companies. The article continued:
`The fact is the retail market place is all but totally controlled by major oil companies, all but totally'.
Mr Davison says there are four ways oil companies get rid of their product.
On the one hand they supply it to high volume `jobbers', such as Solo-
that is, in Melbourne-
They also sell it to owner-operators of service stations.
These people, because they are not tied to an oil company supplier, are therefore wooed to a certain extent and given some substantial price benefits.
But the greater number of outlets by far are represented by people to whom the oil companies are landlords, people who rent the premises from an oil company.
Those people have no choice about price, they pay exactly what the oil company invoices them.
Their position in the market place is very much determined by how much they can afford to run to the competition, given that the maximum margin available to them is under four cents.
The remaining form of distribution is through company-owned sites, usually well-located, high-volume, many-laned sites known in the industry as `gas pumpers'.

The oil companies are dictating to owners of these sites the price at which they can sell their petrol, the price at which they have to buy, when they can buy it and how much they can buy. In a way they have total control of the market, and it is not right that they should do so. I also believe that at present some of the larger companies are forcing smaller service stations out of business because of the pricing policy that is dictated to them. Mr Davison also contends that petrol pricing is destabilising the industry, especially at the retail level. He believes it creates risks of losses. The article continued:
It is simply a matter of the big oil companies using the retail market place to guarantee or protect their market share.
We claim that is cynical in that the oil companies claim they're presiding over healthy discounts initiated by retailers. That is simply false.

I believe that Mr Davison is correct. We are all being led up the garden path, or perhaps I should say down the road, by the petrol companies. I trust that some of the measures the Government has put into place to save petrol and to convert our cars to gas will be implemented quite soon. Recently, the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) issued a Press release and its aim was to get motorists to try to save 80 million litres of petrol. The release stated:
The Australian passenger vehicle industry has agreed to try to achieve a significant further reduction in the average fuel consumption of new passenger cars over the next three years.

That is an admirable aim and I trust it can be achieved. I am certain that, with the new motor designs that Australia's engineers come up with for Australian made cars especially, we can achieve this. The Press release stated further:
A national average fuel consumption target of 8.5 litres/100 km has been set for 1987-a substantial reduction from the 9.56 litres achieved in 1984.
Achievement of the 1987 figure would mean that Australian motorists used 82 million litres less in that year . . .

I am quite certain that the petrol companies will not like this. I am quite certain that they will do all in their power to frustrate Australian motorists' efforts to save that amount of fuel. The Press release continued:

The voluntary program to achieve improved passenger vehicle efficiency began in 1979 with an agreement between the Government and the Federal Chamber of Automotive Industries which represents all vehicle manufacturers, assemblers and importers.

The program originally aimed at reducing the national average fuel consumption from 11.8 litres/100 km in 1978 to a target figure of 9 litres/150 km in 1983. The actual level realised in 1983 was 9.5 litres/100 km.

There has been a change in car design. Recently there has been a resurgence of cars with larger engines. I drive a car with a fairly large engine. I must say that if my family were smaller I would probably shift to a smaller car, but I trust that with new technology, smaller engines may be available to power these larger cars which can carry more people. Australians are used to driving a fairly large car. I think this is one of the reasons why General Motors-Holden's Ltd's level of car sales has dropped off and Ford's sales have picked up. It is just that Ford manufactures a larger car. We need larger cars in Australia to travel in comfort because of the miles and miles between our towns. That is probably the reason, but larger cars such as Fords also mean increased petrol consumption throughout Australia. I trust that new designs coming out will cut down the use of large amounts of gasoline.

BP has closed its refinery at Western Port. I have spoken on this matter on many occasions. I must report that many of the people who worked for BP at Hastings have found new jobs. One wonders about everything that these petrol companies put up about the shortage of fuel when we in Australia are exporting tonnes of fuel. All right; it is good for our balance of payments but I think people in Australia should also get some of the benefits that accrue from our having our own supply of petrol. As I have said on many occasions, I do not believe that the large petrol cartels do the correct job for the Australian public. They are taking many millions of dollars out of this country. I do not believe that they are putting enough back into the country. I believe that they are cutting the people of Australia short on the service that they should be giving to this country.

They are not prepared to let a bloke get up and do a job. People cannot go out and work today without being taxed to death. For God's sake! People cannot go out and find a resource without being taxed to death. Mr Deputy Speaker, I know that you look a little anxious, but this is a very serious matter. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brumby Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my pleasure to speak in support of the Petroleum Revenue Bill and the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2), which in effect is a consequential amendment to the main Bill before the House. Having listened to the previous speaker, the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron), I have to say that while his speech was in some ways entertaining it was a little light on facts. Indeed, it is quite apparent that the honourable member has neither bothered to read the legislation before the House nor read the explanatory memorandum which puts that legislation in language which ordinary people can understand. I think it is important to state at the outset that what this legislation is all about is, over the longer term, encouraging the production of additional petroleum resources in Australia.
—How can any tax encourage production?

—I will explain for the honourable member's benefit that in Australia at the moment, under existing arrangements, petroleum production is taxed via excise by the Commonwealth Government and by State government royalties. In effect, what the existing tax regime tends to do is to tax production. Obviously, there are many marginal resource development projects around Australia, particularly in the oil area, that cannot afford to proceed because their costs are high and their production levels are low. Under the existing tax regime those exploration ventures are permanently put in the waste paper bin because the current tax system is too high but, more importantly, it is too inflexible and taxes that production. What this new taxation arrangement and this legislation is all about is to change the emphasis on taxation away from production to a taxation on profits. That means that there will be a difference in the time span over which the profits, or the taxes, are raised. Many marginal exploration areas in Australia will be able to proceed because the total taxation levied will be less than that levied under the current arrangements.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that there are a number of very important advantages in this resource taxation package. I have mentioned the first advantage; that is, the existing taxation regime applies taxes on production and, as such, discourages marginal projects from getting under way and brings about the premature termination of production from many wells. I would have thought-I have to emphasise this for the benefit of members of the National Party, who are always harping about the need for additional exports in this country-that the export of energy was a significant export from this country and that the alternative tax schedule which this legislation introduces would encourage more production and, over time, facilitate greater exports of energy.

The second reason that we support this tax package is that under the new arrangements the full value of capital and operating costs will be able to be written off in the year in which they are incurred. That is something that cannot be done under the existing tax regime. I suppose the conclusion of that is that major new investments in this country are therefore encouraged. Consequently, they will assist in maintaining production which would otherwise decline.

TALK.START.PARA: —Name the wells that are coming into production.
—The honourable member for Maranoa has asked for an example. One of the classic examples is Jabiru which will get under way next year and which I can say quite categorically--
—They found that three years ago. It is producing oil.

—That is incorrect. Jabiru could not set up under the current tax regime because it will have marginal production. Under the current production-based taxation arrangements of Commonwealth excise and State royalties it simply would not be profitable. Under the new resource royalty agreements the wells will be able to get into production, and that will be good for Australia and good for exports. I will make another point for the benefit of the honourable member for Maranoa, who tonight gave, as I have said, one of the most ignorant speeches I have heard. He talked about Australian oil exploration. I have already said that this legislation will improve and encourage exploration in Australia. I note that despite the honourable member's comments the Opposition does not oppose the Bills. Let me say this: Estimated expenditure on petroleum exploration in 1984, the year just passed, was $900m. That is close to a record and it is up from $826m in 1983.
—Put it in real terms.

—The figure was $826m in 1983. If one adds 7 per cent to that one does not get more than $900m. It is an increase in real terms. What about the number of wells that are drilled? A record 374 wells were drilled in 1984, 268 of which were exploration wells. The fact is that exploration is going well. This legislation will facilitate that exploration in the future and will encourage the actual conversion into production. This is very important for Australians because in the absence of any new oil discovery, our level of self-sufficiency in petroleum fuels and production is forecast to decline from the current level of 79 per cent to 42 per cent in 1993.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that there are reasonable prospects for new crude oil discoveries in Australia, although there are variances in the estimates of how much will be produced. For example, the Bureau of Mineral Resources has estimated that `between 650 and 1,300 million barrels of crude oil can reasonably be expected to be discovered over the next 10 years and that the production possible from these fields could provide somewhere between 35 and 105 million barrels of crude oil a year by 1993-94'. If we get that production and the fields are actually producing oil, Australia's self-sufficiency level will be somewhere between 56 per cent and 86 per cent in that year. I can only repeat, for the benefit of the honourable member opposite who made such an ignorant speech previously, that what is needed in this country is an encouragement to actually put marginal wells into production. That is what the two Bills before the House are all about.

I want to make a couple of other points about what has been said by Opposition members. The honourable member for Maranoa, in his normal way, bleated about the price of petrol. I point out for his benefit and the benefit of other members of the Opposition that the price of petrol did not increase 10c or 20c a litre under the previous Government; it fact, it tripled. Between 1976 and 1980, under the Fraser Liberal Government, of which the honourable member for Maranoa was a member, the price of petrol tripled. I might add also that it was the Opposition parties which introduced import parity pricing. It galls me to hear Opposition members stand up in this House so self-righteously and say that if they ever get back into government they will abolish import parity pricing. That is a load of rubbish, a load of rot. Apart from the fact that in revenue terms it would be impossible for any government to do that, the simple fact is that import parity pricing is the right policy for Australia. Without import parity pricing there would be no discouragement to excessive consumption levels of a vital economic energy resource in Australia. More importantly, if we do not price our petroleum products at the export price, our whole pricing system will be out of kilter and, obviously, there will be incentives for much greater export of the product from Australia. If our price were much lower than elsewhere in the world, consumption in Australia would rise, there would be no encouragement for exploration and by 1993 we would be totally dependent on exports, by which stage we would, of course, be paying the export price.

Contrary to what the honourable member for Maranoa says-and I have to keep repeating this for his benefit-even after the devaluation of the Australian dollar, Australia has the third cheapest petrol of any of the 24 Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries. It is simply nonsense for Opposition members to keep coming into this House-having themselves when in government introduced import parity pricing, having themselves overseen an increase of 300 per cent in the price of petrol-and making the nonsense sorts of statements that if they ever get back into government, which might be by 1995, they will abolish IPP. That is absolute rubbish.

I wish to make a couple of other points about petrol prices. Over the last decade, between 1975 and 1985, the import parity price increased on a 10:1 ratio. It increased from $4.33 a barrel to $42.25 a barrel. Despite that increase, the price of petrol in Australian cities-this is the only statistical information available-has increased only by a 4:1 ratio, from 14.3c a litre in October 1975 to 54.9 a litre in September 1985. I repeat that point: The IPP increased tenfold, but the price of petrol at the pump increased only fourfold. Therefore, it is nonsense to refer continually to that aspect, as the honourable member for Maranoa did in his ignorant contribution.

I conclude by saying that this legislation is about encouraging greater exploration, greater production and greater self-sufficiency in Australian petroleum and in terms of new oil discoveries. It does not add any more tax to petrol or oil or anything like that. All it does is change the nature of that tax. It will levy tax at a higher rate from the more highly profitable fields, while for those fields which are marginal-and there are many of them in Australia-it will apply tax at a lower rate on the basis of profits. That means that many marginal oil fields in Australia will be encouraged to produce, which is good for Australians, good for our exports, good for our dollar and good for Australian jobs. Apparently those are matters of no concern to Opposition members. I support this legislation. I believe it is valuable and it is good for our exports, our exploration, our production and our employment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I readily join with my colleagues the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby) and the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) in supporting the Petroleum Revenue Bill 1985 and the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1985. The Petroleum Revenue Bill should receive the full support of this House and I am quite surprised that members of the National Party of Australia have spoken so negatively. Certainly, the Bill will receive the support of the States. I believe it will be welcomed by the States because it will allow State governments to introduce a resource rent royalty on petroleum developments within their jurisdiction. Despite what the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron) says, this is what the States want. It is not just a matter for Western Australia, it is a matter that every State will applaud. The legislation will enable the States to enter into a revenue sharing agreement with the Commonwealth. It will also allow the Commonwealth-that is, the Federal Government-to waive the crude oil excise liability.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Science (Mr Barry Jones) explained in his second reading speech that this is a State initiative. It is not something that the Commonwealth has foisted upon the States, it is a State initiative. It has been developed in consultation with the Commonwealth. As the honourable member for Bendigo said, it will encourage major new investments in mature oil fields. The honourable member for Maranoa mentioned Barrow Island in Western Australia. The point is that if these investments are going to be sufficiently productive and profitable, under this new revenue rent royalty we are going to get a revenue for the Commonwealth. As the honourable member for Bendigo said, it is not a matter of production, it is a matter of profitability. It is only when profits are to be made that there will be a tax or a revenue for the Commonwealth. Under the existing ad valorem State royalty and the Commonwealth crude oil excise, there can be little incentive for further investments. This has been shown. This means that production could be terminated prematurely and thus a drying up of revenue for the public purse. It also means that we would not have an ongoing development of our oil resources.

This measure is a typical example of Labor governments, both at Federal and State levels, being willing to adjust their taxing and revenue-raising arrangements to meet the needs of the petroleum industry and for the financial benefit of the Australian public. While the Barrow Island experience no doubt brought on the change, the application of this Bill will not be limited to that oil field and, in fact, will allow the Commonwealth to waive excise in any situation-I stress the words `in any situation'-where a relevant resource rent royalty is introduced and a revenue-sharing agreement has been concluded. So it benefits every State, not just Western Australia prior to a State election.

The positive actions of the Federal Government in this instance need to be broadcast widely, not only because it is good legislation-that is only part of the reason-but also because it will help counter the vicious and certainly untrue campaign that is being waged by some elements in the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association and the Motor Traders Association in Queensland against the Hawke Labor Government on the question of Federal Government taxes on the petroleum industry. False statistics are being poured out to the media, pamphlets and stickers are being produced and service station proprietors are being conned into spreading the untruths. There is a campaign centring on the claim that total Federal Government taxes on petrol amount to some 35.33c a litre.

I saw an article in this week's Bulletin, paid for, no doubt, by the Shell oil company, which put forward a graph which shows that 63.2 per cent of the total cost of fuel in New South Wales goes in taxes. The Federal Government is being blamed for the high price of fuel especially in country areas. In my country area it is as high as 69.9c a litre. The National Party of Australia, like the honourable member for Maranoa, is unfortunately spreading the untruths. It needs to be placed on the record and repeated over and over again that in 1978 the Fraser Liberal- National Party Government applied import parity pricing for crude oil. It was not the Labor Government that did it; it was the National and Liberal parties that did it. But, in contrast, the Whitlam Labor Government introduced the policy of controlling the wholesale price of petrol and setting maximums.

It is worth noting that the maximum wholesale price of petrol when Mr Fraser came to power was only 11.69c a litre. But under the Fraser Government, under the Liberals and Nationals, the wholesale price skyrocketed from 11.69c a litre to 39.54c a litre, an increase of 27.85c a litre. Under the Hawke Government, the wholesale price has increased only to 48.11c, a rise of 8.57c a litre. The fact is that the Hawke Labor Government has tried to protect Australian motorists through the setting of maximum wholesale prices by the Prices Surveillance Authority.

Under the Hawke Labor Government there have been five reductions in the wholesale price of fuel. The reductions have rarely been passed on, particularly in country areas of Queensland and many other parts of Australia. The Australian Institute of Petroleum claims that the Federal tax is 35.33c a litre. This is backed up by Shell's claim, in an advertisement which no doubt cost the company many thousands of dollars, that the total tax is 35.33c. It is blatantly untrue. I have obtained data from the Department of Resources and Energy which shows that the excise on crude oil is approximately 14c a litre and the excise on petrol is 10.007c a litre, which means that the total Federal tax on petrol is approximately 24c a litre, not the 35.33c which the National Party, the Petroleum Institute, the motor traders and Shell have spread; instead, it is 24c a litre and the same tax applies everywhere in Australia.

I believe that the oil companies need to come good with their statistics to back up what they are saying. In Queensland in recent times fuel has been sold for as low as 42.5c-that is the retail price. I suggest to the House that if the tax were 35.33c it would be impossible to sell it at that price because that leaves approximately 7c a litre to pay for the initial cost of the crude oil, the 5c to 7c for refining, and the 1c to 5c for transport, and still give a profit to both the oil companies and the service station proprietors. The fact is that a total untruth is being propagated by the Petroleum Institute, Shell and the National Party. This campaign needs to be stopped in its tracks.

I challenge the National Party, Shell and the Petroleum Institute to come good with their facts and not just put up some sort of a model or graph that cannot be backed up. They cannot show that the real tax is 35.33c. In Queensland only the other week an oil company admitted that it could sell pertrol to one of its company owned outlets for a wholesale price of 32c. I ask any intelligent member of the National Party-I know that there are very few of them-to explain this to me: If the tax is 35.33c a litre, how can they wholesale it at 32c a litre? It is simply impossible.

TALK.START.PARA: —They would be making a loss.

—They would not be willing to make those losses. They are not prepared to make those losses. The fact is that the tax is not as high as they say and they are all phoney. They are phoney because they have been ripping off Queenslanders, certainly central Queenslanders. The Hawke Labor Government has demonstrated its bona fides in regard to promoting the Australian petroleum industry and protecting Australian motorists. It is time that the blatant untruths and the misrepresentation by the elements of the Petroleum Institute, the retail industry and the petroleum industry were shown up for what they are. The facts are that the total tax on fuel in Australia averages about 24c a litre. I say `averages' because it cannot be set down at a particular percentum because it varies depending on the oil source.

SPEECH.PARA: The point is that the honourable member for Maranoa has been propagating these types of untruths for a long time. It needs to be said that the truth is with the Government. The facts are very clear and I will present them. In fact, I am prepared to table the documents given to me by the Department which show very clearly that the crude oil excise is 14c a litre and the Commonwealth excise on petrol is 10.007c a litre. One does not need a university degree to work out that that adds up to only 24c a litre. That tax of 24c a litre applies right across Australia. Yet the National Party in Maranoa, western Queensland and central Queensland-in all parts of Australia-is saying that the tax is about 35.33c. I believe that the Petroleum Institute is to blame for this. I believe that it is a blatant liar. I know that that may seem to be unparliamentary, but I am not referring to any member of the House; I am referring to the Institute, because it is a blatant liar. It has told untruths and its reason is quite obvious: It is trying to cover up the rip-off that it is perpetrating in Queensland. It is ripping off the motorists of Queensland and also the motorists of New South Wales and Victoria.
