I believe the Trade Practices Commission ought to have a hard look at what Shell has stated in the last Bulletin magazine because it is blatant misrepresentation. SPEECH.PARA: As to the timing of the introduction of rent taxes, the Commonwealth's policy is of long standing. They remove some inconsistencies; they tighten up and clarify the definitions; they reflect more precisely the Commonwealth's requirement for it to waive its right to levy excise on crude oil and naturally occurring liquefied petroleum gas. There has been no change in the intent of the legislation.

A number of the changes are quite technical. For example, amendments Nos 1, 2, 3, 4, 7, 8, 11, 12, 13, 14, 22, 24 and 31, which are more or less typical of the whole, alter the term `resource rent agreement' to read `resource rent royalty agreement'. DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON ENVIRONMENT AND CONSERVATION

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received advice from the Opposition Whip that he has nominated Mr Webster to be a member of the Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation in place of Mr Connolly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Transport Safety, I present the report of the Committee on bicycle helmet safety, together with extracts of minutes of proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask leave of the House to make a short statement in connection with the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report I have just tabled on bicycle helmet safety is the first report of the Transport Safety Committee, although the inquiry was commenced in the last Parliament by the Standing Committee on Road Safety. The Committee has been concerned throughout this inquiry by the high incidence of head injuries in bicycle injuries, and particularly the very high incidence in fatalities from bicycle accidents, the latter being around 80 per cent. South Australian evidence indicates that in 50 to 65 per cent of cyclist fatalities head injuries are the sole cause of death. Statistics which appalled the Committee during this inquiry were those showing the over-representation of children in bicycle casualties. Studies show that 70 per cent of all bicycle casualties involved children aged from seven to 17 years, although this age group constitutes only 18.4 per cent of the general population. One frequent misconception is that bicycle accidents involving injury or fatality occur only on roads in accidents with motor vehicles. This is not correct as many serious cycling accidents are single vehicle accidents and 25 per cent of cyclist fatalities occur off road. Cycling injuries are very poorly reported and their full extent can be estimated only from the current data reported. This underreporting hinders road safety authorities in identifying the true causes of bicycle accidents and the importance of proper safety counter-measures.

SPEECH.PARA: It must be emphasised that helmets are a secondary safety measure for cyclists and cannot replace primary safety measures such as rider competence, knowledge and observance of road rules, and bicycle brakes, lights and reflectors. However, even the best cyclists have accidents and head injuries can be personally devastating or fatal as well as expensive to the community. Quality helmets are a very effective secondary safety measure and an effective helmet can mean the difference between life and death. With the advent of high quality hard-shell bicycle helmets many of these injuries are avoidable or the severity of the injury can be substantially reduced. Despite the high level of protection offered by quality helmets, they cannot protect riders against all injuries or fatalities as on occasions the impact is too severe. The Committee defines quality helmets as those which have met the minimum requirements set down by the Australian Standard AS2063. The helmet must have a hard outer shell with a firm inner liner. The liner must be able to crush on impact. To be effective as a safety helmet bicycle helmets must be able to: spread impact forces to reduce the risk of skull fracture or penetration from highly localised loads; absorb as much energy as possible to reduce the deceleration forces on the brain; and cover the head and protect it from abrasion.

It is important to understand that cyclist head injuries mainly result from fracturing of the skull as a result of impact and also from damage to the brain when a moving head comes to an abrupt stop. Inadequate shells and liners offer little or no protection for the head. To be certified to the standard, helmets are impact tested to determine their energy attenuation properties. They are also tested on a number of other aspects. Two studies have provided some measure of the benefits of helmet wearing in real crash situations. The Study by Dorsch and others published in 1984 showed that cyclists in Adelaide wearing helmets in a crash suffered fewer and less severe head injuries. Those with a quality hard shell helmet were 19 times less likely to die as a result of head injuries in a crash than those not wearing a helmet. Those wearing hair-net type helmets, favoured by some racing cyclists, were estimated to be eight times less likely to die. A study by McDermott and Klug of cyclist and motor-cyclist casualties in Melbourne showed that cyclists sustained more frequent and severe head injuries than motor-cyclists. Motor-cyclists would be expected to be involved in more severe accidents, and other injuries received by both groups support this. However motor-cyclists universally wear high quality protective helmets while few cyclists did so at the time of the study. The cyclist fatality rate was almost twice that of motor-cyclists and the death rate with head injury as the sole cause was more than twice that of motor-cyclists.

Recent bicycle casualty statistics from Victoria have shown a clear improvement which is believed to be due to increased helmet wearing in that State. Some deficiencies in the standard have been identified in the past 18 months and the Standards Association of Australia has moved to correct them. A separate bicycle helmet standard is being prepared and should be completed in approximately 18 months. The Committee has recommended that this standard, when completed, be made a mandatory product safety standard under the Trade Practices Act. As the revised standard may have some significantly different requirements to the current one the Committee felt that the standard revision should be finalised before compliance with the standard is made mandatory. However, the Committee is most concerned with the number of grossly inadequate safety helmets being sold. The shells of these helmets have inadequate impact resistance and the helmets do not have adequate liners capable of attenuating, or absorbing, the high energy levels that the head can be subjected to in an accident. These two features are essential to a safety helmet. Consequently the Committee has recommended that helmets which do not meet the impact energy attenuation requirements of the current Standard AS2063 be declared unsafe products and prohibited from sale. Similarly, bona fide toy helmets should be permanently marked to indicate clearly that they are toys only and should not be used for safety purposes. It is most important that parents are aware of the danger of buying these toys and relying on them to protect the heads of youngsters who are cycling. The permanent marking required to indicate this is similar to the marking required on children's floating toys used in swimming.

The Committee believes that universal helmet wearing will result in cost savings to the community although the full extent is uncertain. The Committee saw several cost-benefit calculations for universal helmet use. The Committee believes that an accurate and thorough assessment of the cost and benefits of making bicycle helmet use mandatory is necessary before taking such a step. The Committee has recommended that the Federal Office of Road Safety have a full cost-benefit analysis carried out. Regardless of the results of such an analysis the comparatively low cost of a helmet compared with the cost of those injuries which can be avoided make it a very good insurance policy.

Recent bicycle helmet promotion campaigns, particularly those in Victoria, have shown that helmet wearing rates can be increased dramatically. The Committee believes that effective programs to promote bicycle helmet use should be developed at the national level to be quickly available for use by all States and Territories. These programs should utilise where possible effective material already developed. The Committee believes that universal wearing of bicycle helmets should be a national goal, particularly for the highest risk group-children and adolescents. As with seat belts and motorcycle helmets, the Committee believes that universal wearing can be most readily achieved through mandatory wearing legislation. This is not to say that education and promotion campaigns are less important. As with all mandatory safety measures, a high degree of self-enforcement is necessary. If cyclists understand the protection available through helmets--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I take a point of order. With the greatest respect and acknowledging the importance of the subject matter, I would like to draw attention to the fact that the honourable member for Lilley was given permission to make a short or brief statement. It seems that the length of the statement is more consistent with the actual report.
—Order! There is no point of order. The honourable member for Lilley was given leave.

—Thank you, Mr Speaker. I was given 10 minutes. I thank the honourable member for Cowper for taking two of those minutes on an important issue such as that of helmet safety! If cyclists understand the protection available through helmets they are more likely to insist on wearing them. Some high exposure groups, such as adult commuter cyclists, are already achieving high usage rates in south-eastern capital cities. However the highest risk group, 7 to 17-year-olds, are still one of the lowest user groups, with adolescents being the most resistant to helmet use. The acceptance by primary school children of safety measures and their compliance with parental directions has shown that usage rates amongst this group can be raised readily. The adolescent group has been less willing to adopt helmet wearing and peer group pressure has been one of the major factors. Although it will take some time it is hoped that some of the primary school children being persuaded to wear helmets will maintain their helmet use as they get older. It is also important for the adolescent group to have suitable role models offered to encourage helmet wearing. The Federal Office of Road Safety, recently conducted a campaign using Molly Meldrum from the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's Countdown program to promote the wearing of quality helmets. The Committee commends this move. This campaign was backed up by advertisements on radio by a number of well-known popular music groups.

SPEECH.PARA: Two programs which originated in Victorian schools are worthy of wider adoption around Australia. The first is the bulk purchase scheme whereby community members can get together to order large numbers of helmets, obtaining them at especially low prices. This particularly assists low income families and those with several children. A number of Victorian schools have adopted a policy that children must wear a helmet for the journey to and from school. While schools largely lack the power to make this a compulsory rule it has been very successful where introduced and has received strong parental support. These two programs have been effective in getting helmets on to the heads of the group most at risk.

The Committee has recommended that 12 months after a mandatory standard has been introduced for bicycle helmets, which itself should take approximately 18 months, the benefits of universal helmet wearing should be reviewed and unless there are persuasive arguments to the contrary the wearing of helmets by cyclists on roads and other public places should be made compulsory. A number of the prerequisites for universal use are currently being fulfilled. There is a growing acceptance of the necessity of helmet use. Usage rates in many areas have risen substantially in recent years and are continuing to rise. A number of schools are introducing the compulsory wearing of helmets for students when they are cycling to and from school and various schemes have made approved helmets available at a modest price.

The Committee is concerned about the enormity of those head injuries and fatalities that are avoidable with the wearing of a good helmet. Difficulties likely to be encountered in implementing compulsory helmet use such as enforcement with children and civil rights questions need to be addressed directly. Overcoming these obstacles is well worth the effort in terms of the benefits. I am pleased at the excellent bipartisan effort that has gone into the Committee's efforts in looking at the area of bicycle helmet safety. As a community, it is our responsibility to provide to those most at risk, the 7 to 17-year-olds, the level of protection so readily available. Therefore, the Committee has identified three objectives to improve cyclist safety through helmet wearing as: First, make sure that all helmets on the market are of an adequate standard; secondly, educate the community as to the benefits of helmet use; and thirdly, in 2 1/2 years time, after the above two measures have been undertaken, ensure universal helmet wearing through legislation.

On behalf of the Committee I would like to thank officers of the Federal Office of Road Safety and the Federal Minister for Transport, Mr Peter Morris, for their excellent support and co-operation. I personally would like to thank members on both sides of the House, including the Deputy Chairman, the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck), for the effort they have put in and for the serious manner in which they have considered these issues which are of the utmost importance in this House as they are in the community.

TALK.START.PARA: —I quote:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia has no productivity. Our costs are too high. We have too many bludgers. The country is bankrupt and no one will admit it. If Australia were a private company, it would be in liquidation.

Those are the telling words of David Throsby, a partner of Charles David Pty Ltd, which the Australian of 20 November described as `the remarkable New South Wales based meat processor . . . which has changed the gloomy outlook hanging over the Australian meat industry in one swoop this week'. The problem facing this enterprising abattoir operator is to overcome the outdated work practices which have been institutionalised and protected by the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union. These practices have resulted in the Wagga City Council abattoirs losing $15m. The Mudginberri meat workers showed the rest of Australia just what could be done when an outdated tally system is replaced. Productivity increased, profits were made and the meat workers took home more pay. The Throsby brothers aim to annex the New Zealand export sheep market which would provide a much needed boost to the Australian farmer, our balance of payments difficulties and employment opportunities in the meat industry. They are hampered by the nineteenth century attitude of the AMIEU and the Throsbys' claim that union policy is preventing 150 meat workers from earning up to $500 a week.

Mac Gardener's haulage company at Cooma provides another example of union intervention; this time the Transport Workers Union is threatening the viability of a small business which had arrived at a flexible working relationship between the men and the owner. Prior to the TWU action, Mac was able to maintain high levels of productivity and the men were happy and well paid. While the business is still operating, kept alive during the dispute by section 45D of the Trade Practices Act, its long term existence and therefore the workers' jobs are at risk because the award system lacks the incentive component which the previous arrangement provided for Mac and his men.

We have around 125,000 15 to 19-year-olds with little or no chance of gaining a permanent job. In my own electorate another hard working Australian, a fencing contractor, sought to give one of these 19-year-olds a chance in life. He wanted to employ this keen, young, unemployed lad under the agricultural and pastoral workers award, but because he was seeking employment assistance for the boy through one of the Government's much promoted great employment initiatives, he was told that the Builders Labourers Federation award applied. The difference was $130 a week because the BLF does not have a junior award and, although the job involved building timber fences, these were not on farms. Needless to say, that lad did not get the opportunity he was looking for and which was available to him, due to our inflexible wage fixing system. Meanwhile, the Government boasts that it will spend $600,000 of taxpayers' money to provide 72 of Canberra's `most disadvantaged unemployed people' with 26 weeks' work. That Commonwealth community employment program grant works out at $8,793 per job for half a year. I would have thought that it would be far better for the Government to start deregulating the labour market, just as it has the financial market, and to stand up to union selfishness so that people like the Throsbys, Mac Gardener and my fencing contractor could provide real jobs for those out of work in Australia.

It will not be big governments, big unions or big business that will solve the economic ills of our resource rich country. It will be the Mac Gardeners, the fencing contractors and the abattoir operators to whom I have referred. As Tony Cox, Vice-Chairman of the Small Business Combined Association is quoted as saying:

Small business is the backbone of Australia, but it is severely overtaxed and overregulated. It provides 50 per cent of our jobs, it pays 55 per cent of private sector profits and taxes and produces 46 per cent of Australia's gross national product. There are more than 700,000 of them and the average employment is only eight people. They as a group are highly motivated workers who are not unionized, and get a great deal of job satisfaction. They want to be left alone to get on with the job. To them a working week is seven days, not 38 hours. Because of all kinds of government imposed regulations and award conditions and various State taxes, every $1 paid to workers costs the company around $1.43 and, after tax, the employee gets only 75c.

It is quite obvious that if this country is to become competitive in the world market and employ some of the 564,500 unemployed, then this Government and the union movement will have to change their attitudes--

TALK.START.PARA: —My attention has been caught by an article in today's Daily Mirror entitled `Plan to lift van ban is a winner'. We recommended that permanents be allowed to remain, but no more permanents be allowed. If people wanted to live in a caravan park, as some people do by choice or because it is near where they work, they should be in a mobile home park. We recommended that the New South Wales Government establish a pilot scheme, some sort of mobile home park to see just what such a park would be like. It is permanent residential accommodation. That was what we recommended, but nothing happened. The industry took fright and raised enormous amounts of money to fight what it called the Maher report. There were protest meetings that I had to face all over the State, and nothing happened.

The article in today's Daily Mirror states that something will happen. Some of the things that are going to happen are very good. People in caravan parks have to pay a commercial rate for electricity which is very harsh, particularly on pensioners as they get no concessions. That will change and I commend the State Minister. The New South Wales Government is dealing with permanent housing, permanent habitable accommodation. Every structure built for permanent housing and permanent accommodation in New South Wales is governed by Ordinance 70. So the State Government is manoeuvring with the Public Health Act. The Minister, Kevin Stewart, who is a great friend of mine, assured me at a public meeting in Sydney on this issue that there would be no tampering with the Public Health Act; it is enshrined in the legislation in New South Wales and similar legislation in every State. This is the legislation that wiped out tuberculosis and many contagious diseases. Ordinance 70 is enshrined in the Public Health Act and provides minimum accommodation in bedrooms. The second bedroom in caravans, where children sleep, is too small. That is why they do not comply with the housing laws. That is why they are not classified as houses. The Minister does say that there are a lot of problems and the caravans have to be upgraded.

We must recognise what New South Wales is about to do. It is about to legislate for another form of permanent human habitation. I am sure it will proceed slowly. I have found that some of the ski lodges built in the national park not so very far from here do not comply with Ordinance 70. These lodges get away with it because they are deemed to be like a caravan-a recreational vehicle. What I say to New South Wales and any of the other States is this: I believe there is a future for mobile homes in our nation, but not a very big future. I think many people want to retire to mobile homes. They do not care that mobile homes depreciate quickly; they do not care that no home loans are available for them. They are not houses. Whichever State starts mobile home parks and launches them I feel will get a great boost from tourism because of the potential of this form of housing.

I wish New South Wales well, particularly Kevin Stewart who is allegedly going to retire shortly. I hope that whatever he does in this field is done well and with a lot of thought and will certainly be something for which he can be remembered.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1978, as a result of a fire in one of the hangars at HMAS Albatross, the air museum lost the roof over its head. Since that time it has been left out in the open, subject to the vagaries of the weather, and consequently various aircraft have suffered a degree of deterioration. These aircraft are unique, rare aircraft and would be worth many millions of dollars if one were to place a monetary value on them. They are aircraft such as the Sea Fury, the Vampire, the Fairy Firefly, the Bell Scout Helicopter, the Grumman Tracker and the Dakota DC3. Those are just a few of the unique, rare aircraft that are housed at the air museum.

The air museum is in need of a roof over its head, as I mentioned a few moments ago, Some years ago the Federal Government created a program called the steel industries assistance program. This program was designed to try to broaden the base of the economy in areas around steel cities. Of course, the Illawarra is a famous steel area which in previous years was greatly dependent on the steel industry. When the industry went through a recession it was decided that funds should be put into the district to try to take away its dependency on the steel industry for its income. As a consequence, activities such as tourist activities, for which the Wollongong-Illawarra region is very suitable, have been promoted. The air museum at Albatross lends itself very clearly to that very lucrative tourist industry, an industry which employs many people and which can generate a great deal of income in the Illawarra and Shoalhaven districts.

Unfortunately, the funds that have been made available have been hotly contested and the committee that has been established to draw up recommendations for the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) has been advising the Minister. Its latest advice has been to give first priority to funding for a hangar for the air museum at Albatross. Unfortunately, not all people are prepared to take into account the great benefits that this would provide to the unique aircraft in the museum. A member of parliament who represents an electorate slightly to the north of my electorate in the Illawarra region has been lobbying quite strongly to have these funds which have been given first priority by the committee taken away from the air museum and used to create a sporting facility. I suggest to the House that an air museum which has such a huge tourist potential-a similar air museum in the United Kingdom attracts 250,000 visitors a year-has a great potential to create income for the district. I do not see how any sporting facility in a small and parochial area would have the same benefits for the whole region. I suggest that this House and the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations would well serve the people of Australia by helping to preserve such a unique, rare and valuable part of Australia's air history rather than trying to promote the parochial interests of a few.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak tonight about the vicious attack on penalty rates which has been made by the Liberal and National Party Opposition both inside and outside this House. It is my intention to deal briefly with the facts rather than indulge in the emotional and irrational arguments used by members of the Opposition and employers in their attempts to reduce the wages of employees, particularly the wages of those workers whose base rates are already relatively low.

SPEECH.PARA: The attacks on penalty rates have come in two main forms. Firstly, there is the argument that the weekend no longer represents the traditional two-day leisure period for Australian workers; and secondly, there is the argument that the high cost of penalty rates on employers results in fewer employees being offered work opportunities. I would like first to deal with the argument that the weekend is no longer an important leisure time for Australians. A visit to shopping centres in any large city in Australia on a Saturday morning will provide ample evidence of the crowded shops full of customers who are unable to shop during the week because of their working hours. On Saturday afternoons and Sunday sporting events throughout Australia are full of spectators and beaches, parks and other leisure places are crowded with families enjoying numerous and varied leisure activities. Sunday is also a time of religious observance. Contrary to the argument that the weekend is no longer an important aspect of Australian life, the evidence indicates that the weekend break is more popular than ever.

The facts are that the Monday to Friday working week is institutionalised in our society and work activities, school hours and the provision of services such as banking, post offices and public transport are geared to the normal working week. Saturdays and Sundays are a time when families get together and those employees who work on the weekend are entitled to penalty rates to compensate for the disruption to their social and family life.

The argument involving the cost and employment effects of penalty rates requires a more detailed rejection. Again employers have failed to examine the facts. Firstly, those industries which employ more people outside working hours, such as the tourist, hospitality, and retail industries, have not shown a lower rate of employment growth than other industries. Secondly, there is no correlation between penalty rate increases and unemployment. Thirdly, there has not been a significant increase in penalty rates as a percentage of wage increases, with the total penalty payment cost of $700m representing only 1.4 per cent of the total wage and salary bill. If anything, the facts show that there is a positive relationship between penalty rates and employment.

Penalty rates are encompassed within the total wage levels of Australian workers and a reduction in those rates, unless compensated by increases in the basic wage, would reduce the disposable income of employees. Such a reduction in overall wages would result in a drop in consumer demand leading to the inevitable consequence of an increase in unemployment. The opposition of employers to the continuation of penalty rates represents another of those constant attempts by employers to reduce the wages of their employees. I quote a comment of the Full Bench of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in a standard hours case which sets out the position of employers very clearly:

It has been the historic role of employers to oppose the worker's claims for increased leisure. They have, as is well known, opposed in Parliament and elsewhere, every step in this direction and this case is no exception. The arguments have not much changed in 100 years. Employers have feared such changes as a threat to profits, added obstacle to production; a limitation upon industrial expansion; and a threat to internal and international trade relations.

Let me now turn to the specific attacks by employers on workers in the tourist and hospitality industries because they continue through their unions to uphold their right to penalty rates for overtime, shift work, public holiday work and Saturday and Sunday work. In the hospitality industry penalty rates are paid mainly for weekend work and to suggest that these workers should not receive penalty rates is really proposing that people in one section of the population should not be given any consideration for their loss of weekends.

The Liquor Trades Union is especially concerned that up to 80 per cent of workers in the hospitality industry are casual employees. These people are employed on an hourly basis which can be as little as two hours in hotels if customers are few. Their working week is totally at the mercy of unpredictable market forces and they are not entitled to sick leave or redundancy provisions. In other words they can be sacked without notice. Despite the lack of job security, casual hotel employees receive only a 25 per cent loading. It is not the high cost of wages which is causing the financial problems of the hospitality industry but rather the inflationary costs of land, building, stock and fittings, and the high interest rates on the mortgages and loan funds involved.

(5) What (a) mechanisms exist at the mine to prevent an uncontrolled spill of contaminated water and (b) action has he taken to ensure that such a spillage does not occur.

(6) What steps are being taken to ensure that a build-up of excess water at Ranger does not occur again and will he direct the Ranger authorities to build additional containments for water; if not, why not.
(7) What alternatives to water release are being considered by the supervising scientist for the Alligator Rivers Region.

(8) Is the Minister able to say whether (a) there are many plans for a water treatment plant to be used to decontaminated water from the restricted release zone and (b) mining operations have ceased at any time due to excess water; if so, (i) when and (ii) for what period.
(9) What long-term plans have been made for the final disposal of radioactive wastes originating from the mine.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Resources and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No approval has been given by the Northern Territory Minister for Mines and Energy for the release of water from the restricted release zone at the Ranger Mine, nor am I aware of any intention on the part of the Minister to make such a decision in advance of agreement on what constitutes best practicable technolgy for the management of waste within the mine's restricted release zone.

(2) The Government's position is that there will be no release of contaminated water from the restricted release zone at Ranger unless it is agreed that water release under appropriate conditions constitutes the best practicable technology for the management of water within that zone.
(4) Yes, pending the completion of further work towards the establishment and acceptance of best practicable technology.

(5) The Ranger mine operated under strict environmental requirements reflecting the recommendations of the Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry. These requirements are primarily implemented by the Northern Territory supervisory authorities who have responsibility for overseeing the day to day operation of the mine.

(6) to (8) Water management at Ranger in its broadest sense is under consideration by the supervising authorities and the mining company, and feasible options are being examined to establish the best possible technology. I understand that mining operations have been impeded from time to time due to the build-up of water in the mine pit, but this has not significantly impeded the operations of the mill at Ranger.

(9) The Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry envisaged that after the cessation of mining at Ranger the mill tailings will be returned to the mine pit and covered with an impermeable layer of rock, unless after 10 years of operation it is agreed that an alternative method of tailings disposal will result in the environment being no less well protected than by returning the tailings to the pit. The current Plan of Rehabilitation for the mine, which is updated annually, provides for the eventful return of tailings to the pit.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 9 October 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When will the Government bring down its response to the National Language Policy Report of the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts.
(2) In the interim, what action is the Minister undertaking to ensure that second language programs are introduced into Australian schools in the near future.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Education has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) As I have indicated in the Senate, I am co-ordinating, through my Department, the Government's response to the Report of the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts, `A National Language Policy'.

A committee, consisting of senior officers from my portfolio, was established to develop this response. This committee sought the views of other relevant government departments and agencies and State education authorities, concerning the Report and its recommendations. The Committee has completed its task and I expect to be able to announce the Government's response in this session of Parliament.

(2) The teaching of community languages (other than English) in primary and secondary schools is the responsibility of the education authorities (government or non-government) located in the States/Territories. The Commonwealth Government has however since 1979 provided financial assistance of a `seeding nature' under the Multicultural Education Program to assist education authorities to respond to the multicultural nature of Australian society. Funds made available under this Program will total $4.771m (including $0.382m for projects of national significance) in 1986. Funds will be distributed on an equal basis between general multicultural education activities and community language programs.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Proposed Twin City Relationship Proposal: Canberra and Versailles

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Territories, upon notice, on 17 October 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did he write to the Leader of the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly on 20 August 1985 on behalf of the Government, after consultation with the Prime Minister and the Minister for Foreign Affairs, endorsing the twin city relationship proposed between Canberra and the city of Versailles, France.

(2) What were the significant changed circumstances intervening which prompted him to send a message to the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly on 18 September 1985 asking that it not proceed with plans to establish this twin city relationship.
(3) Did this later message suggest that the reason for that decision was prompted by the Rainbow Warrior incident and the continuing French nuclear testing in the South Pacific.

(4) Is he able to say whether (a) the Rainbow Warrior vessel was bombed in Auckland Harbour on 10 July 1985 and the French Government involvement was established by 17 July 1985 well before his letter of 20 August and (b) there was any expectation on the Government's part on or before 20 August that French nuclear testing would be discontinued.
(5) If not, what other undisclosed reason exists for him to withdraw approval, given by him on 20 August 1985.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Scholes The Hon G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) The changed circumstances were as follows:
22 August 1985, one of those charged in New Zealand in relation to the Greenpeace incident was identified by New Zealand police as a French army officer;

25 August 1985, the Tricot report established that the French secret service had been authorised to collect information about Greenpeace and that the `Turenge couple' held by New Zealand police were, in fact, DGSE agents.
28 August 1985, the then Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Evans announced the Government's great concern over the French Government's handling of the matter.
10 September 1985, the ACT House of Assembly debated my earlier message agreeing to the proposed twinning arrangement; and
15 September 1985, following a visit to Mururoa, the French President announced that nuclear testing would continue as long as France considered it necessary.
Accordingly in my message of 18 September 1985, I informed the Assembly that it would be inappropriate to proceed with the proposed twin city arrangement.
(3) No, the reason was expanded upon in my media release made on the same date.

(4) (a) The Rainbow Warrior was bombed on 10 July 1985 but charges were not laid against the French agents until August. The French Government did not admit involvement in the bombing until 22 September 1985.

(b) The Government has never believed that it will be easy to bring about an end to nuclear testing at Mururoa Atoll but Australia is nevertheless committed to that objective and has vigorously pursued it.
